title_it: Cancer in pregnancy 15 years after
title_en: Cancer in pregnancy 15 years after
venue: Aula Magna Università degli Studi di Milano
presentationDescription_it: In the past, the diagnosis of cancer during pregnancy was one of the greatest tragedies in a woman‘s life. In many instances, the choice was either to sacrifice the fetus or to jeopardize the chances of administering an effective treatment to the mother. Many advances have been made in the last 15 years and this situation, albeit still difficult to manage, has now completely changed: in most instances the mother’s cancer can be treated during the pregnancy without harming the fetus. The most common cancers in pregnancy are those with a peak incidence during the woman‘s reproductive period and include cancer of the breast and cervix, melanomas, lymphomas, and leukemias. As the trend for delaying pregnancy into the later reproductive years continues, this rare association is likely to become more common. Several medical, psychological, social, and ethical issues should be considered when treating a pregnant patient with cancer and a multidisciplinary team of trained professionals should be available within a hub and spoke model, to offer each pregnant mother with cancer, to her physician and all members of the oncology team, adequate care and support. In this 2-days congress, all the different aspects of cancer and pregnancy will be discussed by a panel of international experts that have significantly contributed to elucidating epidemiology, biology and best treatment for each oncological disease diagnosed during pregnancy. Enough time will be reserved for case discussion, exchanging opinions and thoughts in addition to the presentation of new data in the poster discussion session. Thanks to Milan University and to Fondazione Menarini, we will be hosted in one of the most beautiful venues in town: the fifteenth century Ospedale Maggiore Ca’ Granda with its cloisters and Aula Magna.&nbsp; <p>&nbsp;</p> <p style="text-align: center;">We hope you will enjoy the Course.&nbsp;</p> <p style="text-align: center;">Fedro A. Peccatori and Giovanna Scarfone Course Directors</p> <p style="text-align: left;">&nbsp;</p>

Enough time will be reserved for case discussion, exchanging opinions and thoughts in addition to the presentation of new data in the poster discussion session. title_it: 2019 Esc Guidelines on the Management of Chronic Coronary Syndromes: a Critical Approach
title_en: 2019 Esc Guidelines on the Management of Chronic Coronary Syndromes: a Critical Approach
presentationDescription_it: <h1>CHRONIC CORONARY SYNDROMES A CRITICAL APPROACH</h1> <span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">Dear Colleagues,</span><p style="margin: 0px 0px 18px; border: 0px; font-size: 14px; line-height: 1.6em; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">Coronary artery disease (CAD) affects the global human population and is the major cause of death in both the developed and developing countries. Lifestyle, environment, and genetics, pose as risk factors for the development of cardiovascular disease.&nbsp;<br />The prevalence of risk factors among healthy individuals (diabetes mellitus, hypertension, smoking, hyperlipidemia, obesity, and psychosocial stress) predicts the occurrence of CAD in the near future.<br />The diagnostic management of patients with angina pectoris typically aims at the detection of obstructive epicardial CAD. This clinical paradigm fails to account for the considerable proportion (approximately one-third) of patients with angina in whom obstructive CAD is excluded. This common scenario presents a diagnostic conundrum<br />whereby angina occurs but there is no obstructive CAD (ischaemia and no obstructive coronary artery disease—INOCA).<br />The proper management of CAD and modification of its morbid course has been established through extensive studies and trials. RAS blockers, statins and aspirin are used for the secondary prevention of the disease , and revascularization when indicated, nitrates, β-blockers, calcium antagonists, ivabradine, trimetazidine and ranolazine are some of the therapeutic approaches used for the symptomatic relief of angina associated with CAD.<br />In our scientific program we are going to discuss the most important risk factors related to CHD, with focus on hypertension and other consequences of CHD, and the recent published<br />ESC guidelines for acute pulmonary embolism, dyslipidaemias, diabetes pre-diabetes and cardiovascular disease, and supraventricular arrhythmias.<br />Experts from all around the world will discuss the hot topics of the just presented ESC guidelines on CHD, and we are going to have a critical approach of them in two panel discussions.<br />At the end of our scientific meeting four case studies based on the topics discussed will be presented , as a trigger to initiate an interactive discussion with all participants.<br /><br /><em>Athanasios J. Manolis<br />President of the Scientific Meeting</em><br /></p>
presentationDescription_en: <h1>CHRONIC CORONARY SYNDROMES A CRITICAL APPROACH</h1> <span style="text-decoration-color: initial; color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px;">Dear Colleagues,</span><p style="text-decoration-color: initial; margin: 0px 0px 18px; border: 0px; font-size: 14px; line-height: 1.6em; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; color: #222222;">Coronary artery disease (CAD) affects the global human population and is the major cause of death in both the developed and developing countries. Lifestyle, environment, and genetics, pose as risk factors for the development of cardiovascular disease.&nbsp;<br />The prevalence of risk factors among healthy individuals (diabetes mellitus, hypertension, smoking, hyperlipidemia, obesity, and psychosocial stress) predicts the occurrence of CAD in the near future.<br />The diagnostic management of patients with angina pectoris typically aims at the detection of obstructive epicardial CAD. This clinical paradigm fails to account for the considerable proportion (approximately one-third) of patients with angina in whom obstructive CAD is excluded. This common scenario presents a diagnostic conundrum<br />whereby angina occurs but there is no obstructive CAD (ischaemia and no obstructive coronary artery disease—INOCA).<br />The proper management of CAD and modification of its morbid course has been established through extensive studies and trials. RAS blockers, statins and aspirin are used for the secondary prevention of the disease , and revascularization when indicated, nitrates, β-blockers, calcium antagonists, ivabradine, trimetazidine and ranolazine are some of the therapeutic approaches used for the symptomatic relief of angina associated with CAD.<br />In our scientific program we are going to discuss the most important risk factors related to CHD, with focus on hypertension and other consequences of CHD, and the recent published<br />ESC guidelines for acute pulmonary embolism, dyslipidaemias, diabetes pre-diabetes and cardiovascular disease, and supraventricular arrhythmias.<br />Experts from all around the world will discuss the hot topics of the just presented ESC guidelines on CHD, and we are going to have a critical approach of them in two panel discussions.<br />At the end of our scientific meeting four case studies based on the topics discussed will be presented , as a trigger to initiate an interactive discussion with all participants.<br /><br /><em>Athanasios J. Manolis<br />President of the Scientific Meeting</em></p>

title_it: International Symposium on: Hot Topics in Respiratory Medicine
title_en: International Symposium on: Hot Topics in Respiratory Medicine
presentationDescription_it: <span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">Chronic respiratory diseases are common and increasing in relative terms as causes of disability and death.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;" /><span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">The two main conditions contributing to death and disability are asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Both are clinical diagnoses and are associated with narrowed airways and difficulty exhaling. Asthma has become more common in many countries in parallel with increasing prevalence of allergic sensitization. COPD, in particular, is an increasing burden as the world’s population ages and tobacco smoking increases in many low- and middle-income countries, especially among women. Systemic inflammation induced by smoking can also cause chronic heart failure, metabolic syndrome and other chronic diseases, which can contribute to the clinical manifestations and natural history of COPD. Therefore, COPD can no longer be considered a lung disease alone, as it is often associated with a wide range of systemic consequences.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;" /><span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">A better understanding of the origin and consequences of systemic inflammation and potential therapies will most likely lead to better care of patients with COPD. Senescence is an irreversible process by which cells enter to a permanent cell cycle arrest with generalized molecular changes.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;" /><span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">Senescent cells remain metabolically active and most of them show a secretory phenotype; through its secretion may induce senescence or cancer in other cells. The secretory cells in the so-called transient senescence may participate in embryogenesis, tissue regeneration and immune response. The deleterious changes associated with age affect the immune system members and the immune senescence cause poor response to vaccines and susceptibility to cancer and infections.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;" /><span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">These latter are a frequent cause of asthma mostly in the elderly, the incidence is increasing in old people, and it may be related with those anatomical, physiological and immune changes caused by age, asthma chronicity and external agents.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;" /><span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">New kids are on the block: bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis in the adult setting, new treatment for interstitial lung diseases and pulmonary hypertension. The goal of the congress is also to share the new pharmacological approaches to the complexity of respiratory diseases and their potential to modify the systemic effects of respiratory diseases. Digital health will be also addressed targeting the new digital medicine approach. All these important issues will be discussed in Prague, on November 15th - 16th, 2019</span>&nbsp;
presentationDescription_en: <span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">Chronic respiratory diseases are common and increasing in relative terms as causes of disability and death.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;" /><span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">The two main conditions contributing to death and disability are asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Both are clinical diagnoses and are associated with narrowed airways and difficulty exhaling. Asthma has become more common in many countries in parallel with increasing prevalence of allergic sensitization. COPD, in particular, is an increasing burden as the world’s population ages and tobacco smoking increases in many low- and middle-income countries, especially among women. Systemic inflammation induced by smoking can also cause chronic heart failure, metabolic syndrome and other chronic diseases, which can contribute to the clinical manifestations and natural history of COPD. Therefore, COPD can no longer be considered a lung disease alone, as it is often associated with a wide range of systemic consequences.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;" /><span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">A better understanding of the origin and consequences of systemic inflammation and potential therapies will most likely lead to better care of patients with COPD. Senescence is an irreversible process by which cells enter to a permanent cell cycle arrest with generalized molecular changes.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;" /><span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">Senescent cells remain metabolically active and most of them show a secretory phenotype; through its secretion may induce senescence or cancer in other cells. The secretory cells in the so-called transient senescence may participate in embryogenesis, tissue regeneration and immune response. The deleterious changes associated with age affect the immune system members and the immune senescence cause poor response to vaccines and susceptibility to cancer and infections.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;" /><span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">These latter are a frequent cause of asthma mostly in the elderly, the incidence is increasing in old people, and it may be related with those anatomical, physiological and immune changes caused by age, asthma chronicity and external agents.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;" /><span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">New kids are on the block: bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis in the adult setting, new treatment for interstitial lung diseases and pulmonary hypertension. The goal of the congress is also to share the new pharmacological approaches to the complexity of respiratory diseases and their potential to modify the systemic effects of respiratory diseases. Digital health will be also addressed targeting the new digital medicine approach. All these important issues will be discussed in Prague, on November 15th - 16th, 2019</span>&nbsp;

title_it: Seminars in Respiratory Medicine: Juniors meet Seniors
title_en: Seminars in Respiratory Medicine: Juniors meet Seniors
description_it: A new event targeting a limited number of leaders in the field and selected participants.
description_en: A new event targeting a limited number of leaders in the field and selected participants.
presentationDescription_it: <div>Seminars in Respiratory Medicine: Juniors meet Experts is a new event targeting a limited number of leaders in the field and selected participants. </div><div><br /></div><div>The format is structured to gather faculty and attending doctors for a two-day full immersion, in a special brainstorming way. It will be a unique opportunity to debate hot topics and new issues in respiratory medicine. </div><div>The Seminar will allow junior physicians to be in close contact with experts in an unformal way, with enough time to build new knowledge and ideas for future research. Juniors will actively participate as Faculty members to the meeting and to the interactive discussion.</div><div><br /></div><div>The first edition of Seminars in Respiratory Medicine will take place in Fiesole, Italy, an extraordinary location. This event will promote lively discussion in order to help junior physicians to grow in their professional career.</div><div><br /></div><div>Seminars in Respiratory Medicine: Juniors meet Experts is a Fondazione Menarini non-profit association event developed with an unrestricted support. </div><div><br /></div><div><em>Sergio Harari and Marc Humbert</em></div><div>Co-Presidents of the Meeting</div>
presentationDescription_en: <div>Seminars in Respiratory Medicine: Juniors meet Experts is a new event targeting a limited number of leaders in the field and selected participants.</div><div><br /></div><div>The format is structured to gather faculty and attending doctors for a two-day full immersion, in a special brainstorming way. It will be a unique opportunity to debate hot topics and new issues in respiratory medicine.</div><div>The Seminar will allow junior physicians to be in close contact with experts in an unformal way, with enough time to build new knowledge and ideas for future research. Juniors will actively participate as Faculty members to the meeting and to the interactive discussion.</div><div><br /></div><div>The first edition of Seminars in Respiratory Medicine will take place in Fiesole, Italy, an extraordinary location. This event will promote lively discussion in order to help junior physicians to grow in their professional career.</div><div><br /></div><div>Seminars in Respiratory Medicine: Juniors meet Experts is a Fondazione Menarini non-profit association event developed with an unrestricted support.</div><div><br /></div><div><em>Sergio Harari and Marc Humbert</em></div><div>Co-Presidents of the Meeting</div>

title_it: International Congress of Geriatric Cardiology
title_en: International Congress of Geriatric Cardiology
description_it: Cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases nowadays occur in patients who are on average 15-20 years older than those enrolled in trials used to build international guidelines.
description_en: Cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases nowadays occur in patients who are on average 15-20 years older than those enrolled in trials used to build international guidelines.
presentationDescription_it: <div>Cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases nowadays occur in patients who are on average 15-20 years older than those enrolled in trials used to build international guidelines. </div><div>Therefore, cardiologists feel the need to confront with geriatricians and gerontologists in order to define multimorbidity, frailty and disability and choose the best therapeutic options to select an individually tailored management, in which quality of life and functional independence are considered to be more valuable goals than life expectancy.</div><div><br /></div><div>The main issues of Geriatric Cardiology will be discussed in the International Congress following a multidisciplinary approach and, for each issue, the gaps between guidelines and real clinical practice will be highlighted, with an attempt at filling such gaps through the production of shared consensus statements. </div><div><br /></div><div>In accordance with this general goal, the international speakers will be asked to provide the key elements that are needed to best assess the risk / benefit ratio of therapeutic strategies in multiple areas of cardio- and cerebrovascular diseases in older persons. The main topics will be arterial hypertension, heart failure, atrial fibrillation, stroke, ischemic heart disease, structural cardiology and cardiac surgery and electrical therapy of cardiac diseases.</div><p style="margin: 0px 0px 18px; border: 0px; font-size: 14px; line-height: 1.6em; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;"><strong style="border: 0px; line-height: inherit;"><br /></strong></p><p style="margin: 0px 0px 18px; border: 0px; font-size: 14px; line-height: 1.6em; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;"><span style="border: 0px; line-height: inherit;"><strong>Co-Presidents of the Congress<br /></strong></span>Alessandro Boccanelli, Niccolò Marchionni, Andrea Ungar</p>
presentationDescription_en: <div>Cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases nowadays occur in patients who are on average 15-20 years older than those enrolled in trials used to build international guidelines.</div><div>Therefore, cardiologists feel the need to confront with geriatricians and gerontologists in order to define multimorbidity, frailty and disability and choose the best therapeutic options to select an individually tailored management, in which quality of life and functional independence are considered to be more valuable goals than life expectancy.</div><div><br /></div><div>The main issues of Geriatric Cardiology will be discussed in the International Congress following a multidisciplinary approach and, for each issue, the gaps between guidelines and real clinical practice will be highlighted, with an attempt at filling such gaps through the production of shared consensus statements.</div><div><br /></div><div>In accordance with this general goal, the international speakers will be asked to provide the key elements that are needed to best assess the risk / benefit ratio of therapeutic strategies in multiple areas of cardio- and cerebrovascular diseases in older persons. The main topics will be arterial hypertension, heart failure, atrial fibrillation, stroke, ischemic heart disease, structural cardiology and cardiac surgery and electrical therapy of cardiac diseases.</div><p style="margin: 0px 0px 18px; border: 0px; font-size: 14px; line-height: 1.6em; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;"><strong style="border: 0px; line-height: inherit;"><br /></strong></p><p style="margin: 0px 0px 18px; border: 0px; font-size: 14px; line-height: 1.6em; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;"><strong style="border: 0px; line-height: inherit;">Co-Presidents of the Congress<br /><span style="font-weight: normal;">Alessandro Boccanelli, Niccolò Marchionni, Andrea Ungar</span></strong></p>

title_it: Functional and Fertility Sparing Procedure in Gynaecology
title_en: Functional and Fertility Sparing Procedure in Gynaecology
description_it: This meeting aims to provide the most recent update on the mechanisms of regulation the function of female pelvic organs and on the procedures of functional and fertility saving in cases of diseases.
description_en: This meeting aims to provide the most recent update on the mechanisms of regulation the function of female pelvic organs and on the procedures of functional and fertility saving in cases of diseases.
presentationDescription_it: <p>The reproductive system and the pelvic organs can face, even in young or fertile age, a series of pathologies that can alter or limit their functions.</p><p>The management of young patients with early diagnosed gynaecologic cancer or severe pelvic disease who wish to become pregnant is a major challenge, especially as the number of survivors of young reproductive cancer is rising. This is due both to the increase in the incidence of gynaecological cancer in young patients and to the increasing age in which women seek the first pregnancy. </p><p> Moreover, severe and widespread benign diseases, typical of the fertile age, such as severe forms of endometriosis and some uterine pathologies may endanger functional and reproductive integrity. </p><p> The organs contained in the pelvis are regulated by extremely delicate mechanisms that can be damaged not only by various diseases, but also by medical or surgical procedures that do not respect the different functional characteristics. </p><p>Just think of the low tract urinary system functions, the procedures that regulates defecation, the mechanisms of sexual functions, the delicate processes that allow the fertilization of the oocytes and the implantation of embryos. </p><p> The conflict between treatments for the preservation of functions of the pelvic organs and fertility and any radical intervention in many cases involves great medical and ethical dilemmas. </p><p> This meeting aims to provide the most recent update on the mechanisms of regulation the function of female pelvic organs and on the procedures of functional and fertility saving in cases of benign and malignant diseases.</p><p><br /></p><p>Co-Presidents of the Meetings:</p><p><em>Renato Seracchioli <br />Valentino Remorgida <br />Errico Zupi&nbsp;</em></p><div style="text-align: center;"><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/BOLOGNA20-21Febbraio2020-bannerTitolo.jpg" alt="" /></div>
presentationDescription_en: <p>The reproductive system and the pelvic organs can face, even in young or fertile age, a series of pathologies that can alter or limit their functions.</p><p>The management of young patients with early diagnosed gynaecologic cancer or severe pelvic disease who wish to become pregnant is a major challenge, especially as the number of survivors of young reproductive cancer is rising. This is due both to the increase in the incidence of gynaecological cancer in young patients and to the increasing age in which women seek the first pregnancy.</p><p>Moreover, severe and widespread benign diseases, typical of the fertile age, such as severe forms of endometriosis and some uterine pathologies may endanger functional and reproductive integrity.</p><p>The organs contained in the pelvis are regulated by extremely delicate mechanisms that can be damaged not only by various diseases, but also by medical or surgical procedures that do not respect the different functional characteristics.</p><p>Just think of the low tract urinary system functions, the procedures that regulates defecation, the mechanisms of sexual functions, the delicate processes that allow the fertilization of the oocytes and the implantation of embryos.</p><p>The conflict between treatments for the preservation of functions of the pelvic organs and fertility and any radical intervention in many cases involves great medical and ethical dilemmas.</p><p>This meeting aims to provide the most recent update on the mechanisms of regulation the function of female pelvic organs and on the procedures of functional and fertility saving in cases of benign and malignant diseases.</p><p><br /></p><p>Co-Presidents of the Meetings:</p><p><em>Renato Seracchioli&nbsp;<br />Valentino Remorgida&nbsp;<br />Errico Zupi&nbsp;</em></p><div style="text-align: center;"><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/BOLOGNA20-21Febbraio2020-bannerTitolo.jpg" alt="" /></div>

title_it: 12th Echo Hong Kong cum Meet the Masters & Experts Cardiology Conference From Imaging to Excellence in Clinical Management
title_en: 12th Echo Hong Kong cum Meet the Masters & Experts Cardiology Conference From Imaging to Excellence in Clinical Management
presentationDescription_it:
Dear Colleagues,

We are pleased to announce that the 12th Echo Hong Kong cum Meet the Masters & Experts Cardiology Conference will be held on 21-24 November 2019 at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre. Echo Hong Kong is the first-of-its-kind conference solely dedicated to echocardiography in the Asia Pacific region with live demonstration and hands-on workshops on patients having variety of cardiovascular diseases. Our goal is to provide top quality training and education to cardiologists and medical professionals. Through scientific exchange and experience sharing, delegates will gain practical knowledge and skills to enhance clinical cardiovascular patient care. Since its inception in 1997, the bi-annual Echo Hong Kong has attracted thousands of delegates from all over the world. The feedback is overwhelmingly excellent and encouraging.
With the theme "From Imaging to Excellence in Clinical Management", a stimulating program including state-of-the-art lectures, debates, case studies with the experts, live demonstration, hands-on workshops & learning labs, echo case & clinical case competitions has been developed. New & special this year, we have added a full-day Sunday session on Clinical Cardiology: "Pearls & Wisdom from the Masters & Experts for Clinical Excellence in Patient Management" in the Conference. Internationally renowned speakers & teachers around the world have been invited as our esteemed faculty. Cardiologists, physicians, emergency room or critical care physicians, anaesthetists, nurses, sonographers and professionals with interest in echocardiography and cardiology will all benefit from this clinically oriented scientific program.
Don't miss out our well-received hands-on workshops as capacity is always exceeded early in the course of registration and we have to turn down numerous late comers in order to maintain quality interactions. We are confident that the upcoming meeting will bring to our delegates an insightful & rewarding learning experience, as well as fostering friendship with colleagues around the world. Our overseas guests will also enjoy the sights and sounds of this beautiful, dynamic & legendary Asia World City, with tax-free shopping opportunities, internationally renowned cuisine, & the friendly people of Hong Kong.
Looking forward to seeing you all in the fine cool November in Hong Kong!

Yuk-Kong Lau MBBS (HK),
FHKCP, FHKAM (Med),
FRCP (London),
FRCP (Edinburgh), FACC

Kwok-Lun Lee MBBS (HK),
MRCP (UK), FHKCP,
FHKAM (Med),
FRCP (Edinburgh)

Thomas Prabowo Tunggal MBBS (HK),
MRCP (UK), FHKCP,
FHKAM (Med),
FRCP (Edinburgh)

title_it: XLVI Corso Di Aggiornamento Alterazioni Congenite Ed Acquisite Della Coagulazione Focus Su: Sindrome Da Anticorpi Antifosfolipidi (APS): Prevenzione, Diagnosi E Trattamento
title_en: XLVI Corso Di Aggiornamento Alterazioni Congenite Ed Acquisite Della Coagulazione Focus Su: Sindrome Da Anticorpi Antifosfolipidi (APS): Prevenzione, Diagnosi E Trattamento
presentationDescription_it:
Le malattie della coagulazione sono la causa della trombosi, cioè dell’occlusione delle arterie e delle vene con conseguente insufficiente apporto di sangue e di ossigeno e morte dei tessuti. Dalla trombosi sono causate le più frequenti e importanti malattie, come l’infarto del miocardio e l’ictus cerebrale, che colpiscono insieme almeno 300.000 persone all’anno nel nostro paese. Con queste premesse, si evince l’importanza di un aggiornamento continuo dei medici sul tema, che la Fondazione Menarini (con il comitato scientifico composto dai maggiori esperti Italiani) affronta a Napoli (25-26 Novembre 2019) per mezzo di questo corso: che è ormai storico avendo raggiunto nel 2019 ben 46 edizioni annuali! Come da tradizione, vengono affrontati argomenti vari sulle varie e molteplici malattie della coagulazione, che vanno dal ruolo dell’inquinamento atmosferico nel facilitare l’insorgenza di trombosi all’effetto protettivo della dieta mediterranea, dimostrato una volta di più dallo studio in corso in Molise. Insieme a questi ed altri argomenti di aggiornamento attuale, il Focus del Corso, che tradizionalmente si svolge per tutto il pomeriggio del primo giorno del corso (25 Novembre) si affronta più specificatamente e approfonditamente i molti problemi ancora non risolti di una relativamente rara ma importante causa di trombosi, sia arteriosa che venosa: la sindrome da anticorpi antifosfolipidi. I problemi di questa sindrome sono sia i metodi di laboratorio più idonei per stabilirne con certezza la diagnosi, che la terapia e prevenzione secondaria, particolarmente rilevanti perché le strategie antitrombotiche tradizionali sono spesso insufficienti per la prevenzione delle recidive. Per questi motivi il 46° Corso è rivolto sia ai clinici che ai laboratoristi.

Prof. Pier Mannuccio Mannucci
Responsabile scientifico

"

title_it: What we need to know for winning the battle against superbugs?
title_en: What we need to know for winning the battle against superbugs?
description_it: The World Economic Forum included antibiotic resistance as a global risk – not just a global health risk, but a global risk. Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) also recently appeared as a discussion topic
description_en: The World Economic Forum included antibiotic resistance as a global risk – not just a global health risk, but a global risk. Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) also recently appeared as a discussion topic
presentationDescription_it: <div style="text-align: center;"><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/Genova16-17Gennaio2020-banner-titolo.jpg" alt="" /></div><div style="text-align: left;">The World Economic Forum included antibiotic resistance as a global risk – not just a global health risk, but a global risk. Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) also recently appeared as a discussion topic at the G8 summit.</div><div><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;">This is a topic that is now discussed in the popular press, in talk shows, in television documentaries, and increasingly, in people’s homes. </div><div><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;">The problem has only grown over the years. It has surfaced across the range of bacterial infections from tuberculosis to gonorrhea to staph to gram-negative sepsis. Patients with all these diseases have borne the consequences of drug resistance. It occurs in our homes, in our hospitals, in our families, and in our farms. As a result, we now have examples of organisms that show near universal resistance to currently available drugs – what the media has dubbed the superbugs. </div><div><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;">It’s worth pointing out that AMR is an equal opportunity threat. It causes problems whether you live in South Asia or Southern Europe, in South Africa or South America. We’re all in this together. </div><div><br /></div><div>For decades we’ve convinced ourselves that we could innovate our way out of the problem simply by coming up with new antibiotics. That actually worked pretty well for decades. You might say we became victims of our own success. We made it very easy to take antibiotics because they were inexpensive and available. </div><div><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;">So, for many reasons, we’ve reached the tipping point. AMR has now climbed the ladder of public health priorities and gotten near the top. This attention provides an unprecedented opportunity to finally do something about this problem and reverse the tide on resistance. </div><div><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;">One of the principles central to slowing the development of resistance is the judicious use of antibiotics. A key way to achieve this result is through antibiotic stewardship programs. </div><div><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;">Given the focus of the conference “What we need to know for winning the battle against superbugs?”, much of the discussion will try to address the problem of multi-drug resistant organisms and the use of antibiotics.</div>
presentationDescription_en: <div style="text-align: center;"><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/Genova16-17Gennaio2020-banner-titolo.jpg" alt="" /></div><div style="text-align: left;">The World Economic Forum included antibiotic resistance as a global risk – not just a global health risk, but a global risk. Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) also recently appeared as a discussion topic at the G8 summit.</div><div><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;">This is a topic that is now discussed in the popular press, in talk shows, in television documentaries, and increasingly, in people’s homes.</div><div><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;">The problem has only grown over the years. It has surfaced across the range of bacterial infections from tuberculosis to gonorrhea to staph to gram-negative sepsis. Patients with all these diseases have borne the consequences of drug resistance. It occurs in our homes, in our hospitals, in our families, and in our farms. As a result, we now have examples of organisms that show near universal resistance to currently available drugs – what the media has dubbed the superbugs.</div><div><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;">It’s worth pointing out that AMR is an equal opportunity threat. It causes problems whether you live in&nbsp;South Asia or Southern Europe, in South Africa or South America. We’re all in this together.</div><div><br /></div><div>For decades we’ve convinced ourselves that we could innovate our way out of the problem simply by coming up with new antibiotics. That actually worked pretty well for decades. You might say we became victims of our own success. We made it very easy to take antibiotics because they were inexpensive and available.</div><div><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;">So, for many reasons, we’ve reached the tipping point. AMR has now climbed the ladder of public health priorities and gotten near the top. This attention provides an unprecedented opportunity to finally do something about this problem and reverse the tide on resistance.</div><div><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;">One of the principles central to slowing the development of resistance is the judicious use of antibiotics. A key way to achieve this result is through antibiotic stewardship programs.</div><div><br /></div><div style="text-align: left;">Given the focus of the conference “What we need to know for winning the battle against superbugs?”, much of the discussion will try to address the problem of multi-drug resistant organisms and the use of antibiotics.</div>&nbsp;

title_it: Diretta Video Streaming: Incontri con la città - Sempre più ricchi, sempre più poveri: le dinamiche della povertà nel mondo
title_en: Diretta Video Streaming: Incontri con la città - Sempre più ricchi, sempre più poveri: le dinamiche della povertà nel mondo
presentationDescription_it: <div><div>Domenica 10 maggio alle 10.30 dall&#39;aula magna del rettorato verrà trasmessa in diretta online la lezione del prof. <strong>Mario Biggeri</strong>, docente di economia applicata, dal titolo<strong> &quot;Sempre più ricchi, sempre più poveri: le dinamiche della povertà nel mondo&quot;</strong>. </div><div><br /></div><div>La lezione sarà preceduta dai saluti istituzionali, dal momento che sarà la prima di questo ciclo (gli incontri di marzo e aprile saranno recuperati successivamente, in date ancora da definire).&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>L&#39;incontro sarà moderato da <strong>Gianni Pietraperzia</strong>, ricercatore e membro del comitato organizzatore, che raccoglierà le domande che arriveranno dal pubblico tramite messaggio al numero 347-5804905. </div><div><br /></div><div>La lezione sarà trasmessa in diretta dalla homepage di ateneo.</div><div><br /></div><div><span style="font-size: 18pt;"><strong><a href="https://www.unifi.it/mod-MDVideo.html" target="_blank">Clicca qui per vedere in diretta la lezione</a></strong></span></div><div><br /></div><br /></div><div><table style="border-spacing: 0px; title_it: Keystone Symposia: Transforming Vaccinology
title_en: Keystone Symposia: Transforming Vaccinology
presentationDescription_it:
Along with clean water and antibiotics, vaccination has allowed mankind to conquer the infectious diseases that used to eradicate about 50% of children. Over the last century, vaccination has also extended life expectancy from under 50 to over 80 years of age. Now that the most important vaccines for infants and children are available, vaccination faces new challenges with the intent to bring the benefits of vaccines to other age groups, emerging infections, antimicrobial resistance, diseases that afflict low-income countries, and to improve therapies against chronic infectious diseases, cancer, autoimmune and neurodegenerative diseases.

This new vaccine ambition is supported by the incredible advances in science and technology that make it technically possible to develop vaccines against many new targets and by innovative approaches to vaccine development for emerging infections and for diseases of low-income countries. The technologies that are transforming vaccinology are structure-based design, adjuvants, nucleic acid vaccines (especially RNA), viral vectors, systems biology, and controlled human infections. They are supported by scientific advances in human immunology, genomics, synthetic biology, molecular structure of antigens and antigen-antibody complexes, germinal centers, and microbiome. Conference participants will be exposed to the multidisciplinary technologies that are transforming vaccinology, including the efforts of CEPI, Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and Wellcome Trust, to change the way vaccines are developed.

"

title_it: International Symposium: Cardiometabolic Risk and Vascular Disease from Mechanisms to Treatment
title_en: International Symposium: Cardiometabolic Risk and Vascular Disease from Mechanisms to Treatment
venue: Sune Bergstroem Hall, Karolinska University Hospital
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="color: #202124; font-family: Roboto, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-weight: 400; text-align: start; white-space: pre-wrap; text-decoration-color: initial;">This two-day programme offers a comprehensive update of cardiometabolic risk presented by a distinguished international teaching faculty. The educational objectives are to review and disseminate the latest knowledge about advances in the pathophysiology, diagnosis and treatment of cardiometabolic risk and to discuss its impact in clinical practice. The scientific programme covers a broad spectrum of topics including the relationship between immunity and metabolism as well as inflammation and atherosclerosis; preventive strategies; evidence-based management of obesity and insulin resistance; atherothrombosis and strategies beyond glycemic control; diabetes, acute coronary syndromes and heart failure. Our Symposium is designed to promote a working and learning environment across specialty borders.</span><br /></strong></p><p style="text-align: center;"><em><strong><span style="font-weight: 400;">Francesco Cosentino</span></strong></em></p><p style="text-align: center;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: center;"><strong>CHAIRMAN</strong><br /> Francesco Cosentino<br /> Unit of Cardiology<br /> Department of Medicine, Solna<br /> Karolinska Institute &amp; Karolinska University Hospital<br /> Stockholm, Sweden<br /><br /> CO - ORGANIZED BY<br /> Karolinska Institute &amp; Karolinska University Hospital<br /> Stockholm, Sweden and Fondazione Internazionale Menarini</p><p style="text-align: center;"><br /></p><p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="color: #124173; font-family: &quot;Microsoft Sans Serif&quot;;"><span style="font-weight: 700;">Puoi scegliere 2 modalità di partecipazione: in streaming (Tab LIVE STREAMING) </span></span></span></p><p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: center;"><span style="color: #124173; font-family: &quot;Microsoft Sans Serif&quot;; font-size: 10pt;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="font-weight: 700;">o con presenza all&#39;evento (Tab PARTECIPAZIONE RESIDENZIALE)</span></span><br /></span></p>
presentationDescription_en: <p style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="color: #202124; font-family: Roboto, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-weight: 400; white-space: pre-wrap; text-decoration-color: initial;">This two-day programme offers a comprehensive update of cardiometabolic risk presented by a distinguished international teaching faculty. The educational objectives are to review and disseminate the latest knowledge about advances in the pathophysiology, diagnosis and treatment of cardiometabolic risk and to discuss its impact in clinical practice. The scientific programme covers a broad spectrum of topics including the relationship between immunity and metabolism as well as inflammation and atherosclerosis; preventive strategies; evidence-based management of obesity and insulin resistance; atherothrombosis and strategies beyond glycemic control; diabetes, acute coronary syndromes and heart failure. Our Symposium is designed to promote a working and learning environment across specialty borders.</span><br /></strong></p><p style="text-align: center;"><em><strong><span style="font-weight: 400;">Francesco Cosentino</span></strong></em></p><p style="text-align: center;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: center;"><strong>CHAIRMAN</strong><br />Francesco Cosentino<br />Unit of Cardiology<br />Department of Medicine, Solna<br />Karolinska Institute &amp; Karolinska University Hospital<br />Stockholm, Sweden<br /><br />CO - ORGANIZED BY<br />Karolinska Institute &amp; Karolinska University Hospital<br />Stockholm, Sweden and Fondazione Internazionale Menarini</p><p style="text-align: left; margin: 0pt;"><br /></p><p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: center;"><span style="color: #124173; font-family: &quot;Microsoft Sans Serif&quot;; font-size: 10pt;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><strong>You can choose between 2 ways of participating: streaming (Tab LIVE STREAMING) </strong></span></span></p><p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: center;"><span style="color: #124173; font-family: &quot;Microsoft Sans Serif&quot;; font-size: 10pt;"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><strong>or by attending the event (Tab RESIDENTIAL ATTENDANCE)</strong></span></span></p><p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: center;"><br /></p>

title_it: JUvenile Sudden cardiac deaTh: JUST know and treat
title_en: JUvenile Sudden cardiac deaTh: JUST know and treat
presentationDescription_it:
When a death occurs in professional sport context or in any apparently healthy young individual, public opinion demands an adequate response from the clinical and scientific community.
Few medical conditions are more traumatic than sudden cardiac death (SCD), not anticipated by any symptom, of a young person. It is a rare event, generally linked to a fatal arrhythmia, but its dramatic presentation and the impact on the family and the whole community finds an amplified resonance in the cases of athletes, perfectly exemplifying the metaphor of a vulnerability hidden in an apparently healthy body.
In the general population, there is great concern about juvenile SCD risk, a perception even greater than that experienced in more frequent fatal conditions, such as accidents, suicides, violence. Overall, it is justified to consider the SCD of the young as a threat to global health. The development of strategies based on both scientific evidences and expert consensus is therefore required to reduce the impact of juvenile SCD.
SCD in young people, including about 25% of cases occurring during sports activities, is rare (estimated incidence is between 1 and 10 cases/100000 people/year), but its impact in terms of years of life lost is considerable, given the long life expectancy of young people. Cardiac arrest in a young person can be caused by hereditary conditions, such as hypertrophic, dilated and arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathies, or mutations that alter the proteins that control the heart rhythm causing diseases in which the patient’s heart, while appearing normal to clinical investigations, is predisposed to have serious arrhythmias (the so-called channelopathies: long QT syndrome and short QT, Brugada syndrome, catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia). In the individual patient, these conditions can be asymptomatic and undiagnosed, so that sudden cardiac death may be the first clinical manifestation. It is estimated that cardiopulmonary resuscitation and the widespread availability of external semi-automatic defibrillators could prevent about a quarter of juvenile SCD.
The topic of SCD in the young will be addressed by experts evaluating pathophysiologic, diagnostic and therapeutic issues related to this fatal condition. Thanks to the Fondazione Menarini, we will have the opportunity to meet in Pisa, one of the most beautiful cities in Tuscany, in a workshop endorsed by all the University and Research organizations of the city, currently involved in a research project on juvenile SCD. We hope that participating to this workshop will be as interesting and stimulating as its organization.

title_it: Webinar - respirami - air pollution and covid-19: mechanisms, preliminary findings and ways ahead
title_en: Webinar - respirami - air pollution and covid-19: mechanisms, preliminary findings and ways ahead
presentationDescription_it: <div><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><strong><span style="color: #993300;">Presentation and rationale</span></strong></span><br /><br /></div><div>The human coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID_19) is an infectious disease caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), that in the first six months of 2020 spread to at least 200 countries of the world.The first epicenter was in January the city of Wuhan and caused in the whole China 84.000 infected cases and 4600 deaths. The first epicenter in Europe was Italy in February-March and particularly the Northern region of Lombardy, causing in whole country approximately 240.000 infections and 35.000 fatalities. Other heavily affected European countries were Spain, France, the UK and Russia. COVID-19 then spread to the Americas with a first epicenter in April in New York City, causing in the USA at least 2.000.000 infections and 115.000 fatalities.In the frame of this dramatic global scenario there is still considerable uncertainty pertaining to the mechanisms of viral spread and the factors that contribute to the different degree of disease severity. It is plausible that an environmental risk factor such as ambient air pollution characterized by a high population attributable fraction plays a key role in increasing the likelihood of spread and severe clinical outcomes in COVID-19, because ambient air pollution has an adverse impact on global morbidity and mortality through components such as fine particulate matter (PM2.5), nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and ozone (O3). They affect human health by producing oxidative stress and inflammation, that is turn cause damage on the respiratory, cardiovascular and immune systems definitely involved in COVID-19. With this background, it is biologically plausible that the degree and duration of exposure to air pollution might have harmful effects on the occurrence and clinical course of COVID-19.With these gaps of knowledge this webinar is planned to contribute to a better understanding on whether or not short- and long-term exposure to ambient air pollution influences the spread and clinical manifestations of COVID-19. It is hoped that this initiative will update on the latest evidence and help to support and foster globally public health interventions targeted to protect people living in heavily polluted regions through efforts aimed to lower the emissions of the harmful components of ambient air.</div><p><br /></p><p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><em><strong>In the months of October and November there will be two webinars&nbsp;</strong></em></span><em style="font-size: 14pt;"><strong>that will focus on air pollution and its health effects.</strong></em></p><div><br /></div>
presentationDescription_en: <div><strong><span style="color: #800000;"><span style="font-size: 14pt;">Presentation and rationale</span><br /><br /></span></strong></div><div style="text-align: left;">The human coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID_19) is an infectious disease caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), that in the first six months of 2020 spread to at least 200 countries of the world.The first epicenter was in January the city of Wuhan and caused in the whole China 84.000 infected cases and 4600 deaths. The first epicenter in Europe was Italy in February-March and particularly the Northern region of Lombardy, causing in whole country approximately 240.000 infections and 35.000 fatalities. Other heavily affected European countries were Spain, France, the UK and Russia. COVID-19 then spread to the Americas with a first epicenter in April in New York City, causing in the USA at least 2.000.000 infections and 115.000 fatalities.In the frame of this dramatic global scenario there is still considerable uncertainty pertaining to the mechanisms of viral spread and the factors that contribute to the different degree of disease severity. It is plausible that an environmental risk factor such as ambient air pollution characterized by a high population attributable fraction plays a key role in increasing the likelihood of spread and severe clinical outcomes in COVID-19, because ambient air pollution has an adverse impact on global morbidity and mortality through components such as fine particulate matter (PM2.5), nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and ozone (O3). They affect human health by producing oxidative stress and inflammation, that is turn cause damage on the respiratory, cardiovascular and immune systems definitely involved in COVID-19. With this background, it is biologically plausible that the degree and duration of exposure to air pollution might have harmful effects on the occurrence and clinical course of COVID-19.With these gaps of knowledge this webinar is planned to contribute to a better understanding on whether or not short- and long-term exposure to ambient air pollution influences the spread and clinical manifestations of COVID-19. It is hoped that this initiative will update on the latest evidence and help to support and foster globally public health interventions targeted to protect people living in heavily polluted regions through efforts aimed to lower the emissions of the harmful components of ambient air.</div><p><br /></p><p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><em><strong>In the months of October and November there will be two webinars&nbsp;</strong></em></span><em style="font-size: 14pt;"><strong>that will focus on air pollution and its health effects.</strong></em>&nbsp;</p>

title_en: Convegno Internazionale di Suicidologia e Salute Pubblica XVIII Edizione
description_it: Welcome to the XVIII edition of the International Symposium on Suicidology and Public Health
description_en: Welcome to the XVIII edition of the International Symposium on Suicidology and Public Health
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 18pt;">Welcome to the <strong>XVIII edition</strong> of the <strong>International Symposium on Suicidology and Public Health</strong>, gathering the scientific community for an in-depth discussion on suicide risk, mental health, psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy in psychiatric field. </span></p><p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 18pt;">The conference will host renowned speakers and international opinion leaders.</span></p><p style="text-align: center;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="font-size: 24px;"><span style="color: #800000;">REGISTRAZIONE</span></span></strong></p><p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 24px;">Per registrarsi ai webinars, apri la locandina&nbsp;e clicca su i bottoni dedicati alla registrazione &quot;ISCRIVITI&quot;:</span></p><p style="text-align: center;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: center;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong style="text-decoration-line: underline;"><span style="font-size: 18pt; text-decoration-line: underline;"><a href="https://www.fondazione-menarini.it/Portals/19/eventi/Webinar-Suicidologia7-12Settembre2020-locandinaITA.pdf?ver=2020-08-03-112632-303" target="_blank">Clicca qui</a></span></strong></span></p>
presentationDescription_en: <p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 18pt;">Welcome to the&nbsp;<strong>XVIII edition</strong>&nbsp;of the&nbsp;<strong>International Symposium on Suicidology and Public Health</strong>, gathering the scientific community for an in-depth discussion on suicide risk, mental health, psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy in psychiatric field.</span></p><p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 18pt;">The conference will host renowned speakers and international opinion leaders.</span></p><p style="text-align: center;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="color: #800000; font-size: 24px;">REGISTRATION</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 18pt;">To register to webinars please open the file of the flyer and click on the&nbsp;<strong>REGISTRATION&nbsp;</strong>button.</span></p><p style="text-align: center;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong style="text-decoration-line: underline;"><span style="font-size: 18pt; text-decoration-line: underline;"><a href="https://www.en.fondazione-menarini.it/Home/Events/International-Symposium-on-Suicidology-and-Public-Health/738/Flyer" target="_blank">Click here</a></span></strong></span></p>

title_it: RESPIRAMI - Recent Advances on Air pollution and Health
title_en: RESPIRAMI - Recent Advances on Air pollution and Health
description_it: The Respirami 3 conference in Milan in January 2019 (http://www.ilpolmone.it/congresso-respirami-milano-2019) was a remarkable event with a large participation of international scientists...
description_en: The Respirami 3 conference in Milan in January 2019 (http://www.ilpolmone.it/congresso-respirami-milano-2019) was a remarkable event with a large participation of international scientists...
presentationDescription_it: <p><span style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;">The Respirami 3 conference in Milan in January 2019</span><span style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;was a remarkable event with a large participation of international scientists, professionals of the health care sector and environmental protection agencies, all providing an interesting update of the research on air pollution. Since then, research on the health effects of air pollution have progressed considerably. The Health Effects Institute, the European Respiratory Society (ERS), the World Health Organization (WHO), and the International Society for Environmental Epidemiology (ISEE) organized a joint meeting in Brussels, Belgium, on January 21-22, 2020 with the aim to review the latest science on major pollutants, focusing on particulate matter 2.5 μm or less in diameter (PM2.5) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), to help evaluate the need for updating Europe’s air quality policies. A number of important scientific and policy questions about the causal links between air pollution and health, its effects at low levels of exposure, the relative contributions of different sources or constituents, and ultimately the question of how to achieve the most health benefits most cost-effectively were considered.</span><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><span style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;">The present initiative will update Italian professional on the latest evidence and provide an interesting platform for future research applications and project. The initiative is planned as a series of webinar with at least three presentations (20 minutes each) and sufficient time for Questions and Answers.</span><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><strong style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify; font-size: 18px; line-height: 24px;">Chairs of the Seminar:<br />P.M. Mannucci - S. Harari - F. Forastiere - M. Krzyzanowski</strong>&nbsp;</p>
presentationDescription_en: <p><span style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;">The Respirami 3 conference in Milan in January 2019 </span><span style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;">was a remarkable event with a large participation of international scientists, professionals of the health care sector and environmental protection agencies, all providing an interesting update of the research on air pollution. Since then, research on the health effects of air pollution have progressed considerably. The Health Effects Institute, the European Respiratory Society (ERS), the World Health Organization (WHO), and the International Society for Environmental Epidemiology (ISEE) organized a joint meeting in Brussels, Belgium, on January 21-22, 2020 with the aim to review the latest science on major pollutants, focusing on particulate matter 2.5 μm or less in diameter (PM2.5) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), to help evaluate the need for updating Europe’s air quality policies. A number of important scientific and policy questions about the causal links between air pollution and health, its effects at low levels of exposure, the relative contributions of different sources or constituents, and ultimately the question of how to achieve the most health benefits most cost-effectively were considered.</span><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><span style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;">The present initiative will update Italian professional on the latest evidence and provide an interesting platform for future research applications and project. The initiative is planned as a series of webinar with at least three presentations (20 minutes each) and sufficient time for Questions and Answers.</span><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><strong style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify; font-size: 18px; line-height: 24px;">Chairs of the Seminar:<br />P.M. title_it: RESPIRAMI - Recent Advances on Air pollution and Health - 2
title_en: RESPIRAMI - Recent Advances on Air pollution and Health - 2
description_it: The present initiative will update Italian professional on the latest evidence and provide an interesting platform for future research applications and project.
description_en: The present initiative will update Italian professional on the latest evidence and provide an interesting platform for future research applications and project.
presentationDescription_it: <p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><span style="font-family: &quot;Microsoft Sans Serif&quot;;">&nbsp;</span></span><strong style="font-size: 18pt; font-family: &quot;Microsoft Sans Serif&quot;;"><span style="color: #0000ff;">18 November 2020 6.00 – 7.20 pm (CET)</span></strong></p><p><strong style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify; text-decoration-color: initial; font-size: 18px; line-height: 24px; color: #cd1719;">Presentation</strong><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><span style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;">The Respirami 3 conference in Milan in January 2019</span><span style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;">&nbsp;was a remarkable event with a large participation of international scientists, professionals of the health care sector and environmental protection agencies, all providing an interesting update of the research on air pollution. Since then, research on the health effects of air pollution have progressed considerably. The Health Effects Institute, the European Respiratory Society (ERS), the World Health Organization (WHO), and the International Society for Environmental Epidemiology (ISEE) organized a joint meeting in Brussels, Belgium, on January 21-22, 2020 with the aim to review the latest science on major pollutants, focusing on particulate matter 2.5 μm or less in diameter (PM2.5) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), to help evaluate the need for updating Europe’s air quality policies. A number of important scientific and policy questions about the causal links between air pollution and health, its effects at low levels of exposure, the relative contributions of different sources or constituents, and ultimately the question of how to achieve the most health benefits most cost-effectively were considered.</span><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><span style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;">The present initiative will update Italian professional on the latest evidence and provide an interesting platform for future research applications and project. The initiative is planned as a series of webinar with at least three presentations (20 minutes each) and sufficient time for Questions and Answers.</span><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><br style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-align: justify;" /><strong style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify; font-size: 18px; line-height: 24px;">Chairs: </strong></p><p><span style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify; font-size: 18px; line-height: 24px;">F. Forastiere</span></p><p><span style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify; font-size: 18px; line-height: 24px;">M. Mannucci</span></p><p><span style="font-family: &quot;Open Sans&quot;, sans-serif, Helvetica, sans-serif; text-align: justify; font-size: 18px; line-height: 24px;">S. Harari</span>&nbsp;</p>

title_it: Seminars in Respiratory Medicine: Juniors meet Experts
title_en: Seminars in Respiratory Medicine: Juniors meet Experts
presentationDescription_it: <div><em>Seminars in Respiratory Medicine: Juniors meet Experts is a new event developed with the contribute of well-known leaders in the field and dedicated to specialist in in respiratory disease and internal medicine, especially juniors .</em></div><div><em> It is structured through web seminars and restricted in presence seminars that will take place in Fiesole (Tuscany- Italy) starting from Spring 2021. It is a unique opportunity to debate hot topics and new issues in respiratory medicine. </em></div><div><em>This event will promote lively discussion in order to help junior physicians to grow in their professional career.&nbsp;</em></div><div><br /></div><div><strong style="color: #222222; font-size: small;"><span style="font-size: 10.5pt;"><br /></span></strong></div><div style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 14pt; text-decoration: underline;"><strong style="text-decoration-line: underline;"><span style="text-decoration-line: underline; color: #800000;">FIRST WEBINAR</span></strong></span></div><p style="text-align: center;"><strong style="color: #222222; font-size: small;"><span style="font-size: 10.5pt;">Thursday, 5th Novem<strong>ber 2020, Afternoon</strong><br /></span></strong></p><div style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 14px; color: #222222;"><strong>6.00-7.30 P.M. title_it: EVIDENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT TO REDUCE CARDIOMETABOLIC RISK
title_en: EVIDENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT TO REDUCE CARDIOMETABOLIC RISK
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: left; margin: 0pt;"><span style="font-family: &quot;Microsoft Sans Serif&quot;; font-size: 14pt;">A major paradigm shift was introduced by the 2019 ESC guidelines on diabetes,&nbsp;prediabetes and CVD, recommending SGLT-2i or GLP-1 RAs with proven CV benefits&nbsp;in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) or high/very high&nbsp;CV risk irrespective of HbA1c level. In the perspective of empowering clinicians to&nbsp;integrate evidence-based therapies into practice, our webinar will address the current&nbsp;management of cardiometabolic risk and provide a vision for the future.</span></p><p style="text-align: left; margin: 0pt;"><br /></p><p><br /></p><p><strong><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="color: #800000;">CHAIRMAN</span></span></strong> </p><p> <span style="font-size: 14pt;"><strong>FRANCESCO COSENTINO</strong> </span></p><p> Unit of Cardiology Department of Medicine</p><p>Solna Karolinska Institute &amp; Karolinska University Hospital Stockholm, Sweden&nbsp;</p><div style="text-align: center;"><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/istruzioni-webinars_small_new(4).jpg" alt="" /></div>
presentationDescription_en: <p style="text-align: left; margin: 0pt;"><span style="font-family: &quot;Microsoft Sans Serif&quot;; font-size: 14pt;">A major paradigm shift was introduced by the 2019 ESC guidelines on diabetes,&nbsp;prediabetes and CVD, recommending SGLT-2i or GLP-1 RAs with proven CV benefits&nbsp;in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) or high/very high&nbsp;CV risk irrespective of HbA1c level. In the perspective of empowering clinicians to&nbsp;integrate evidence-based therapies into practice, our webinar will address the current&nbsp;management of cardiometabolic risk and provide a vision for the future.</span></p><p style="text-align: left; margin: 0pt;"><br /></p><p><strong><span style="color: #800000; font-size: 12pt;">CHAIRMAN</span></strong></p><p><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><strong>FRANCESCO COSENTINO</strong></span></p><p>Unit of Cardiology Department of Medicine</p><p>Solna Karolinska Institute &amp; Karolinska University Hospital Stockholm, Sweden&nbsp;</p><div style="text-align: center;"><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/istruzioni-webinars_small_new(4).jpg" alt="" /></div>

title_it: FAD: Heart and Virus: which link?
title_en: FAD: Heart and Virus: which link?
