title_it: FAD: Stem Cell Transplantation in Childhood Biotechnological Advances
title_en: FAD: Stem Cell Transplantation in Childhood Biotechnological Advances
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: left;"><strong><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="color: #000080;">Target: Pediatrics, Immunology, Stem cell</span></span></strong></p><p><strong><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="color: #000080;">Scientific Responsible: Prof. Franco Locatelli</span></span></strong></p><p><strong><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="color: #000080;">Italian CME Credit</span></span></strong></p><p><strong>Rationale: <br /></strong>Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is a curative treatment for pediatric patients with many hematological diseases. The indications for HSCT in children are well defined for acute leukemia, as well as for patients with non-malignant disease. HSCT from HLA-identical sibling or unrelated donors, such as new techniques of graft manipulation using haploidentical donor graft, provides a high chance of cure for those patients. The field of HSCT is rapidly evolving with the possibility to perform targeted immunotherapy with CAR-T cells for acute lymphoblastic leukemia, B-cell lymphomas and solid tumors. More recently, the first results of gene therapy for hereditary diseases, open new perspectives of treatment for patients with thalassemia, sickle cell disease, primary immune-deficiencies and metabolic disorders.</p><p><strong>GOALS:</strong>&nbsp;<br />The meeting will address all the relevant aspects of indication and results of HSCT in pediatric population, focusing on new insights on gene therapy for hereditary diseases, as well as on the newest results obtained through approaches of immunotherapy. Ethical and regulatory aspects related to these new therapies will be discussed, as well. Recognized, outstanding international leaders will deliver the main lectures, but also high-level research talks selected from the best abstracts submitted by attendees will be presented.</p>
presentationDescription_en: <p><strong><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="color: #000080;">Target: Pediatrics, Immunology, Stem cell</span></span></strong></p><p><strong><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="color: #000080;">Scientific Responsible: Prof. Franco Locatelli </span></span></strong></p><p><strong><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="color: #000080;">Italian CME Credit</span></span></strong> </p><p><strong>Rationale: <br /></strong>Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is a curative treatment for pediatric patients with many hematological diseases. The indications for HSCT in children are well defined for acute leukemia, as well as for patients with non-malignant disease. HSCT from HLA-identical sibling or unrelated donors, such as new techniques of graft manipulation using haploidentical donor graft, provides a high chance of cure for those patients. The field of HSCT is rapidly evolving with the possibility to perform targeted immunotherapy with CAR-T cells for acute lymphoblastic leukemia, B-cell lymphomas and solid tumors. More recently, the first results of gene therapy for hereditary diseases, open new perspectives of treatment for patients with thalassemia, sickle cell disease, primary immune-deficiencies and metabolic disorders. </p><p><br /></p><p> <strong>GOALS:</strong> <br />The meeting will address all the relevant aspects of indication and results of HSCT in pediatric population, focusing on new insights on gene therapy for hereditary diseases, as well as on the newest results obtained through approaches of immunotherapy. Ethical and regulatory aspects related to these new therapies will be discussed, as well. Recognized, outstanding international leaders will deliver the main lectures, but also high-level research talks selected from the best abstracts submitted by attendees will be presented.</p>

title_it: FAD: RESPIRAMI - Recent Advances on Air pollution and Health
title_en: FAD: RESPIRAMI - Recent Advances on Air pollution and Health
presentationDescription_it: <div style="text-decoration-color: initial; color: #222222; font-size: small;"><strong style="border: 0px; font-size: 14px; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif;"></strong></div><div style="text-decoration-color: initial; font-size: small; text-align: center;"><div><span style="font-size: 18pt;"><strong style="text-decoration-line: underline;"><span style="text-decoration-line: underline;"><span style="color: #0000ff;">Nuova data:</span></span></strong></span></div><div><span style="font-size: 18pt;"><strong style="text-decoration-line: underline;"><span style="text-decoration-line: underline;"><span style="color: #0000ff;">28/01/2021 - 28/01/2022</span></span></strong></span></div><div style="color: #222222;"> <br /></div></div><div style="text-decoration-color: initial; color: #222222; font-size: small; text-align: center;"><strong style="border: 0px; font-size: 14px; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif;"><span style="border: 0px; color: #000080; font-size: 12pt;"><strong style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial; border: 0px; font-size: 14px;"><strong><span style="border: 0px; color: #000080; font-size: 12pt;"><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><br /></span></span></strong></strong></span></strong></div><div style="text-decoration-color: initial; color: #222222; font-size: small; text-align: center;"><strong style="border: 0px; font-size: 14px; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif;"><span style="border: 0px; color: #000080; font-size: 12pt;"><strong style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial; border: 0px; font-size: 14px;"><strong><span style="border: 0px; color: #000080; font-size: 12pt;"><span style="font-size: 14pt;">Target:&nbsp;<strong style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial; border: 0px;"><span style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-weight: 400; text-decoration-color: initial; border: 0px;">Respiratory</span></strong></span></span></strong></strong><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><br /></span></span></strong></div><div style="text-decoration-color: initial; color: #222222; font-size: small; text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><strong style="border: 0px; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif;"><span style="border: 0px; color: #000080;">Scientific Responsible:</span></strong>&nbsp;Francesco Forastiere, Michal Krzyzanowski, Sergio Harari, </span></div><div style="text-decoration-color: initial; color: #222222; font-size: small; text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 14pt;">and Pier Mannuccio Mannucci</span><br /></div><div style="text-decoration-color: initial; font-size: small; text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000080;"><br /><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><strong>Italian CME Crredit: 4&nbsp;</strong></span></span></div><p><br /></p><p><strong><span style="color: #800000; font-size: 14pt;">INTRODUCTION AND RATIONALE I SESSION</span></strong></p><p><span style="font-size: 12pt;">The human coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID_19) is an infectious disease caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), that in the first six months of 2020 spread to at least 200 countries of the world. The first epicenter was in January the city of Wuhan and caused in the whole China 84.000 infected cases and 4600 deaths. The first epicenter in Europe was Italy in February-March and particularly the Northern region of Lombardy, causing in whole country approximately 240.000 infections and 35.000 fatalities. Other heavily affected European countries were Spain, France, the UK and Russia. COVID-19 then spread to the Americas with a first epicenter in April in New York City, causing in the USA at least 2.000.000 infections and 115.000 fatalities. In the frame of this dramatic global scenario there is still considerable uncertainty pertaining to the mechanisms of viral spread and the factors that contribute to the different degree of disease severity. It is plausible that an environmental risk factor such as ambient air pollution characterized by a high population attributable fraction plays a key role in increasing the likelihood of spread and severe clinical outcomes in COVID-19, because ambient air pollution has an adverse impact on global morbidity and mortality through components such as fine particulate matter (PM2.5), nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and ozone (O3). They affect human health by producing oxidative stress and inflammation, that is turn cause damage on the respiratory, cardiovascular and immune systems definitely involved in COVID-19. With this background, it is biologically plausible that the degree and duration of exposure to air pollution might have harmful effects on the occurrence and clinical course of COVID-19. With these gaps of knowledge this webinar is planned to contribute to a better understanding on whether or not short- and long-term exposure to ambient air pollution influences the spread and clinical manifestations of COVID-19. It is hoped that this initiative will update on the latest evidence and help to support and foster globally public health interventions targeted to protect people living in heavily polluted regions through efforts aimed to lower the emissions of the harmful components of ambient air.&nbsp;</span></p><p><br /></p><p><strong><span style="color: #800000; font-size: 14pt;">RATIONALE OF SESSION II and III</span></strong><br /></p><p><span style="font-size: 12pt;">The Respirami 3 conference in Milan in January 2019 (http://www.ilpolmone.it/congresso-respirami-milano-2019) was a remarkable event with a large participation of international scientists, professionals of the health care sector and environmental protection agencies, all providing an interesting update of the research on air pollution. Since then, research on the health effects of air pollution have progressed considerably. The Health Effects Institute, the European Respiratory Society (ERS), the World Health Organization (WHO), and the International Society for Environmental Epidemiology (ISEE) organized a joint meeting in Brussels, Belgium, on January 21-22, 2020 with the aim to review the latest science on major pollutants, focusing on particulate matter 2.5 μm or less in diameter (PM2.5) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), to help evaluate the need for updating Europe’s air quality policies. A number of important scientific and policy questions about the causal links between air pollution and health, its effects at low levels of exposure, the relative contributions of different sources or constituents, and ultimately the question of how to achieve the most health benefits most cost-effectively were considered.</span><span style="font-size: 12pt;">The present initiative will update Italian an International professionals on the latest evidence and provide an interesting platform for future research applications and project.</span></p>

text-decoration-line: underline;">New date:</span></strong></span></div><div><span style="font-size: 18pt;"><strong style="text-decoration-line: underline;"><span style="color: #0000ff; text-decoration-line: underline;">28/01/2021 - 28/01/2022</span></strong></span></div></div><div style="color: #222222;"> <br /></div></div><div style="text-decoration-color: initial; color: #222222; font-size: small; text-align: center;"><strong style="border: 0px; font-size: 14px; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif;"><span style="border: 0px; color: #000080; font-size: 12pt;"><strong style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial; border: 0px; font-size: 14px;"><span style="font-size: 14pt; border: 0px; color: #000080;">Target:&nbsp;<strong style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial; border: 0px;"><span style="font-weight: 400; text-decoration-color: initial; border: 0px;">Respiratory</span></strong></span></strong><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><br /></span></span></strong></div><div style="text-decoration-color: initial; color: #222222; color: #222222; font-size: small; text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 14pt;">and Pier Mannuccio Mannucci</span><br /></div><div style="font-size: small; text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000080;"><br /><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><strong>Italian CME Crredit: 4&nbsp;</strong></span></span></div><p><br /></p><p><strong><span style="color: #800000; font-size: 14pt;">INTRODUCTION AND RATIONALE I SESSION</span></strong></p><p><span style="font-size: 12pt;">The human coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID_19) is an infectious disease caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), that in the first six months of 2020 spread to at least 200 countries of the world. The first epicenter was in January the city of Wuhan and caused in the whole China 84.000 infected cases and 4600 deaths. The first epicenter in Europe was Italy in February-March and particularly the Northern region of Lombardy, causing in whole country approximately 240.000 infections and 35.000 fatalities. Other heavily affected European countries were Spain, France, the UK and Russia. COVID-19 then spread to the Americas with a first epicenter in April in New York City, causing in the USA at least 2.000.000 infections and 115.000 fatalities. In the frame of this dramatic global scenario there is still considerable uncertainty pertaining to the mechanisms of viral spread and the factors that contribute to the different degree of disease severity. It is plausible that an environmental risk factor such as ambient air pollution characterized by a high population attributable fraction plays a key role in increasing the likelihood of spread and severe clinical outcomes in COVID-19, because ambient air pollution has an adverse impact on global morbidity and mortality through components such as fine particulate matter (PM2.5), nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and ozone (O3). They affect human health by producing oxidative stress and inflammation, that is turn cause damage on the respiratory, cardiovascular and immune systems definitely involved in COVID-19. With this background, it is biologically plausible that the degree and duration of exposure to air pollution might have harmful effects on the occurrence and clinical course of COVID-19. With these gaps of knowledge this webinar is planned to contribute to a better understanding on whether or not short- and long-term exposure to ambient air pollution influences the spread and clinical manifestations of COVID-19. It is hoped that this initiative will update on the latest evidence and help to support and foster globally public health interventions targeted to protect people living in heavily polluted regions through efforts aimed to lower the emissions of the harmful components of ambient air.&nbsp;</span></p><p><br /></p><p><strong><span style="color: #800000; font-size: 14pt;">RATIONALE OF SESSION II and III</span></strong><br /></p><p><span style="font-size: 12pt;">The Respirami 3 conference in Milan in January 2019 (http://www.ilpolmone.it/congresso-respirami-milano-2019) was a remarkable event with a large participation of international scientists, professionals of the health care sector and environmental protection agencies, all providing an interesting update of the research on air pollution. Since then, research on the health effects of air pollution have progressed considerably. The Health Effects Institute, the European Respiratory Society (ERS), the World Health Organization (WHO), and the International Society for Environmental Epidemiology (ISEE) organized a joint meeting in Brussels, Belgium, on January 21-22, 2020 with the aim to review the latest science on major pollutants, focusing on particulate matter 2.5 μm or less in diameter (PM2.5) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), to help evaluate the need for updating Europe’s air quality policies. A number of important scientific and policy questions about the causal links between air pollution and health, its effects at low levels of exposure, the relative contributions of different sources or constituents, and ultimately the question of how to achieve the most health benefits most cost-effectively were considered.&nbsp;</span><span style="font-size: 12pt;">The present initi</span><span style="font-size: 12pt;">ative will update Italian an International professionals on the latest evidence and provide an interesting platform for future research applications and project.</span></p>

title_it: FAD: What we need to know for winning the battle against Superbugs?
title_en: FAD: What we need to know for winning the battle against Superbugs?
presentationDescription_it: <p>Antibiotic-resistant super-bacteria kill thousands of patients each year. The World Economic Forum has defined antibiotic resistance as a global risk, which is not limited to health alone. The increase in life expectancy and advances in surgery, transplantology, oncology, haematology and resuscitation have increased and made patients more vulnerable to infections contracted in hospital or during healthcare, so it is estimated that without new drugs, by 2050 the phenomenon of antibiotic resistance could cause 450,000 deaths in Italy alone. New antibiotics would be able to reduce mortality by a third, from now on saving 3,000 lives each year. Antibiotic resistance is therefore a hot topic and the purpose of this training course is to take stock of the situation and describe new strategies for fighting this phenomenon. The spectre of a pre-antibiotic era, which would take us back a hundred years, is stretching inexorably over global public health due to super-resistant bacteria. Already today, they kill 33,000 people in Europe every year, and 10,000 in Italy alone, the most affected nation together with Greece, and almost 5% of hospitalised patients suffer from an infection that cannot be treated with common antibiotics. The forecasts for the future are very serious and to be able to fight the battle against multi-resistant germs it is necessary to boost research and encourage the use of new antibiotics, true lifesavers like the anticancer drugs, thus overcoming the paradox of “not treating an infection today for fear that it will become more serious or less curable tomorrow”. By 2050, it is expected that there will be 392,000 deaths in Europe, 10 million worldwide, and about 450,000 in Italy, surpassing the mortality rate for cancer, with an economic impact of 100 trillion dollars. An emergency that could be overcome thanks, on the one hand, to new antibiotics by intensifying scientific research and, on the other hand, by making the best use of the most innovative drugs. It is therefore essential for the new antibiotics to be used earlier on, even in an appropriate empirical way, above all for the most critical and serious patients in which a delay, even a few hours, in starting the right antibiotic therapy, could be fatal. The fight against antibiotic resistance cannot be separated from the training of doctors: many do not know about the new drugs and are afraid to use them. Only 35% use them, often with a delay, wasting precious time and exposing patients to a greater risk of serious complications. A change of pace is indispensable because simple prevention is no longer sufficient: even by administering antibiotics only when necessary and paying close attention to the containment of infections and bacterial transmission in hospitals and nursing homes, only 50% of infections acquired during healthcare can be prevented. Antibiotics are therefore still a lifesaver, especially for the numerous fragile patients such as the elderly, patients undergoing organ transplants or cancer treatment, those in intensive care or who have undergone major surgery. It is essential to carry out research to identify new therapies, enhancing the value of innovative antibiotics, which, when included in appropriate therapeutic schemes, will allow for protecting the efforts and investments made in support of patient health with huge savings of resources, in both the short and long term.</p><p><br /></p><p><br /></p> <h4><span style="color: #800000;">Prof. Matteo Bassetti <br /><em>Infectious Diseases Clinic, University of Genoa, <br />Hospital Policlinico San Martino – IRCCS, Genoa, Italy</em></span></h4>

title_it: PEDIATRIC AIRWAY SURGERY: Old Problems New Solutions - 1
title_en: PEDIATRIC AIRWAY SURGERY: Old Problems New Solutions - 1
presentationDescription_it: <div><strong><span style="color: #000080;">Live International Symposium online on:</span></strong></div><div><strong><span style="color: #000080;">5 March, 12 March, 19 March 2021</span></strong></div><p>Pediatric airway surgery is a relatively young discipline that has seen a dramatic worldwide increase in interest in recent years. In the last 10 years, Operative Units dedicated to Airway Surgery on their own or in combination with the Digestive Tract Surgery have increased in many parts of the globe. The main international conferences have expanded gradually the space dedicated to airways pathologies, congenital and acquired, in adults and in particular in pediatric age. Dedicated societies and worldwide networks have been created which with their itinerant meetings and conferences have favored the exchange of information and the di&#x1F;usion of techniques and innovations all over the world. In parallel, the interest of the industries engaged in producing dedicated instruments and applying new technologies has grown, completely converting their production line and adapting it to the needs of this particular surgical sector. Despite the e&#x1F;ort of those working in this specific area, to spread innovations and to create situations of encounter and comparison between the world&#39;s leading exponents, the sector still complains of a shortage in the education and training of specialists in this discipline. To date, there are no international fellowship programs dedicated to airway surgery or theoretical-practical masters or intensive courses that specifically teach the bases for the diagnosis and treatment of airway pathology, particularly in the pediatric field. Even on the occasion of the various international conferences, the shortness of time for relations unfortunately limits the time to teaching, reducing it too often to a report on personal cases. This digital international symposium on airway surgery was conceived with a view to promoting the spread of culture in the field of airway surgery in children and to create the basis for a distance education system with a practical character.</p><h5><span style="color: #800000;">Scientific Director: Sergio Bottero</span></h5><p><br /></p>

title_it: Advances in Cardiomyopathies
title_en: Advances in Cardiomyopathies
presentationDescription_it: <div><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Dear colleagues,</span></div><div><span style="font-size: 10pt;">It is a great pleasure to invite you to the “IV Florence International Symposium on Advances in Cardiomyopathies”, to be held next April, 22nd and 23th 2021. As in the previous editions held in 2008, 2012 and 2015, the course is designed to constantly promote close interaction between basic science and clinical practice, in an attempt to address the topic in a truly global fashion. Novel options such as next generation sequencing gene testing, innovative pharmacological approaches and the subcutaneous ICD will be discussed.<br /><br /></span></div><div><span style="font-size: 10pt;">It is hoped that the broad range of topics will attract the interest of a wide audience, including physicians, clinical researchers, cardiologists, pathologists, basic scientists, and young investigators. A wide and open discussion among all the participants is welcome.<br /><br /></span></div><div><span style="font-size: 10pt;">We hope that the Symposium will be extremely productive, providing with an opportunity to improve our understanding of this challenging area of expertise and to stimulate further research into the field.</span></div><p><br /></p><h3><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><span style="color: #800000;">Chairmen</span></span></h3><div><br /><strong><span style="color: #800000;">Prof. FRANCO CECCHI</span></strong></div><div>Associate Professor of Cardiovascular Diseases</div><div>University of Florence</div><div>Florence (IT)</div><div>Department of Cardiovascular, Neural and Metabolic Sciences</div><div>IRCCS, Istituto Auxologico Italiano, S.Luca Hospital,</div><div>Milan (IT)</div><p><br /></p><div><strong><span style="color: #800000;">Prof. IACOPO OLIVOTTO</span></strong></div><div>Associate Professor of Cardiovascular Diseases</div><div>University of Florence, Cardiomyopathy Unit,</div><div>Careggi University Hospital,</div><div>Florence (IT)</div><p><br /></p>

A wide and open discussion among all the participants is welcome.<br /><br /></span></div><div><span style="font-size: 10pt;">We hope that the Symposium will be extremely productive, providing with an opportunity to improve our understanding of this challenging area of expertise and to stimulate further research into the field.</span></div><p><br /></p><h3><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><span style="color: #800000;">Chairmen</span></span></h3><div><br /><strong><span style="color: #800000;">Prof. FRANCO CECCHI</span></strong></div><div>Associate Professor of Cardiovascular Diseases</div><div>University of Florence</div><div>Florence (IT)</div><div>Department of Cardiovascular, Neural and Metabolic Sciences</div><div>IRCCS, Istituto Auxologico Italiano, S.Luca Hospital,</div><div>Milan (IT)</div><p><br /></p><div><strong><span style="color: #800000;">Prof. IACOPO OLIVOTTO</span></strong></div><div>Associate Professor of Cardiovascular Diseases</div><div>University of Florence, Cardiomyopathy Unit,</div><div>Careggi University Hospital,</div><div>Florence (IT)</div><p><br /></p>

title_it: Educational Webinars in conjuction with the development of the H. Pylori - Consensus Meeting Maastricht VI/Florence
title_en: Educational Webinars in conjuction with the development of the H. Pylori - Consensus Meeting Maastricht VI/Florence
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center; font-family: Arial; font-size: 14pt; color: #993300;"> <strong>WEBINAR I - Educational Webinars in conjuction with the development of the H. Pylori - Consensus Meeting Maastricht VI/Florence – 18/05/2021 <br /></strong><br /> <strong>WEBINAR II - Educational Webinars in conjuction with the development of the H. Pylori - Consensus Meeting Maastricht VI/Florence – 03/06/21 <br /></strong><br /> <strong>WEBINAR III - Educational Webinars in conjuction with the development of the H. Pylori - Consensus Meeting Maastricht VI/Florence - 15/06/21 <br /></strong><br /> <strong>WEBINAR IV - Educational Webinars in conjuction with the development of the H. Pylori - Consensus Meeting Maastricht VI/Florence – 29/06/21 </strong> </p> <p style="text-align: center; font-size: 14pt;"><strong>Educational events in the context of the H. pylori Consensus development</strong></p> <p style="text-align: center; font-family: Arial; font-size: 14pt; color: #993300;"> <strong>18<sup>th</sup> May 2021 - h. 16.00 - 18.00 (CEST)</strong><br /> <strong>3<sup>rd</sup> June 2021 - h. 16.00 - 18.00 (CEST)</strong><br /> <strong>15<sup>th</sup> June 2021 - h. 16.00 - 18.00 (CEST)</strong><br /> <strong>29<sup>th</sup> June 2021 - h. 16.00 - 18.00 (CEST)</strong> </p> <p> This year is the 25th anniversary since the first H. pylori Consensus report held in Maastricht in 1996. </p> <p> We are now working on the 6th consensus edition (Maastricht VI//Florence) with a group of dedicated clinical experts and scientists, focussing on this continuously growing and expanding field. </p> <p> H.pylori is unique in its pathogenic relationship with the stomach which has diverse clinical outcomes due to a series of other interfering factors. Ever since its discovery, H. pylori has aroused great scientific interest with controversial opinions involving numerous medical disciplines, and it has become an exemplary model because of its medical multi- and interdisciplinarity. </p> <p> For this reason we believe that in the context of the H. pylori Consensus development, which combines a challenging academic exercise with the demand to come up with useful clinical guidance, a series of accompanying webinars would be useful for educational purposes in clinical medicine and related scientific disciplines. </p> <p> The contents of these educational webinars will include methodological aspects on how to select relevant questions, provide evidence, proceed with the assessment of individual statements, deal with controversies, and finally, on how to reach a consensus. </p> <p> Authoritative experts in the H. pylori field will give concise presentations with up-to-date knowledge on clinical scenarios, diagnostic procedures, therapeutic strategies, preventive measures, and the interaction of H. pylori with the gut microbiota. Specific aspects, such as the role of H. pylori eradication in patients with myocardial infarction, and H. pylori related clinical challenges in times of COVID-19, will add important actuality to our endeavours. </p> <p> We hope to stimulate your curiosity and interest to follow the webinars accompanying the H. pylori consensus development in the aim of benefitting your daily clinical and academic practice. </p> <p> <em>Course Coordinator:</em><br /> <strong>P. Malfertheiner</strong><br /> Otto-von-Guericke Universität<br /> LMU-Universitätsklinikum , Med. Klinik II<br /> München, DE </p>

Ever since its discovery, H. pylori has aroused great scientific interest with controversial opinions involving numerous medical disciplines, and it has become an exemplary model because of its medical multi- and interdisciplinarity. </p> <p> For this reason we believe that in the context of the H. pylori Consensus development, which combines a challenging academic exercise with the demand to come up with useful clinical guidance, a series of accompanying webinars would be useful for educational purposes in clinical medicine and related scientific disciplines. </p> <p> The contents of these educational webinars will include methodological aspects on how to select relevant questions, provide evidence, proceed with the assessment of individual statements, deal with controversies, and finally, on how to reach a consensus. </p> <p> Authoritative experts in the H. pylori field will give concise presentations with up-to-date knowledge on clinical scenarios, diagnostic procedures, therapeutic strategies, preventive measures, and the interaction of H. pylori with the gut microbiota. Specific aspects, such as the role of H. pylori eradication in patients with myocardial infarction, and H. pylori related clinical challenges in times of COVID-19, will add important actuality to our endeavours. </p> <p> We hope to stimulate your curiosity and interest to follow the webinars accompanying the H. pylori consensus development in the aim of benefitting your daily clinical and academic practice. </p> <p> <em>Course Coordinator:</em><br /> <strong>P. title_it: Recent Advances in Cardiovascular Diseases
title_en: Recent Advances in Cardiovascular Diseases
presentationDescription_it: <div><br /></div><div>Cardiovascular diseases are still one of major health problem. The rational of this digital symposium is to share the recent advances in cardiovascular diseases This educational event will be divided in three different areas The first one will be focused on ischemic heart disease In particular, outstanding experts in the fields will discuss the prevention and the interventional treatments of patients with acute and chronic coronary syndromes The impact of COVID 19 on cardiovascular diseases will be also discussed<br /><br /></div><div>The second area of this digital symposium will be dedicated to heart failure New therapeutical strategies, decision Pathway for Optimization of Heart Failure Treatment and the current applications of artificial intelligence in Heart Failure will be discussed in details.<br /><br /></div><div>Finally, in the third section of the meeting the new perspectives in the diagnosis and treatment of structural heart diseases, i e aortic stenosis, mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation will be treated by superb experts in the field</div>
presentationDescription_en: <div>Cardiovascular diseases are still one of major health problem. The rational of this digital symposium is to share the recent advances in cardiovascular diseases This educational event will be divided in three different areas The first one will be focused on ischemic heart disease In particular, outstanding experts in the fields will discuss the prevention and the interventional treatments of patients with acute and chronic coronary syndromes The impact of COVID 19 on cardiovascular diseases will be also discussed<br /><br /></div><div>The second area of this digital symposium will be dedicated to heart failure New therapeutical strategies, decision Pathway for Optimization of Heart Failure Treatment and the current applications of artificial intelligence in Heart Failure will be discussed in details.<br /><br /></div><div>Finally, in the third section of the meeting the new perspectives in the diagnosis and treatment of structural heart diseases, i e aortic stenosis, mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation will be treated by superb experts in the field</div>

title_it: Treatment of lung cancer in the era of precision medicine
title_en: Treatment of lung cancer in the era of precision medicine
presentationDescription_it: <div>In the last years progresses have been made in the field of non small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) tumor genomic with the discovery of biomolecular markers with about 20 of patients to date treated with targeted therapies according to specific genetic alterations. <br />New efforts are ongoing to identify new molecular targets and new drugs. Also the field of immunotherapy have been subjected to a huge step beyond with the development of a new class of the drugs the check point inhibitors. Recently single agent immunotherapy and the combination of chemo immunotherapy are the new standard of treatments for advanced NSCLC non oncogene addicted. The new frontiers of immunotherapy are represented by the combination of new immunotherapic agents. Some of the encoureging results observed in the metastatic setting have already been traslated in earlier stages of disease. <br />The rationale of the meeting is to deal with and discuss all these new standard treatments and their future developments and the new paradigms of the precision medicine.</div>
presentationDescription_en: In the last years progresses have been made in the field of non small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) tumor genomic with the discovery of biomolecular markers with about 20 of patients to date treated with targeted therapies according to specific genetic alterations.<br />New efforts are ongoing to identify new molecular targets and new drugs. Also the field of immunotherapy have been subjected to a huge step beyond with the development of a new class of the drugs the check point inhibitors. Recently single agent immunotherapy and the combination of chemo immunotherapy are the new standard of treatments for advanced NSCLC non oncogene addicted. The new frontiers of immunotherapy are represented by the combination of new immunotherapic agents. Some of the encoureging results observed in the metastatic setting have already been traslated in earlier stages of disease.<br />The rationale of the meeting is to deal with and discuss all these new standard treatments and their future developments and the new paradigms of the precision medicine.

title_it: Gender Differences in COVID-19 Pandemic around the World
title_en: Gender Differences in COVID-19 Pandemic around the World
presentationDescription_it: <div style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><strong>Webinar organized by</strong></span></div><h4 style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #800000; font-size: 18pt;">The Italian Gender Medicine Network</span></h4><div style="text-align: center;"><a href="https://igm2021.livebit.it/" target="_blank"><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/join-the-event.png" alt="" /></a></div><p style="text-align: center;"><br /></p><div>Coronavirus disease 2019 (<strong>COVID-19</strong>) led to about 6.5 million confirmed cases causing almost 400,000 related deaths worldwide. COVID-19 is mainly characterized by a lethal severe acute respiratory syndrome, but a number of additional clinical manifestations has been described, such as severe lymphopenia and eosinopenia, extensive pneumonia, a “cytokine storm” leading to acute respiratory distress syndrome, endothelitis, thrombo-embolic complications and multiorgan failure. Moreover, a series of long lasting symptoms have been observed in the post-COVID patients, a syndrome called Long COVID.</div><div>In the last months, research studies gained several novel insights as concerns SARS-Cov-2 mechanisms of infection and spreading paralleled by studies on vaccines and specific drugs. However, a surprising scenario is now emerging from these studies: a significant difference between women and men in the lethality of this infection, higher in men, and in the post-COVID syndrome, likely higher in fertile women.</div><div>This webinar, organized by the Italian Gender Medicine Network and under the auspices of the International Gender Medicine Society, would tackle these open questions. The Italian Journal of Gender Specific Medicine (<a href="https://www.gendermedjournal.it/" target="_blank">www.gendermedjournal.it</a>) will participate contributing to the spreading of the scientific results of the webinar. A series of lectures, specifically devoted to the dissection of this matter, will offer a deeper</div><div>analysis of features and mechanisms underlying the observed sex/gender disparity in order to pull on board different scientific skills and viewpoints.</div>
presentationDescription_en: <div><div style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><strong>Webinar organized by</strong></span></div><h4 style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #800000; font-size: 18pt;">The Italian Gender Medicine Network</span></h4><div style="text-align: center;"><a href="https://igm2021.livebit.it/" target="_blank"><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/join-the-event.png" alt="" /></a></div></div><p><br /></p><div>Coronavirus disease 2019 (<strong>COVID-19</strong>) led to about 6.5 million confirmed cases causing almost 400,000 related deaths worldwide. COVID-19 is mainly characterized by a lethal severe acute respiratory syndrome, but a number of additional clinical manifestations has been described, such as severe lymphopenia and eosinopenia, extensive pneumonia, a “cytokine storm” leading to acute respiratory distress syndrome, endothelitis, thrombo-embolic complications and multiorgan failure. Moreover, a series of long lasting symptoms have been observed in the post-COVID patients, a syndrome called Long COVID.</div><div>In the last months, research studies gained several novel insights as concerns SARS-Cov-2 mechanisms of infection and spreading paralleled by studies on vaccines and specific drugs. However, a surprising scenario is now emerging from these studies: a significant difference between women and men in the lethality of this infection, higher in men, and in the post-COVID syndrome, likely higher in fertile women.</div><div>This webinar, organized by the Italian Gender Medicine Network and under the auspices of the International Gender Medicine Society, would tackle these open questions. The Italian Journal of Gender Specific Medicine (<a href="https://www.gendermedjournal.it/" target="_blank">www.gendermedjournal.it</a>) will participate contributing to the spreading of the scientific results of the webinar. A series of lectures, specifically devoted to the dissection of this matter, will offer a deeper</div><div>analysis of features and mechanisms underlying the observed sex/gender disparity in order to pull on board different scientific skills and viewpoints.</div>

title_it: Across Asthma, COPD & COVID-19 through the novelties
title_en: Across Asthma, COPD & COVID-19 through the novelties
presentationDescription_it: <div><div>Chronic obstructive respiratory diseases include firstly chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma, both are frequent and common and affects an high number of subjects around the world Specifically about 200 milion people suffer from asthma, a common disease among children and more than 3 milion people die each year from COPD, an estimated 6 of all deaths worldwide. Therefore, to better inform prevention, screening, treatment, and research efforts dedicated to chronic respiratory diseases, are crucial to understand their prevalence, morbidity, and mortality, both on global and regional scales. Additionally, is important to underline that chronic respiratory diseases are common and are associated with substantial morbidity and mortality, but also highlight the heterogeneity of chronic respiratory disease related health burden and risk factors by world region and sex.</div><div>These diseases are responsable of important symptoms as shortness of breath, wheeze, dyspnea, cough and comorbidity conditioning disability, reduced physical activity, impaired quality of life and also mortality.</div><div>Therefore, increasing research funding is essential to develop strategies to detect chronic respiratory diseases at their earliest stage and to accelerate the discovery of novel therapies, which are sorely needed for these diseases. During the years various form of treatment have been developed in order to help patients for symptoms improvement, better quality of life and reducing mortality SARS-CoV-2 and the related COVID 19 has caused a pandemic and high number of thats worldwide.</div><div>The clinical spectrum can range from mild simptoms to severe hypoxic respiratory failure, sepsis,multiorgan involvement and death.</div><div>The objective of the present meeting is focused on the possibility to give medical doctors the new and more recent informations regarding pathophysiology, clinical presentations and therapies of chronic respiratory diseases, with particular attention to COPD and Asthma, and COVID-19 pandemic All these points in order to help the clinical managemnt and research activity.</div></div><div><br /></div><div><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><span style="color: #800000;">Scientific Directors:<br /><br /></span></span></div><div><strong>Prof. Marcos Restrepo</strong></div><div>San Antonio Texas, USA<br /><br /></div><div><strong>Prof. Pierachille Santus</strong> <br />Milan, ITALY</div><p><br /></p>

Therefore, to better inform prevention, screening, treatment, and research efforts dedicated to chronic respiratory diseases, are crucial to understand their prevalence, morbidity, and mortality, both on global and regional scales. Additionally, is important to underline that chronic respiratory diseases are common and are associated with substantial morbidity and mortality, but also highlight the heterogeneity of chronic respiratory disease related health burden and risk factors by world region and sex.</div><div>These diseases are responsable of important symptoms as shortness of breath, wheeze, dyspnea, cough and comorbidity conditioning disability, reduced physical activity, impaired quality of life and also mortality.</div><div>Therefore, increasing research funding is essential to develop strategies to detect chronic respiratory diseases at their earliest stage and to accelerate the discovery of novel therapies, which are sorely needed for these diseases. During the years various form of treatment have been developed in order to help patients for symptoms improvement, better quality of life and reducing mortality SARS-CoV-2 and the related COVID 19 has caused a pandemic and high number of thats worldwide.</div><div>The clinical spectrum can range from mild simptoms to severe hypoxic respiratory failure, sepsis,multiorgan involvement and death.</div><div>The objective of the present meeting is focused on the possibility to give medical doctors the new and more recent informations regarding pathophysiology, clinical presentations and therapies of chronic respiratory diseases, with particular attention to COPD and Asthma, and COVID-19 pandemic All these points in order to help the clinical managemnt and research activity.</div></div><div><br /></div><div><span style="color: #800000; font-size: 14pt;">Scientific Directors:<br /><br /></span></div><div><strong>Prof. Marcos Restrepo</strong></div><div>San Antonio Texas, USA<br /><br /></div><div><strong>Prof. Pierachille Santus</strong><br />Milan, ITALY</div><p><br /></p>

title_it: Treatment of lung cancer in the era of precision medicine - 2
title_en: Treatment of lung cancer in the era of precision medicine - 2
presentationDescription_it: <span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;">In the last years progresses have been made in the field of non small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) tumor genomic with the discovery of biomolecular markers with about 20 of patients to date treated with targeted therapies according to specific genetic alterations.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;" /><span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;"><br />New efforts are ongoing to identify new molecular targets and new drugs. Also the field of immunotherapy have been subjected to a huge step beyond with the development of a new class of the drugs the check point inhibitors. Recently single agent immunotherapy and the combination of chemo immunotherapy are the new standard of treatments for advanced NSCLC non oncogene addicted. The new frontiers of immunotherapy are represented by the combination of new immunotherapic agents. <br />Some of the encoureging results observed in the metastatic setting have already been traslated in earlier stages of disease.</span><br style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;" /><span style="color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; text-decoration-color: initial;"><br />The rationale of the meeting is to deal with and discuss all these new standard treatments and their future developments and the new paradigms of the precision medicine.</span>
presentationDescription_en: <span style="text-decoration-color: initial; color: #222222; font-family: merriweather_sansbook, sans-serif; font-size: 14px;">In the last years progresses have been made in the field of non small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) tumor genomic with the discovery of biomolecular markers with about 20 of patients to date treated with targeted therapies according to specific genetic alterations.<br /><br />New efforts are ongoing to identify new molecular targets and new drugs. Also the field of immunotherapy have been subjected to a huge step beyond with the development of a new class of the drugs the check point inhibitors. Recently single agent immunotherapy and the combination of chemo immunotherapy are the new standard of treatments for advanced NSCLC non oncogene addicted. The new frontiers of immunotherapy are represented by the combination of new immunotherapic agents.<br />Some of the encoureging results observed in the metastatic setting have already been traslated in earlier stages of disease.<br /><br />The rationale of the meeting is to deal with and discuss all these new standard treatments and their future developments and the new paradigms of the precision medicine.</span>

title_it: Across Asthma, COPD & COVID-19 through the novelties - 2
title_en: Across Asthma, COPD & COVID-19 through the novelties - 2
presentationDescription_it: <div>Chronic obstructive respiratory diseases include firstly chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma, both are frequent and common and affects an high number of subjects around the world. Specifically about 200 milion people suffer from asthma, a common disease among children and more than 3 milion people die each year from COPD, an estimated 6 of all deaths worldwide. Therefore, to better inform prevention, screening, treatment, and research efforts dedicated to chronic respiratory diseases, are crucial to understand their prevalence, morbidity, and mortality, both on global and regional scales. Additionally, is important to underline that chronic respiratory diseases are common and are associated with substantial morbidity and mortality, but also highlight the heterogeneity of chronic respiratory disease related health burden and risk factors by world region and sex.</div><div>These diseases are responsable of important symptoms as shortness of breath, wheeze, dyspnea, cough and comorbidity conditioning disability, reduced physical activity, impaired quality of life and also mortality.</div><div>Therefore, inncreasing research funding is essential to develop strategies to detect chronic respiratory diseases at their earliest stage and to accelerate the discovery of novel therapies, which are sorely needed for these diseases. During the years various form of treatment have been developed in order to help patients for symptoms improvement, better quality of life and reducing mortality SARS-CoV-2 and the related COVID-19 has caused a pandemic and high number of thats worldwide. The clinical spectrum can range from mild simptoms to severe hypoxic respiratory failure, sepsis,multiorgan involvement and death.</div><div>The objective of the present meeting is focused on the possibility to give medical doctors the new and more recent informations regarding pathophysiology, clinical presentations and therapies of chronic respiratory diseases, with particular attention to COPD and Asthma, and COVID-19 pandemic. All these points in order to help the clinical managemnt and research activity.</div><div><br /></div><div><span style="border: 0px; color: #800000; font-size: 14pt;">Scientific Directors:<br /><br /></span></div><div><strong>Prof. Marcos Restrepo</strong></div><div>San Antonio Texas, USA<br /><br /></div><div><strong>Prof. Pierachille Santus</strong><br />Milan, ITALY</div>

title_it: Educational Webinars in conjuction with the development of the H. Pylori - Consensus Meeting Maastricht VI/Florence - 2
title_en: Educational Webinars in conjuction with the development of the H. Pylori - Consensus Meeting Maastricht VI/Florence - 2
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center; font-size: 14pt;"><strong>Educational events in the context of the H. pylori Consensus development</strong></p> <p style="text-align: center; font-family: Arial; font-size: 14pt; color: #993300;"> <strong>18<sup>th</sup> May 2021 - h. 16.00 - 18.00 (CEST)</strong><br /> <strong>3<sup>rd</sup> June 2021 - h. 16.00 - 18.00 (CEST)</strong><br /> <strong>15<sup>th</sup> June 2021 - h. 16.00 - 18.00 (CEST)</strong><br /> <strong>29<sup>th</sup> June 2021 - h. 16.00 - 18.00 (CEST)</strong> </p> <p> This year is the 25th anniversary since the first H. pylori Consensus report held in Maastricht in 1996. </p> <p> We are now working on the 6th consensus edition (Maastricht VI//Florence) with a group of dedicated clinical experts and scientists, focussing on this continuously growing and expanding field. </p> <p> H.pylori is unique in its pathogenic relationship with the stomach which has diverse clinical outcomes due to a series of other interfering factors. Ever since its discovery, H. pylori has aroused great scientific interest with controversial opinions involving numerous medical disciplines, and it has become an exemplary model because of its medical multi- and interdisciplinarity. </p> <p> For this reason we believe that in the context of the H. pylori Consensus development, which combines a challenging academic exercise with the demand to come up with useful clinical guidance, a series of accompanying webinars would be useful for educational purposes in clinical medicine and related scientific disciplines. </p> <p> The contents of these educational webinars will include methodological aspects on how to select relevant questions, provide evidence, proceed with the assessment of individual statements, deal with controversies, and finally, on how to reach a consensus. </p> <p> Authoritative experts in the H. pylori field will give concise presentations with up-to-date knowledge on clinical scenarios, diagnostic procedures, therapeutic strategies, preventive measures, and the interaction of H. pylori with the gut microbiota. Specific aspects, such as the role of H. pylori eradication in patients with myocardial infarction, and H. pylori related clinical challenges in times of COVID-19, will add important actuality to our endeavours. </p> <p> We hope to stimulate your curiosity and interest to follow the webinars accompanying the H. pylori consensus development in the aim of benefitting your daily clinical and academic practice. </p> <p> <em>Course Coordinator:</em><br /> <strong>P. Malfertheiner</strong><br /> Otto-von-Guericke Universität<br /> LMU-Universitätsklinikum , Med. Klinik II<br /> München, DE </p>

presentationDescription_en: <p style="text-align: center; font-size: 14pt;"><strong>Educational events in the context of the H. pylori Consensus development</strong></p> <p style="text-align: center; font-family: Arial; font-size: 14pt; color: #993300;"> <strong>18<sup>th</sup> May 2021 - h. 16.00 - 18.00 (CEST)</strong><br /> <strong>3<sup>rd</sup> June 2021 - h. 16.00 - 18.00 (CEST)</strong><br /> <strong>15<sup>th</sup> June 2021 - h. 16.00 - 18.00 (CEST)</strong><br /> <strong>29<sup>th</sup> June 2021 - h. 16.00 - 18.00 (CEST)</strong> </p> <p> This year is the 25th anniversary since the first H. pylori Consensus report held in Maastricht in 1996. </p> <p> We are now working on the 6th consensus edition (Maastricht VI//Florence) with a group of dedicated clinical experts and scientists, focussing on this continuously growing and expanding field. </p> <p> H.pylori is unique in its pathogenic relationship with the stomach which has diverse clinical outcomes due to a series of other interfering factors. Ever since its discovery, H. pylori has aroused great scientific interest with controversial opinions involving numerous medical disciplines, and it has become an exemplary model because of its medical multi- and interdisciplinarity. </p> <p> For this reason we believe that in the context of the H. pylori Consensus development, which combines a challenging academic exercise with the demand to come up with useful clinical guidance, a series of accompanying webinars would be useful for educational purposes in clinical medicine and related scientific disciplines. </p> <p> The contents of these educational webinars will include methodological aspects on how to select relevant questions, provide evidence, proceed with the assessment of individual statements, deal with controversies, and finally, on how to reach a consensus. </p> <p> Authoritative experts in the H. pylori field will give concise presentations with up-to-date knowledge on clinical scenarios, diagnostic procedures, therapeutic strategies, preventive measures, and the interaction of H. pylori with the gut microbiota. Specific aspects, such as the role of H. pylori eradication in patients with myocardial infarction, and H. pylori related clinical challenges in times of COVID-19, will add important actuality to our endeavours. </p> <p> We hope to stimulate your curiosity and interest to follow the webinars accompanying the H. pylori consensus development in the aim of benefitting your daily clinical and academic practice. </p> <p> <em>Course Coordinator:</em><br /> <strong>P. Malfertheiner</strong><br /> Otto-von-Guericke Universität<br /> LMU-Universitätsklinikum , Med. Klinik II<br /> München, DE </p>

title_it: Breast Cancer in the Elderly
title_en: Breast Cancer in the Elderly
presentationDescription_it: <p>Breast cancer management in older patients can be challenging and requires calibrated and weighted risk-benefit decision making. Despite breast cancer being a common disease in older women, few evidence-based recommendations exist upon which oncologists can ground their clinical decisions. The course will handle breast cancer management in older patients from different perspectives, from the place older people have in our society to the characterization and needs of older patients according to different health professional specialties including patients’ advocates. Specific diagnostic and treatment scenarios and controverses will be discussed and debated emphasizing the most relevant pending questions and new evidence. The overall aim is to provide a broad panorama on how to address the complexity of different disease settings in older patients and to help clinicians to understand and select the best available choices in routine clinical practice, when sitting in a multidisciplinary meeting or in front of the patient according.<br /></p><p><strong>Laura Biganzoli and Olivia Pagani</strong></p><p><br /></p><p><br /></p>
presentationDescription_en:
Breast cancer management in older patients can be challenging and requires calibrated and weighted risk-benefit decision making. Despite breast cancer being a common disease in older women, few evidence-based recommendations exist upon which oncologists can ground their clinical decisions. The course will handle breast cancer management in older patients from different perspectives, from the place older people have in our society to the characterization and needs of older patients according to different health professional specialties including patients’ advocates. Specific diagnostic and treatment scenarios and controverses will be discussed and debated emphasizing the most relevant pending questions and new evidence. The overall aim is to provide a broad panorama on how to address the complexity of different disease settings in older patients and to help clinicians to understand and select the best available choices in routine clinical practice, when sitting in a multidisciplinary meeting or in front of the patient according.

Laura Biganzoli and Olivia Pagani

title_it: IV Florence International Symposium on Advances in CARDIOMyopathies
title_en: IV Florence International Symposium on Advances in CARDIOMyopathies
presentationDescription_it: <p> Dear colleagues, <br /> It is a great pleasure to invite you to the “IV Florence International Symposium on Advances in Cardiomyopathies”, to be held in Florence on the 9th and 10th of September 2021. As in the previous editions held in 2008, 2012 and 2015, the course is designed to constantly promote close interaction between basic science and clinical practice, in an attempt to address the topic in a truly global fashion. Novel options such as next generation sequencing gene testing, innovative pharmacological approaches and the subcutaneous ICD will be discussed. It is hoped that the broad range of topics will attract the interest of a wide audience, including physicians, clinical researchers, cardiologists, pathologists, basic scientists, and young investigators. <br /> A wide and open discussion among all the participants is welcome. <br /> We hope that the Symposium will be extremely productive, providing with an opportunity to improve our understanding of this challenging area of expertise and to stimulate further research into the field. <br /> We look forward to welcoming you in Florence next September. Arrivederci a Firenze !! </p> <p style="text-align: right;"> <strong>Franco Cecchi <br />Iacopo Olivotto </strong> </p> <p style="text-align: center;font-size: 12pt;color: #989898;"> <strong> Puoi scegliere 2 modalità di partecipazione: in streaming (Tab LIVE STREAMING) <br /> <br /> o con presenza all&#39;evento (Tab PARTECIPAZIONE RESIDENZIALE). <br /> <br /> Vi ricordiamo che in quest&#39;ultimo caso, secondo le ultime disposizioni di legge, è OBBLIGATORIO esibire la certificazione di avvenuta doppia vaccinazione (cd Green Pass) per accedere a convegni e congressi.</strong> </p> <p style="text-align: center;font-size: 12pt;color: #124173;"> <strong>&quot;Gentile utente, a seguito del raggiunto limite massimo di presenze consentite secondo le ultime disposizioni Covid, non è più possibile registrarsi per la partecipazione all&#39;evento in presenza, ma solo per l&#39;accesso al live streaming.&quot;</strong> </p>
presentationDescription_en: <p> Dear colleagues, <br /> It is a great pleasure to invite you to the “IV Florence International Symposium on Advances in Cardiomyopathies”, to be held in Florence on the 9th and 10th of September 2021. As in the previous editions held in 2008, 2012 and 2015, the course is designed to constantly promote close interaction between basic science and clinical practice, in an attempt to address the topic in a truly global fashion. Novel options such as next generation sequencing gene testing, innovative pharmacological approaches and the subcutaneous ICD will be discussed. It is hoped that the broad range of topics will attract the interest of a wide audience, including physicians, clinical researchers, cardiologists, pathologists, basic scientists, and young investigators. <br /> A wide and open discussion among all the participants is welcome. <br /> We hope that the Symposium will be extremely productive, providing with an opportunity to improve our understanding of this challenging area of expertise and to stimulate further research into the field. <br /> We look forward to welcoming you in Florence next September. title_it: International Symposium on: H. Pylori Consensus Report Maastricht VI Florence
title_en: International Symposium on: H. Pylori Consensus Report Maastricht VI Florence
presentationDescription_it: <div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;">We are here to finalize the 6th H. Pylori consensus conference (Maastricht VI//Florence) in a face-to-face meeting and we are truly sorry that some of our team members from outside Europe will have to be connected via Video.We will sincerely miss their presence on site.</div><div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;">This event will bring the dedicated process of researching on the latest developments in the clinical field of H. Pylori, the writing of comments according to best available scientific evidence and expressing votes on the elaborated statements to a successful end. </div><div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;">To all delegates, clinical experts, and scientists for their invaluable contributions a big Thank-you! </div><div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;">The structure of the meeting is designed to provide time slots for all 5 Working Groups to present each individual statement by the endorsed delegate for general final voting.Statements already accepted in the Delphi round are not intended for further discussion of their contents. Statements left with uncertainty because of controversial opinions however will be reproposed for clarification, debate, and final voting.</div><div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;">We believe that in the context of the unique event of the H. Pylori Consensus development we will appreciate and benefit in receiving short presentations of the latest News on basic and translational science, diagnostic procedures, therapeutic strategies, preventive measures, </div><div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;">and the interaction of H. Pylori with gut microbiota. </div><div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;">We look forward to a challenging and rewarding meeting with on site and Video assisted get together for the successful conclusion </div><div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;">of Maastricht VI/ Florence H. Pylori consensus 2021.&nbsp;</div><div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;">Thank you again for all your enthusiasm and efforts to contribute.&nbsp;</div><div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;">Prof. P. title_it: International Symposium on Update in CV High Risk Patients Management and Anticoagulation
title_en: International Symposium on Update in CV High Risk Patients Management and Anticoagulation
evidenceImageUrl: /Portals/19/vgfm/events/785/generalinformations/11c2ce707afa458991055534501b8cc8_40c19b6d2f86471cb8f66e4c3d740f52_International Symposium on Update in CV high risk patients management.jpg?ver=K-1UpoFZiPpNShqi5UDJcQ%3d%3d
presentationDescription_it: <div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: &#xA;initial;"><div style="color: #000000; text-decoration-color: initial; &#xA;text-align: center;"><strong><span style="color: #800000; font-size: 12pt;"> International Symposium on Update in CV high risk patients management and anticoagulation. </span></strong></div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div> <div style="text-align: center;"><strong>Mexico City (Mexico) 3rd - 4th December 2021<br /><br /></strong></div><div style="text-align: center;"><strong>CO-PRESIDENTS OF THE MEETING:</strong></div><div style="text-align: center;">Prof. Raul Izaguirre,&nbsp;<span style="font-size: 10pt;">Prof. Athanasios J. Manolis&nbsp;&amp;&nbsp;</span>Prof. Juan Verdejo&nbsp;</div><div style="text-align: center;"> </div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><p style="text-align: center;"><br /></p><div style="text-align: center;">Dear Friends Dear Colleagues</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;">On behalf of the Organizing Committee and Fondazione Internazionale Menarini, it</div><div style="text-align: center;">is a great pleasure for us to welcome you to the upcoming International Symposium</div><div style="text-align: center;">on “Update in Cardiovascular High Risk Patients Management and Anticoagulation”</div><div style="text-align: center;">(hybrid event), which will be held in Mexico City on December 3rd-4th 2021.</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;">CVD and principally CHD and Stroke, are the leading causes of global mortality and</div><div style="text-align: center;">major contributors to disability. CVD burden continues its decade long rise for almost</div><div style="text-align: center;">all countries and not only high income ones. Prevalence of total CVD cases nearly</div><div style="text-align: center;">doubled from 271m in 1990 to 523m in 2019 and the number of CVD deaths increased</div><div style="text-align: center;">from 12.1m in 1990 to 18.6 m in 2019.</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;">So the First day of the meeting we will discuss the most important risk factor for CVD</div><div style="text-align: center;">which continues to be Hypertension, the key messages from the recent published ESC</div><div style="text-align: center;">Guidelines for Heart Failure, the recent published trials in the field of Diabetes, an update</div><div style="text-align: center;">in the Management of Chronic Coronary Syndromes and finally other important</div><div style="text-align: center;">topics, such as PAD, Stroke and Dementia, Prevention of Sudden Death and how to</div><div style="text-align: center;">treat the very Elderly.</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;">The Second day will be dedicated to thrombosis and we will cover special and</div><div style="text-align: center;">important topics for thromboprofylaxis with NOAC’s in patients with NVAF, in the</div><div style="text-align: center;">elderly, in CKD, in VTD, in women, post PCI and finally the role of Antidotes.</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;">The presence of Opinion Leaders and Experts from all around the world shall ensure</div><div style="text-align: center;">the success of the meeting.</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;">We cordially invite all of you to join this International Symposium.</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /><div>Prof. <strong>Raul Izaguirre</strong></div><div>Prof. <strong>Athanasios J. Manolis</strong></div><div>Prof. <strong>Juan Verdejo</strong></div><div><em>Co-Presidents of the Meeting</em></div><br /><br /></div></div>
presentationDescription_en: <div style="color: #222222; font-size: small; text-decoration-color: &#xA;initial;"><div style="color: #000000; text-decoration-color: initial; &#xA;text-align: center;"><strong><span style="color: #800000; font-size: 12pt;"> </span></strong><div><strong><span style="color: #800000; font-size: 12pt;">International Symposium on Update in CV high risk patients management and anticoagulation.</span></strong></div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;"><br /></div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;"><strong>Mexico City (Mexico) 3rd - 4th December 2021<br /><br /></strong></div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;"><strong>CO-PRESIDENTS OF THE MEETING:</strong></div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">Prof. Raul Izaguirre,&nbsp;<span style="font-size: 10pt;">Prof. Athanasios J. Manolis&nbsp;&amp;&nbsp;</span>Prof. Juan Verdejo&nbsp;</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;"><br /></div><p style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;"><br /></p><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">Dear Friends Dear Colleagues</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;"><br /></div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">On behalf of the Organizing Committee and Fondazione Internazionale Menarini, it</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">is a great pleasure for us to welcome you to the upcoming International Symposium</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">on “Update in Cardiovascular High Risk Patients Management and Anticoagulation”</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">(hybrid event), which will be held in Mexico City on December 3rd-4th 2021.</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;"><br /></div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">CVD and principally CHD and Stroke, are the leading causes of global mortality and</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">major contributors to disability. CVD burden continues its decade long rise for almost</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">all countries and not only high income ones. Prevalence of total CVD cases nearly</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">doubled from 271m in 1990 to 523m in 2019 and the number of CVD deaths increased</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">from 12.1m in 1990 to 18.6 m in 2019.</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;"><br /></div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">So the First day of the meeting we will discuss the most important risk factor for CVD</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">which continues to be Hypertension, the key messages from the recent published ESC</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">Guidelines for Heart Failure, the recent published trials in the field of Diabetes, an update</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">in the Management of Chronic Coronary Syndromes and finally other important</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">topics, such as PAD, Stroke and Dementia, Prevention of Sudden Death and how to</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">treat the very Elderly.</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;"><br /></div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">The Second day will be dedicated to thrombosis and we will cover special and</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">important topics for thromboprofylaxis with NOAC’s in patients with NVAF, in the</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">elderly, in CKD, in VTD, in women, post PCI and finally the role of Antidotes.</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;"><br /></div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">The presence of Opinion Leaders and Experts from all around the world shall ensure</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">the success of the meeting.</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;"><br /></div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;">We cordially invite all of you to join this International Symposium.</div><div style="color: #222222; text-decoration-color: initial;"><br /><div>Prof.&nbsp;<strong>Raul Izaguirre</strong></div><div>Prof.&nbsp;<strong>Athanasios J.
