title_it: Colloquium between the Experts - Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors in Cardiology
title_en: Colloquium between the Experts - Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors in Cardiology
presentationDescription_it: <div style="font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial;"><div style="color: #222222; text-align: center;">Acetazolamide and other related carbonic anhydrase inhibitors have had a long history of effectiveness in prevention and treatment of acute mountain sickness and remain the standard of care for this indication. Indeed, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors play an important role in several hypoxic conditions. Prof. Erik Swenson from the Department of Medicine, University of Washington, Seattle WA, USA; is at present the major worldwide recognized expert on carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. We will discuss with Prof. Swenson all the possible indications of acetazolamide in cardiology.</div><div style="color: #222222; text-align: center;"><br /></div></div><div style="text-align: center;">Chaired by:</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /><strong>Prof. Piergiuseppe Agostoni</strong></div><div style="text-align: center;">Full Professor in Cardiology</div><div style="text-align: center;">Chief of Heart Failure, Clinical Cardiology</div><div style="text-align: center;">and Rehabilitation Unit</div><div style="text-align: center;">Università degli Studi di Milano</div><div style="text-align: center;">Centro Cardiologico Monzino chaired by</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;"><strong>&nbsp;Prof. Erik Swenson</strong></div><div style="text-align: center;">Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine</div><div style="text-align: center;">Department of Medicine</div><div style="text-align: center;">University of Washington</div><div style="text-align: center;">Seattle, WA, USA</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div>
presentationDescription_en: <div style="font-size: small; text-decoration-color: initial;"><div style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #222222;">Acetazolamide and other related carbonic anhydrase inhibitors have had a long history of effectiveness in prevention and treatment of acute mountain sickness and remain the standard of care for this indication. Indeed, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors play an important role in several hypoxic conditions. Prof. Erik Swenson from the Department of Medicine, University of Washington, Seattle WA, USA; is at present the major worldwide recognized expert on carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. We will discuss with Prof. Swenson all the possible indications of acetazolamide in cardiology.</span></div><div style="color: #222222; text-align: center;"><br /></div></div><div style="text-align: center;">Chaired by:</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /><strong>Prof. Piergiuseppe Agostoni</strong></div><div style="text-align: center;">Full Professor in Cardiology</div><div style="text-align: center;">Chief of Heart Failure, Clinical Cardiology</div><div style="text-align: center;">and Rehabilitation Unit</div><div style="text-align: center;">Università degli Studi di Milano</div><div style="text-align: center;">Centro Cardiologico Monzino chaired by</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;"><strong>&nbsp;Prof. Erik Swenson</strong></div><div style="text-align: center;">Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine</div><div style="text-align: center;">Department of Medicine</div><div style="text-align: center;">University of Washington</div><div style="text-align: center;">Seattle, WA, USA</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div>

title_it: XV UPDATE IN ANESTESIA OSTETRICA
title_en: XV UPDATE IN OBSTETRIC ANESTHESIA
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center;">A dispetto dell&#39;incertezza legata alla pandemia e alle nuove condizioni in cui ci troviamo a vivere e a lavorare da due anni a questa parte, siamo lieti e orgogliosi di ritrovarvi al XV Update in Anestesia Ostetrica: una sicurezza in tempi disorientanti. Ad oggi resta un&#39;occasione di confronto che permette alle diverse componenti dell&#39;equipe di sala parto di interagire e relazionarsi su argomentazioni e problematiche quotidiane più o meno gravi, più o meno frequenti. Uno spunto per confrontarsi e migliorare pratiche cliniche già consolidate o modificarle qualora obsolete o sub standard. Buon lavoro a tutti e grazie al contributo di ognuno!</p><div style="text-align: center;"><strong>RESPONSABILE SCIENTIFICO </strong></div><div style="text-align: center;"><strong>FERDINANDO LUCA LORINI</strong></div><div style="text-align: center;">Direttore Dipartimento di Emergenza Urgenza e Area Critica</div><div style="text-align: center;">ASST Papa Giovanni XXIII - BERGAMO</div>
presentationDescription_en: <div style="text-align: center;"><strong>SCIENTIFIC DIRECTOR</strong></div><div style="text-align: center;"><strong>FERDINANDO LUCA LORINI</strong></div><div style="text-align: center;">Director of Emergency Department and Critical Area&nbsp;</div><div style="text-align: center;">ASST Papa Giovanni XXIII - BERGAMO</div>

title_it: Heart and Virus: which link? Long Covid syndrome and future scenario
title_en: Heart and Virus: which link? Long Covid syndrome and future scenario
presentationDescription_it: <div style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="color: #800000;">Heart and Virus: which link? Long Covid syndrome and future scenario </span></strong></div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;"><div>To highlight the most important cardiological and clinical findings diring Sars- cov-2 infection and to share different expertise.</div><div>To look at the previous mistakes to avoid them in the future.</div><div>Starting from the positive actions to fight better and more effectively under the cardiological point of view any future pandemic.</div><div>To highlight the long Covid syndrome and the potential effect in the future.</div><div><br /></div><div>Medical disciplines:</div><div>Cardiologists, Internists, Pulmonologists, Geriatricians, General Practitioners, Intensivists, Emergentists, Radiologists, Infectious disease specialists, Nurses and Technicians, Pharmacists.</div><div><br /><div>President: Fausto Rigo</div><div>Villa Salus Hospital Foundation / IRCCS San Camillo Hospital, Venice, IT</div><div><br /></div><div>CO – President: Fausto Pinto</div><div>Department of Cardiology, School of Medicine CCUL, University of Lisbon, Lisbon, PT</div></div><p><br /></p><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/cover_programma_Pagina_1.jpg" alt="" /></div>

title_it: Advances in heart failure, cardiomyopathies and pericardial diseases
title_en: Advances in heart failure, cardiomyopathies and pericardial diseases
venue: Centro Congressi, Molo IV 1: Punto Franco Vecchio, Magazzino I - Molo IV/Trieste, Italy
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center;">Heart Failure represents a high-prevalence worldwide syndromes, due to the ageing and the increasing co-morbidity profile of the general population. Several recent advances in medical and device treatments have been done in the recent years, with the results of new classes of drugs available in the therapeutic armamentarium of physicians. Despite those achievements, prognosis of Heart Failure is still poor and important gaps of knowledge remain to be filled. In this perspective, the complex road of etiological definition and personalized therapy represent an important horizon. Myocardial and pericardial diseases are relevant causes of Heart Failure in which significant advances in terms of survival improvement have been obtained in the last decades. The characterization of cardiomyopathies, beyond the classical phenotypic classification, towards a personalized medicine and a targeted therapy is one of the main reason at the basis of this survival improvement. New techniques, such as cardiac magnetic resonance and genetic testing, integrated to the classical clinical, ECG and echocardiographic evaluation are the cornerstones of the modern management of myocardial and pericardial diseases. The present meeting has been thought to provide to participants a deep and complete overview of the standard and emerging diagnostic techniques and therapeutic strategies of Cardiomyopathies and, more in general, of Heart Failure. The aim of the meeting is to give practical guidelines for the management of those complex patients and their relatives, dealing important issues from clinical evaluation to the application of artificial intelligence and to the latest available therapies, including the future perspectives. For this purpose, the most important Italian and international researchers and opinion leaders have accepted to meet together in Trieste, for assessing the state of the art about the comprehensive clinical management of Heart Failure and Cardiomyopathies patients.</p> <div style="text-align: center;"><strong>Co-Presidents of the Meeting</strong></div><div style="text-align: center;"><strong>Prof. Gianfranco Sinagra &amp; Prof. Perry Elliott</strong></div>

title_it: 4th INTERNATIONAL WORKSHOP ON TUMOR EVOLUTION - MAKING THE IMPOSSIBLE POSSIBLE: SUCCESSFUL TACKLING OF DIFFICULT TARGETS IN CANCER RESEARCH AND CLINICAL DEVELOPMENT
title_en: 4th INTERNATIONAL WORKSHOP ON TUMOR EVOLUTION - MAKING THE IMPOSSIBLE POSSIBLE: SUCCESSFUL TACKLING OF DIFFICULT TARGETS IN CANCER RESEARCH AND CLINICAL DEVELOPMENT
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center;">The past decades have witnessed major advances in our understanding of cancer biology. Breakthroughs in genomic technologies, transcriptomic profiling leveraged at single cell level, functional characterization of genes boosted more recently by the advent of whole-genome CRISPR/Cas9 screens, have enhanced our identification of therapeutic targets. Unfortunately, many of the candidate genes that emerged from these studies have shown to be extremely difficult if not impossible to target. KRAS, TP53, MYC, PTEN gene alterations are only a few examples of key drivers whose therapeutic targeting have not yet entered the clinical practice, with the notable exception of the recent development of KRAC G12C inhibitors for the treatment of non small cell lung cancer. In line with this brilliant example, the of this workshop focuses on showing how to “make the impossible possible: i.e. to successfully tackle difficult targets in cancer research and clinical development”. These ambitious goals require the combination of clever and sophisticated medicinal chemistry efforts aided by advanced structural biology as well as innovative clinical trials. In this regard, clinical trials act as a critical engine for the discovery and development of new therapies undergoing a massive re-wiring in the last decade. Indeed, they shifted from traditional studies evaluating cytotoxic chemotherapy to histology-based populations conceived to be adaptively designed and biomarker-driven to evaluate precise molecular targeted and immunotherapies in selected patients subsets. Unprecedented effort has been devoted to the generation of a framework that can timely transform scientific discoveries to clinical practice through the application of innovative technologies and adaptive design methodologies.</p><p><br /></p><p style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="color: #800000;">ORGANIZATION COMMITTEE:</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: center;"><strong>GENNARO CILIBERTO, FEDERICO CAPPUZZO, RITA FALCIONI, GIOVANNI BLANDINO</strong></p>

title_it: RespiraMi IV international seminar. Recent advances on air pollution and health
title_en: RespiraMi IV international seminar. Recent advances on air pollution and health
presentationDescription_it: <h4 style="text-align: center;">Respirami IV International Seminar Recent Advances on Air Pollution and Health</h4><h4 style="text-align: center;">Milan, Italy, 17th-18th June, 2022<br /></h4> <p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Scientific Directors:</strong><br /> Prof. Francesco Forastiere<br /> Prof. Sergio A. Harari<br /> Prof. Michal Krzyzanowski<br /> Prof. Pier Mannuccio Mannucci</p><div style="text-align: center;"> </div><p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Rationale</strong></p><div style="text-align: center;"> </div><p style="text-align: center;">Air pollution is one of the most important risk factors for global morbidity, disability and mortality. Because a huge number of individuals are currently exposed to this risk in high-income as well as in low-income countries, the health care and public health dimensions of its consequences are impressive, considering that, according to global data stemming concordantly from WHO and the Global Burden of Disease epidemiological study, at least 7 million premature deaths are due to ambient and household air pollution. With this background, together with the team of epidemiologists from Lazio (led by Francesco Forastiere and Massimo Stafoggia) plus a former staff member of WHO (Michal Krzyzanowski), first in 2015 we chose to organize every three years an independent international seminar called RespiraMi, with the goal to gather the most distinguished global experts and prompt them to present their recent and mostly unpublished data on the progress of science towards tackling the global issue of outdoor and indoor air pollution.<br /> The fourth 2022 edition and scientific program of the Seminar (RespiraMi 4) enlists a faculty of speakers from four continents (Europe, North America and Asia), who will put special emphasis on the effects of air pollution on the weakest groups of world citizens: the newborn, pregnant women, older and poorest people, as well as on the growing evidence that air pollution is a cause of most common, growing and devastating neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson and dementia.<br /> The 2022 International Seminar “Recent Advances on Air Pollution and Health” will be organized as a hybrid event lasting two days in Milan, on June 17 and 18, in order to provide insights not only on the current state of the art but also a look on to the future of air quality and related research efforts.<br /> Session 1 will summarize the new and recent evidence that prompted WHO to release the updated Air Quality Guidelines (AQG), designed to preserve better than the previous guidelines health state of citizens of the whole world on the basis of new evidence on the deleterious effects even of low levels of pollutants.<br /> The session will also offer new evidence on the effects on health of specific pollutants such as NO2 and biomass burning emissions. Session 2 will deal with new aspects pertaining to several damages of air pollution on human health, with special emphasis on outcomes such as mental health and cognitive development as well as on pregnancy complications. Session 3 will offer a systematic review of selected effects of traffic-related air pollution, with special emphasis on mortality but also on morbidity for cardiovascular and respiratory disease and on birth outcomes. Session 4 will provide new evidence on the beneficial effects of greenness and how to best design the ecosystem service of trees and ornamental potted plants in order to reduce indoor and outdoor pollution. Session 5 deals with the burden of diseases stemming from major air pollution sources, with specific evidence from highly polluted countries from the third world such as India, Nigeria and Ghana. Session 6 will tackle the formidable challenges warranted to achieve a cleaner air and illustrate in this context the European Green Deal program, as well as the ongoing plan to update the European air quality legislation. Session 7 will feature the current burden of air pollution in Italy and the role of Italian researchers from the Network on Environment and Health, and will also feature the impact on ambient air pollution of COVID-19 lockdown restrictions in Milan and Rome. Finally, Session 8 will be based on a panel discussion addressing the questions of future planning of research on air pollution, and we expect to get comments and suggestions by the live but also remote audience to the Seminar. Interested participants, both in presence and at distance, should get registered at Fondazione Menarini, but registration is free of charge.</p><p style="text-align: center;"><br /></p><h5 style="text-align: center;">Per gli utenti non healthcare, vi segnaliamo la possibilità di iscriversi all&#39;evento a partire dalla prossima settimana. Per ogni ulteriore informazione o segnalazione, fate pure riferimento al nostro <a href="https://www.fondazione-menarini.it/Home/Contattaci">Contact Us</a></h5><div><br /></div>

Harari<br /> Prof. Michal Krzyzanowski<br /> Prof. Pier Mannuccio Mannucci</p><div style="text-align: center;"> </div><p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Rationale</strong></p><div style="text-align: center;"> </div><p style="text-align: center;">Air pollution is one of the most important risk factors for global morbidity, disability and mortality. Session 7 will feature the current burden of air pollution in Italy and the role of Italian researchers from the Network on Environment and Health, and will also feature the impact on ambient air pollution of COVID-19 lockdown restrictions in Milan and Rome. Finally, Session 8 will be based on a panel discussion addressing the questions of future planning of research on air pollution, and we expect to get comments and suggestions by the live but also remote audience to the Seminar. Interested participants, both in presence and at distance, should get registered at Fondazione Menarini, but registration is free of charge.</p><p style="text-align: center;"><br /></p><h5 style="text-align: center;">To non-health care users, we recognise the possibility to subscribe for the event starting next week. From any information or warnings please use our<a href="https://www.en.fondazione-menarini.it/Home/Contact-Us?_ga=2.65937771.494264955.1654695783-1049191007.1654695783"> Contact Us</a></h5>

title_en: Digital Symposium SARS-CoV-2: current challenges beyond COVID-19
presentationDescription_it: <h3 style="text-align: center;">Digital Symposium SARS-CoV-2: current challenges beyond COVID-19</h3><div style="text-align: center;"><strong>Scientific Directors</strong></div><div style="text-align: center;"><strong>prof. Carlo Federico Perno Roma (IT)</strong></div><div style="text-align: center;"><strong>prof. Federico Garcia Granada (ES)</strong></div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;"><div>We have been living for two years in the mist of a global pandemic, the resolution of which has</div><div>depended, and still depends, on the awareness, training and involvement of all health professionals</div><div>at multiple levels. The availability of vaccines and new therapeutic strategies provide us with tools</div><div>of critical importance, the management of which must however be carefully regulated. Knowledge</div><div>of their potential in relation to the epidemiology of infection, viral evolution and the continuous</div><div>updating of diagnosis and surveillance tools is part of a fundamental training for those who work in</div><div>the health sector, which must be preserved and promoted.</div><div><br /></div><div>The SARS-CoV-2 outbreak has led to a steady stream of new information about the virus, the</div><div>disease it causes, and the tools to diagnose and fight it. These range from seminal and</div><div>groundbreaking studies published in leading medical journals to pre-print articles, released even</div><div>before their scientific validity is established by peer-review. This continuous flow of information</div><div>underscores the need for expert scrutiny of emerging data and international public health</div><div>provisions, transforming them into a concise and clear message.</div><div><br /></div><div>These webinars are a series of interactive online meetings. The program includes a wide range of</div><div>topics, from virology to epidemiology, prevention and treatment of COVID-19, diagnostics, public</div><div>health measures, clinical manifestations and the management of acute and chronic complications.</div><div>The goal of this series of meetings is to give an expert reading of the most relevant and innovative</div><div>aspects of SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19.</div><div><br /></div><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div>

title_it: International Symposium From Genes to target therapy in Hematology - a meeting to celebrate 50+2 years of Hematology Department in Florence
title_en: International Symposium From Genes to target therapy in Hematology - a meeting to celebrate 50+2 years of Hematology Department in Florence
presentationDescription_it: <h4 style="text-align: center;">International Symposium From Genes to target therapy in Hematology - a meeting to celebrate 50+2 years of Hematology Department in Florence</h4><p><br /></p><div style="text-align: center;">It is undoubtful that hematology has witnessed many exciting discoveries in the last 50 years, ranging from the description of recurrent chromosomal defects uniquely associated with disease, such as the Philadelphia chromosome in chronic myelogenous leukemia, to the discovery of genes considered to be disease-driver and/or associated with unique clinical characteristics and prognosis, to the immunophenotypic characterization of very rare bone marrow and blood cell subsets with specific functions, perhaps no other field in clinical medicine witnessed so rapid translation of discoveries from the laboratory to patient’s side, in terms of new powerful diagnostic tools made available, new diagnostic categories being identified and prognostic scores developed, and, after all, new therapeutic options being made available for the patients. There is no doubt that these progresses have contributed to start a new era of personalized medicine in hematology.</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;">It is with these premises that we are honored to host colleagues and friends at this meeting, emblematically entitled “From genes to target therapy in Hematology”.</div><div style="text-align: center;">The topics covered in more than 30 scientific presentations and In Focus talks point to many fields of hematology where the most breakthrough advancements occurred, promoting changes in the diagnosis and management of neoplastic and non-neoplastic diseases.</div><div style="text-align: center;">A Faculty of national and international experts will drive us in such exciting pilgrimage to modern hematology.</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;">There is also a more intimate, yet public, reason to promote this meeting,</div><div style="text-align: center;">that is, the opportunity to celebrate, through science, the first 50 years of</div><div style="text-align: center;">the Hematology Unit in Florence, an institution where -we are proudly</div><div style="text-align: center;">convinced- those advances progressively became part of the management</div><div style="text-align: center;">of patients with hematologic disorders. Unfortunately, COVID</div><div style="text-align: center;">pandemia forced us to move the meeting from the spring of 2020 to</div><div style="text-align: center;">summer 2022, so that we are actually celebrating the 52nd year of the</div><div style="text-align: center;">Florence Hematology…but no worries, let the celebration begin!</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;">prof. Alessandro Maria Vannucchi</div>

title_it: Updates in cardiovascular diseases and guidelines
title_en: Updates in cardiovascular diseases and guidelines
presentationDescription_it: <h6 style="text-align: center;">Updates in Cardiovascular Diseases and Guidelines</h6><div style="text-align: center;">Cardiovascular Diseases continue to be the leading cause of death worldwide.</div><div style="text-align: center;">However, during the past few years, with prevention and effective treatment we</div><div style="text-align: center;">have succeeded in not only significantly reducing morbidity and mortality, but also</div><div style="text-align: center;">increasing life expectancy.</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;">During this 2 days’ meeting, Opinion Leaders and renewed Experts from all around the</div><div style="text-align: center;">world will share their knowledge and will discuss the important role of prevention and</div><div style="text-align: center;">diagnosis, as well as the latest data for the best clinical management and treatment</div><div style="text-align: center;">options.</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;">We will have the opportunity to contribute to the highest level of cardiovascular</div><div style="text-align: center;">science going through a very rich scientific programme, and all together with local</div><div style="text-align: center;">and international speakers, we will address the most important cardiovascular risk</div><div style="text-align: center;">factors, hot topics in all cardiovascular medicine such as Hypertension, Heart Failure,</div><div style="text-align: center;">Coronary Heart Disease, Stroke, Atrial Fibrillation, Pulmonary Embolism, COVID-19</div><div style="text-align: center;">etc. as well as the recently published Guidelines.</div><div title_it: Interstitial lung diseases: today and tomorrow
title_en: Interstitial lung diseases: today and tomorrow
presentationDescription_it: <h6 style="text-align: center;">1° Session - 02 May 2022 3.00 p.m. -5.10 p.m.</h6> <h6 style="text-align: center;">2° Session - 11 May 2022 5.00 p.m. -7.00 p.m.</h6> <h6 style="text-align: center;">3° Session - 23 May 2022 3.00 p.m. -5.00 p.m.</h6> <p> <strong>Scientific Directors:</strong><br /> Prof. Carlo Vancheri and Prof. Luca Richeldi </p> <h6 style="text-align: center;">RATIONALE</h6> <p> Interstitial Lung Diseases (ILDs) are a large family of disorders characterized by inflammation and/or fibrosis of the lungs. Some ILDs, such as IPF and sarcoidosis, are idiopathic, others including hypersensitivity pneumonia and drug-induced ILDs_ recognize specific etiologic agents, some others are instead associated with systemic diseases as in the case of connective tissue diseases (CTD-ILDs). ILDs represent about 20 % of the lung diseases routinely seen by a pulmonologist in his daily activity and their number, due to the improvement of the diagnostic procedures, is increasing. It is also plausible that exposures to known risk factors such as smoking, but also to new and unknown environmental and professional agents or drugs may be responsible for this alarming trend. This, may easily explain the increasing scientific attention for ILDs by researchers and clinicians attracted by the wide array of “intriguing” basic and clinical issues associated with pathogenesis, diagnosis, follow-up and treatment of this group of diseases. In particular, a large number of clinical, functional and radiological overlaps among ILDs makes their diagnosis extremely difficult and challenging. This meeting will address practical and still controversial or unresolved clinical issues related to ILDs. Pulmonologists, radiologists and other experts will bring together their knowledge with the unique aim to underline specific research or clinical aspects of ILDs that might be useful to make easier the management of ILDs for a larger audience of clinicians. The participation and commitment of international experts for this group of diseases, coming from very different scientific and clinical settings, confirms the relevance and the broad clinical interest for this important chapter of respiratory diseases. </p>
presentationDescription_en: <h6 style="text-align: center;">1° Session - 02 May 2022 3.00 p.m. -5.10 p.m.</h6> <h6 style="text-align: center;">2° Session - 11 May 2022 5.00 p.m. -7.00 p.m.</h6> <h6 style="text-align: center;">3° Session - 23 May 2022 3.00 p.m. -5.00 p.m.</h6> <p> <strong>Scientific Directors:</strong><br /> Prof. Carlo Vancheri and Prof. Luca Richeldi </p> <h6 style="text-align: center;">RATIONALE</h6> <p> Interstitial Lung Diseases (ILDs) are a large family of disorders characterized by inflammation and/or fibrosis of the lungs. Some ILDs, such as IPF and sarcoidosis, are idiopathic, others including hypersensitivity pneumonia and drug-induced ILDs_ recognize specific etiologic agents, some others are instead associated with systemic diseases as in the case of connective tissue diseases (CTD-ILDs). ILDs represent about 20 % of the lung diseases routinely seen by a pulmonologist in his daily activity and their number, due to the improvement of the diagnostic procedures, is increasing. title_it: Innovations in cardiac amyloidosis. Pathophysiology, diagnosis and treatment. Pisa Amyloid 2022
title_en: Innovations in cardiac amyloidosis. Pathophysiology, diagnosis and treatment. Pisa Amyloid 2022
presentationDescription_it:
Cardiac amyloidosis (CA) is caused by the accumulation of amyloid fibrils in the extracellular space of the myocardium, leading to clinical manifestations that include conduction disturbances and heart failure. CA was traditionally considered a rare disease with no effective therapies and a poor prognosis. In recent years, more options for non-invasive diagnosis and greater disease awareness have led to the identification of a growing number of cases, challenging the notion of CA as a rare disorder. The ability of recognizing and managing patients with CA should become part of the core curriculum of Cardiologists as well as Internal Medicine specialists, General Practitioners, Neurologists, Nephrologists and Hematologists. The Pisa Amyloid 2022 meeting will gather international experts of CA to the city of the leaning tower and will represent a unique opportunity to learn about CA for all audiences, as it will span from basic knowledge about CA to the forefront of scientific research.

Michele Emdin, Claudio Passino, Claudio Rapezzi, Giuseppe Vergaro
presentationDescription_en: <em>Cardiac amyloidosis (CA) is caused by the accumulation of amyloid fibrils in the extracellular space of the myocardium, leading to clinical manifestations that include conduction disturbances and heart failure. CA was traditionally considered a rare disease with no effective therapies and a poor prognosis. In recent years, more options for non-invasive diagnosis and greater disease awareness have led to the identification of a growing number of cases, challenging the notion of CA as a rare disorder. The ability of recognizing and managing patients with CA should become part of the core curriculum of Cardiologists as well as Internal Medicine specialists, General Practitioners, Neurologists, Nephrologists and Hematologists. The Pisa Amyloid 2022 meeting will gather international experts of CA to the city of the leaning tower and will represent a unique opportunity to learn about CA for all audiences, as it will span from basic knowledge about CA to the forefront of scientific research.<br /><br /><strong>Michele Emdin, Claudio Passino, Claudio Rapezzi, Giuseppe Vergaro</strong></em>

title_it: Conference on Sex, gender and epigenetics: from molecule to bedside
title_en: Conference on Sex, gender and epigenetics: from molecule to bedside
description_it: “Sex, Gender and Epigenetics: From Molecule to Bedside” is the first in a series of symposia focusing on the most important topics in contemporary biomedicine and technology. We have organized this me
venue: Fortezza da Basso – Sala della Scherma
presentationDescription_it: <div><strong>“Sex, Gender and Epigenetics: From Molecule to Bedside”</strong> is the first in a series of symposia focusing on the most important topics in contemporary biomedicine and technology. </div><div>We have organized this meeting at the invitation of Italy’s Fondazione Internazionale Menarini, which has created this major new initiative to foster its educational</div><div>mission. Each symposium will feature international panels of world-class experts and will be hosted in Florence, Italy. The proceedings will represent a 21st-century overview of each of the topics chosen and be published both online and in printed form. </div><div><br /></div><div>Twenty-three expert scholars from around the world, including Nobel laureate in Chemistry Doctor Aaron Ciechanover, will participate in this first symposium, scheduled for May 12-14 of 2022. </div><div>It will consider the function, mechanisms and relationship of epigenetic processes to the normal physiology of men and women as well as the sex-specific experience of disease. Our program will emphasize the clinical relevance of how the genome is epigenetically modified by the environment and how some of those modifications are transmitted to future generations. A focus on epigenetics for the prevention, detection and treatment of disease will be an important component of our discussions. </div><div><br /></div><div>We welcome you to this inaugural symposium, the first in a landmark series formulated to present comprehensive overviews of the most important issues in 21st century medicine and technology.</div>
presentationDescription_en: <div><strong>“Sex, Gender and Epigenetics: From Molecule to Bedside”</strong>&nbsp;is the first in a series of symposia focusing on the most important topics in contemporary biomedicine and technology.</div><div>We have organized this meeting at the invitation of Italy’s Fondazione Internazionale Menarini, which has created this major new initiative to foster its educational</div><div>mission. Each symposium will feature international panels of world-class experts and will be hosted in Florence, Italy. The proceedings will represent a 21st-century overview of each of the topics chosen and be published both online and in printed form.</div><div><br /></div><div>Twenty-three expert scholars from around the world, including Nobel laureate in Chemistry Doctor Aaron Ciechanover, will participate in this first symposium, scheduled for May 12-14 of 2022.</div><div>It will consider the function, mechanisms and relationship of epigenetic processes to the normal physiology of men and women as well as the sex-specific experience of disease. Our program will emphasize the clinical relevance of how the genome is epigenetically modified by the environment and how some of those modifications are transmitted to future generations. A focus on epigenetics for the prevention, detection and treatment of disease will be an important component of our discussions.</div><div><br /></div><div>We welcome you to this inaugural symposium, the first in a landmark series formulated to present comprehensive overviews of the most important issues in 21st century medicine and technology.</div>

title_it: International consensus on: Role of interventional pulmonology in COPD and other respiratory pathologies
title_en: International consensus on: Role of interventional pulmonology in COPD and other respiratory pathologies
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center;"><strong>WELCOME LETTER</strong></p> <p style="text-align: center;"> La Pneumologia interventistica si occupa della diagnostica e della terapia delle malattie respiratorie con metodiche invasive. L’attività è focalizzata sull’utilizzo delle tecniche endoscopiche e bioptiche, con strumento flessibile e rigido, per la diagnosi e il trattamento di un ampio spettro di patologie dell’apparato respiratorio: malattie neoplastiche di bronchi, del polmone e della pleura, malattie interstiziali polmonari, patologie ostruttive bronchiali, patologia infettiva severa, stenosi tracheobronchiali, rimozione dei corpi estranei.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"> La Pneumologia Interventistica sta avendo un’evoluzione molto rapida negli ultimi anni per le migliorate tecniche e strumentazioni a disposizione e per le maggiori conoscenze scientifiche. Per tale motivo la broncoscopia e le procedure pleuriche (ecografia toracica, toracoscopia ecc.) sono diventate strumenti fondamentali nel bagaglio del Pneumologo al quale vengono richieste conoscenze e tecniche sempre più complesse. Il presente Workshop vuole affrontare alcuni aspetti della disciplina che hanno avuto maggiori evoluzioni negli ultimi anni partendo dal problema clinico per arrivare alla soluzione strumentale: le polmoniti specifiche ed aspecifiche, le patologie pleuriche infettive e neoplastiche e il trattamento farmacologico ed endoscopico della BPCO a fenotipo enfisematoso. Il Corso si avvale dei maggiori esperti italiani ed internazionali sui 3 argomenti e sarà disponibile anche alla fruizione on-line. </p> <p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Prof. Lorenzo Corbetta<br />President of the Meeting</strong></p>
presentationDescription_en: <p style="text-align: center;"><strong>WELCOME LETTER</strong></p> <p style="text-align: center;"> La Pneumologia interventistica si occupa della diagnostica e della terapia delle malattie respiratorie con metodiche invasive. Per tale motivo la broncoscopia e le procedure pleuriche (ecografia toracica, toracoscopia ecc.) sono diventate strumenti fondamentali nel bagaglio del Pneumologo al quale vengono richieste conoscenze e tecniche sempre più complesse. title_it: Update in neuro-oncology

title_it: Digital international symposium: New horizons in the therapy of gynecologic cancer
title_en: Digital international symposium: New horizons in the therapy of gynecologic cancer
presentationDescription_it: In the last two decades the treatment of ovarian and endometrial carcinomas has achieved tremendous progress thanks also to the implementation of multidisciplinary boards and to the progress of knowledge of molecular biology. These seminars will discuss the state of the art in the treatment of ovarian and endometrial carcinomas and the new horizons of therapy. Particular attention will be paid to the asperts connected with virtual multidisciplinarity and the management of patients, aspects of these current issues in the field of Covid-19 panepidemic. This multidisciplinary approach plays a pivotal role in the management of women affected by ovarin or endometrial cancer since referral to high-volume oncological center is to date mandatory to assure best practice. Furthermore the impact of new knowledge on the molecular biology of these neoplasms will be discussed in depth.
presentationDescription_en: In the last two decades the treatment of ovarian and endometrial carcinomas has achieved tremendous progress thanks also to the implementation of multidisciplinary boards and to the progress of knowledge of molecular biology. These seminars will discuss the state of the art in the treatment of ovarian and endometrial carcinomas and the new horizons of therapy. Particular attention will be paid to the asperts connected with virtual multidisciplinarity and the management of patients, aspects of these current issues in the field of Covid-19 panepidemic. This multidisciplinary approach plays a pivotal role in the management of women affected by ovarin or endometrial cancer since referral to high-volume oncological center is to date mandatory to assure best practice. Furthermore the impact of new knowledge on the molecular biology of these neoplasms will be discussed in depth.

title_it: International symposium on: Hot topics in cardiovascular medicine and anticoagulation
title_en: International symposium on: Hot topics in cardiovascular medicine and anticoagulation
venue: CANCUN CONVENTION CENTER BLVD. KUKULKÁN KM. 9, PUNTA CANCUN, ZONA HOTELERA, 77500 CANCÚN, Q.R
presentationDescription_it:
Dear Colleagues

On behalf of the Organizing Committee and Fondazione International Menarini, it is a great pleasure for us to welcome you to the upcoming International Symposium on “Hot Topics in Cardiovascular Medicine and Anticoagulation” , which will be held in Cancun on June 24-25, 2022.

Cardiovascular Disease and especially Coronary Heart Disease is the leading cause of death worldwide, and continues its decade long rise for almost all countries and not only the high income ones. However, with the prevention and effective treatment we have succeeded in not only significantly reducing morbidity and mortality, but also increasing life expectancy, despite the residual risk that still exists.

During the two days Symposium, Opinion Leaders and renewed Experts from all around the world will share their knowledge and will discuss the important role of prevention and diagnosis, as well as the latest data for the best clinical management options.

You will have the opportunity to contribute to the highest level of Cardiovascular Science going trough a very rich Scientific Program, and all together with Local and International Speakers, we will address the most important Cardiovascular Risk Factors, Hot Topics in all the area of Cardiovascular Continuum such as Hypertension, Heart Failure, Chronic Coronary Syndromes, Arrhythmias, etc.

The second day will be dedicated to Thrombosis and Anticoagulation and will discuss special topics for Thromboprophylaxis, the role of DOAC’s in Atrial Fibrillation and not only, but also important thinks for COVID-19 and post-COVID Syndrome.

The presence of Opinion Leaders and Experts from all around the world shall ensure the success of the International Symposium. We cordially invite you to join us.

J. Verdejo, B. Khandheria, A. J. Manolis Co-Presidents of the Meeting

We cordially invite you to join us.</p><p><strong>J. Verdejo, B. Khandheria, A. J. Manolis Co-Presidents of the Meeting</strong></p>

title_it: European closed consensus conference on: Diagnosis of arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy
title_en: European closed consensus conference on: Diagnosis of arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center;">Criteria for diagnosis of arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy (ACM) were first proposed in 1994 andrevised in 2010 by an International Task Force. Although the International Task Force criteriademonstrated a good accuracy for diagnosis of the original right ventricular phenotype (arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy), they lacked sensitivity for identification of theexpanding phenotypic spectrum of ACM, which includes left-sided variants and did not incorporate late-gadolinium enhancement findings by cardiac magnetic resonance. The lack of specificdiagnostic criteria for the left ventricular phenotype of ACM has resulted in clinical under-recognition of patients with phenotypes other than the original ARVC over the 4 decades since thedisease discovery. The development of the 2020 upgrading of diagnostic criteria (“the Paduacriteria”) by International experts was based on the evolving clinical experience with the expanding spectrum of ACM phenotypes and needed to fill the diagnostic gap of the previous 1994 and2010 TF guidelines. The key upgrade was the incorporation of tissue characterization findingsby cardiac magnetic resonance for noninvasive detection of late-gadolinium enhancement/myocardial fibrosis that are determinants for characterization of arrhythmogenic biventricularand left ventricular phenotypes. and to provide a codification for future translational and clinicalresearch. The 2020 Padua criteria are heavily dependent on cardiac magnetic resonance, whichhas become mandatory to characterize the ACM phenotype and to exclude other diagnoses. Newcriteria regarding left ventricular depolarization and repolarization ECG abnormalities and ventricular arrhythmias of left ventricular origin were also provided. The 2020 Padua criteria aimedto improve the diagnosis of ACM by providing new criteria for diagnosis of biventricular and ALVCphenotypes, particularly by means of the incorporation of CMR tissue characterization findingsas well as LV depolarization and repolarization ECG abnormalities and ventricular arrhythmias.This new diagnostic approach needs to be validated by clinical studies on large patient populations. Preliminary data confirm that the clinical use of the Padua criteria substantially impactsthe diagnostic accuracy and permits a comprehensive identification of the phenotypic variety ofACM, mostly by virtue of demonstration of RV and LV LGE/myocardial fibrosis by CMR. The application of the upgraded diagnostic criteria in real-world clinical practice will be crucial for futurerefinement and correlation with therapeutic outcomes.</p><p style="text-align: center;">The aim of this Conference is to refine the “Padua criteria” and to reach a large internationalconsensus for the proposal of the 2022 European Task Force Criteria (“refined Padua criteria”),as a result of an interactive discussion between European panellists chosen for their expertise inthe basic science or clinical manifestations of the disease.</p><p style="text-align: center;">The conference will run over two full days and will consist of a series of short presentationsfollowed by interactive round table discussion focused on key aspects of the disease diagnosis,differential diagnosis with phenocopies and characterization of etiologic variants of the disease.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><strong>President of the Meeting</strong><br />Prof. Domenico Corrado<br />Inherited Arrhythmogenic Cardiomyopathies and Sports Cardiology Unit, Department of Cardiac, Thoracic and Vascular Sciences and Public Health University of Padua Medical School, Padua, Italy</p>
presentationDescription_en: <p style="text-align: center;">Criteria for diagnosis of arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy (ACM) were first proposed in 1994 andrevised in 2010 by an International Task Force. The lack of specificdiagnostic criteria for the left ventricular phenotype of ACM has resulted in clinical under-recognition of patients with phenotypes other than the original ARVC over the 4 decades since thedisease discovery. The development of the 2020 upgrading of diagnostic criteria (“the Paduacriteria”) by International experts was based on the evolving clinical experience with the expanding spectrum of ACM phenotypes and needed to fill the diagnostic gap of the previous 1994 and2010 TF guidelines. The key upgrade was the incorporation of tissue characterization findingsby cardiac magnetic resonance for noninvasive detection of late-gadolinium enhancement/myocardial fibrosis that are determinants for characterization of arrhythmogenic biventricularand left ventricular phenotypes. and to provide a codification for future translational and clinicalresearch. The 2020 Padua criteria are heavily dependent on cardiac magnetic resonance, whichhas become mandatory to characterize the ACM phenotype and to exclude other diagnoses. Newcriteria regarding left ventricular depolarization and repolarization ECG abnormalities and ventricular arrhythmias of left ventricular origin were also provided. The 2020 Padua criteria aimedto improve the diagnosis of ACM by providing new criteria for diagnosis of biventricular and ALVCphenotypes, particularly by means of the incorporation of CMR tissue characterization findingsas well as LV depolarization and repolarization ECG abnormalities and ventricular arrhythmias.This new diagnostic approach needs to be validated by clinical studies on large patient populations. Preliminary data confirm that the clinical use of the Padua criteria substantially impactsthe diagnostic accuracy and permits a comprehensive identification of the phenotypic variety ofACM, mostly by virtue of demonstration of RV and LV LGE/myocardial fibrosis by CMR. The application of the upgraded diagnostic criteria in real-world clinical practice will be crucial for futurerefinement and correlation with therapeutic outcomes.</p><p style="text-align: center;">The aim of this Conference is to refine the “Padua criteria” and to reach a large internationalconsensus for the proposal of the 2022 European Task Force Criteria (“refined Padua criteria”),as a result of an interactive discussion between European panellists chosen for their expertise inthe basic science or clinical manifestations of the disease.</p><p style="text-align: center;">The conference will run over two full days and will consist of a series of short presentationsfollowed by interactive round table discussion focused on key aspects of the disease diagnosis,differential diagnosis with phenocopies and characterization of etiologic variants of the disease.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><strong>President of the Meeting</strong><br />Prof. Domenico Corrado<br />Inherited Arrhythmogenic Cardiomyopathies and Sports Cardiology Unit, Department of Cardiac, Thoracic and Vascular Sciences and Public Health University of Padua Medical School, Padua, Italy</p>

title_it: Get up stand up for AYAs with cancer
title_en: Get up stand up for AYAs with cancer
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center;"> Adolescents and young adults (AYAs) diagnosed with cancer make up a particular group of patients whose clinical and psychological needs differ substantially from those of pediatric patients or older adult patients. In recent years, the international scientific community has recognized the particular problems faced by AYA patients. There are several ways in which AYAs inhabit a middle ground between the worlds of pediatric and adult oncology, and neither pediatric nor adult healthcare models have proved capable of meeting their particular features which range from a unique epidemiology (with both pediatric-type and adult-type tumors occurring within the same age group) to a complex psychological sphere, from clinical challenges such as difficulty accessing specialized care and treatment trials to the need for ageappropriate hospital environments with dedicated facilities and programs. </p><p style="text-align: center;">Faced with these challenges, the scientific community should adapt to the needs of AYA patients with cancer by involving diverse health professionals from different disciplines, patient advocates, and stakeholders, possibly engaging on an international level. An excellent example of cooperation between adult and pediatric oncology societies in Europe comes from the European Society for Medical Oncology (ESMO) joining forces with the European Society for Paediatric Oncology (SIOPE) to establish a Working Group on AYAs. Similarly, in April 2021 the Italian Association of Medical Oncology (Associazione Italiana di Oncologia Medica, AIOM) joined forces with the Italian Association of Pediatric Hematology and Oncology (Associazione Italiana di Oncologia ed Ematologia Pediatrica, AIEOP) to set up a formal AIEOP-AIOM Working Group dedicated to AYAs. </p><p style="text-align: center;">Several local, national, and international projects have developed with the aim of improving chances of survival and quality of life. </p><p style="text-align: center;">In this 2-days congress, all the different aspects of AYAs with cancer will be discussed by a panel of international experts that have significantly contributed to elucidating the unique challenges for these patients. Enough time will be reserved for discussion, exchanging opinions and thoughts in addition to the presentation of national and international experiences. Thanks to Fondazione Menarini, we will be hosted in one of the most beautiful venues in Milan: Fondazione Giangiacomo Feltrinelli. </p><p style="text-align: center;">We hope you will enjoy the Course, </p><div style="text-align: center;"> </div><div style="text-align: center;">Andrea Ferrari</div><div style="text-align: center;">Fedro Peccatori</div>
presentationDescription_en: <p style="text-align: center;"> Adolescents and young adults (AYAs) diagnosed with cancer make up a particular group of patients whose clinical and psychological needs differ substantially from those of pediatric patients or older adult patients. In recent years, the international scientific community has recognized the particular problems faced by AYA patients. There are several ways in which AYAs inhabit a middle ground between the worlds of pediatric and adult oncology, and neither pediatric nor adult healthcare models have proved capable of meeting their particular features which range from a unique epidemiology (with both pediatric-type and adult-type tumors occurring within the same age group) to a complex psychological sphere, from clinical challenges such as difficulty accessing specialized care and treatment trials to the need for ageappropriate hospital environments with dedicated facilities and programs. </p><p style="text-align: center;">Faced with these challenges, the scientific community should adapt to the needs of AYA patients with cancer by involving diverse health professionals from different disciplines, patient advocates, and stakeholders, possibly engaging on an international level. An excellent example of cooperation between adult and pediatric oncology societies in Europe comes from the European Society for Medical Oncology (ESMO) joining forces with the European Society for Paediatric Oncology (SIOPE) to establish a Working Group on AYAs. Similarly, in April 2021 the Italian Association of Medical Oncology (Associazione Italiana di Oncologia Medica, AIOM) joined forces with the Italian Association of Pediatric Hematology and Oncology (Associazione Italiana di Oncologia ed Ematologia Pediatrica, AIEOP) to set up a formal AIEOP-AIOM Working Group dedicated to AYAs. </p><p style="text-align: center;">Several local, national, and international projects have developed with the aim of improving chances of survival and quality of life. </p><p style="text-align: center;">In this 2-days congress, all the different aspects of AYAs with cancer will be discussed by a panel of international experts that have significantly contributed to elucidating the unique challenges for these patients. Enough time will be reserved for discussion, exchanging opinions and thoughts in addition to the presentation of national and international experiences. Thanks to Fondazione Menarini, we will be hosted in one of the most beautiful venues in Milan: Fondazione Giangiacomo Feltrinelli. </p><p style="text-align: center;">We hope you will enjoy the Course, </p><div style="text-align: center;"> </div><div style="text-align: center;">Andrea Ferrari</div><div style="text-align: center;">Fedro Peccatori</div>

title_it: Moving from umbrella terms to therapeutic features in airway disease: a paradigm shift
title_en: Moving from umbrella terms to therapeutic features in airway disease: a paradigm shift
presentationDescription_it: <h4 style="text-align: center;">Moving from umbrella terms to therapeutic features in airway disease: a paradign shift</h4><h4 style="text-align: center;">18th-19th November 2022 Prague</h4><p style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="color: #ff0000;">INTRO SPEECH</span></strong><br /></p><p style="text-align: center;">Step therapy has become the therapy of choice for non-communicable diseases. This therapeutic approach in chronic airway diseases is characterized by the gradual increase of longacting bronchodilators and/or inhaled corticosteroids. Unfortunately, although this strategy has significantly improved the outcomes of airway diseases, its drawbacks are now evident, and real therapeutic progress in these diseases has virtually come to a standstill. </p><p style="text-align: center;"> However, the new paradigm for modern healthcare is a proactive and personalized response to patients’ symptoms, combining precision diagnosis and personalized treatment. In response to the shortcomings of stepwise therapy, a new approach known as the ‘treatable traits’ method has emerged. The “treatable traits” approach involves individually assessing patients for a predetermined list of treatable conditions, then developing and implementing an individualized treatment plan based on this multidimensional evaluation. The adoption of an approach based on the discovery and treatment of verified treatable traits is expected to improve the efficacy and safety of therapies for complex human diseases in general and airway disorders/diseases in particular, </p><p style="text-align: center;"> Indeed, patients with chronic airway diseases have treatable lung characteristics, also defined treatable traits, such as airflow obstruction, exacerbations, and eosinophilic inflammation, which characterize many of the clinical phenotypes and may be present to different degrees in each patient. For these individuals, especially those with complex conditions such as severe asthma or multimorbid COPD, which tends to have more severe disease and increased co-morbidities, especially in the elderly, this new paradigm of disease management is very promising in terms of individualization of care and improved outcomes. </p><p style="text-align: center;"> Therefore, the motivations for organizing this international symposium are to provide an opportunity to discuss new knowledge concerning candidate treatable characteristics in airway disorders/diseases, examine the most suitable therapeutic approaches and identify pathways to implement treatable traits in practice, so that we can move from umbrella terms such as asthma and COPD to therapeutic traits.<br /></p><div style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="color: #ff0000;">CO-PRESIDENTS</span></strong></div><div style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="color: #000080;">Mario Cazzola</span></strong></div><div style="text-align: center;">Honorary Professor of Respiratory Medicine</div><div style="text-align: center;">Docens Turris Virgatae</div><div style="text-align: center;">Department of Experimental Medicine</div><div style="text-align: center;">University of Rome ‘Tor Vergata’ – Rome (IT)</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="color: #000080;">Vladimir Koblizek</span></strong></div><div style="text-align: center;">Head of Department of Pneumology, University Hospital Hradec Kralove,</div><div style="text-align: center;">Faculty of Medicine Hradec Kralove Charles University, Czechia</div><div style="text-align: center;">Scientific Secretary of Czech Pneumological and Phthisiological Society</div><div style="text-align: center;">Coordinator of the Czech Multicenter Research Database of COPD</div><div style="text-align: center;">Coordinator of the Pilot program of early detection of undiagnosed COPD (Czech Republic)</div><div style="text-align: center;"> </div>

title_it: EARLY-ONSET COLORECTAL CANCER Delphi initiative recommendations on EO-CRC (DIRECt): the path to improve diagnosis and clinical management
title_en: EARLY-ONSET COLORECTAL CANCER Delphi initiative recommendations on EO-CRC (DIRECt): the path to improve diagnosis and clinical management
venue: Sala L. Pirelli – Via Clerici, 5 - Milano
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center;">The incidence of colorectal cancer before the age of 50 is increasing. Patients with early-onset colorectal cancer (eoCRC) are managed according to CRC guidelines that are not specific for this age group. A multidisciplinary international group (DIRECt) was convened to develop the first evidence-based consensus recommendations for the management of eoCRC.<br /> The DIRECt group produced 28 statements in 7 areas of interest: diagnosis, screening, genetics, pathology-oncology, endoscopy, therapy, and end-stage disease.<br /> These are the first evidence-based consensus recommendations on eoCRC.</p> <p style="color: #ae0f0a; font-weight: bold; text-align: center;">PRESIDENT OF THE MEETING</p> <p style="text-align: center; color: #005a76; font-weight: bold;">Giulia Martina Cavestro</p> <p style="text-align: center; margin-top: -15px;">M.D. Ph.D. Gastroenterology and Gastrointestinal Endoscopy Unit<br /> Vita-Salute San Raffaele University<br /> San Raffaele Scientific Institute<br /> Milan, Italy</p>
presentationDescription_en: <p style="text-align: center;">The incidence of colorectal cancer before the age of 50 is increasing. Patients with early-onset colorectal cancer (eoCRC) are managed according to CRC guidelines that are not specific for this age group. A multidisciplinary international group (DIRECt) was convened to develop the first evidence-based consensus recommendations for the management of eoCRC.<br /> The DIRECt group produced 28 statements in 7 areas of interest: diagnosis, screening, genetics, pathology-oncology, endoscopy, therapy, and end-stage disease.<br /> These are the first evidence-based consensus recommendations on eoCRC.</p> <p style="color: #ae0f0a; font-weight: bold; text-align: center;">PRESIDENT OF THE MEETING</p> <p style="text-align: center; color: #005a76; font-weight: bold;">Giulia Martina Cavestro</p> <p style="text-align: center; margin-top: -15px;">M.D. Ph.D. Gastroenterology and Gastrointestinal Endoscopy Unit<br /> Vita-Salute San Raffaele University<br /> San Raffaele Scientific Institute<br /> Milan, Italy</p>

title_it: Convegno Internazionale di Suicidologia e Salute Pubblica XX EDIZIONE
title_en: Convegno Internazionale di Suicidologia e Salute Pubblica XX EDIZIONE
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center;">Benvenuti alla XX edizione del Simposio Internazionale sulla Suicidologia e la Salute Pubblica, che riunisce la comunità scientifica per una discussione approfondita sul rischio di suicidio, salute mentale, psicoterapia e farmacoterapia in campo psichiatrico.</p><p style="text-align: center;">La conferenza ospiterà relatori rinomati e opinion leader internazionali.</p>
presentationDescription_en: <p style="text-align: center;">Welcome to the XX edition of the International Symposium on Suicidology and Public Health, gathering the scientific community for an in-depth discussion on suicide risk, mental health, psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy in psychiatric field.</p><p style="text-align: center;">The conference will host renowned speakers and international opinion leaders.</p>

title_it: Gastritis RE.GA.IN Project
title_en: Gastritis RE.GA.IN Project
presentationDescription_it: <div>Helicobacter pylori infection, and its related gastric diseases affect more than one third of the world population; gastric cancer - a wellestablished consequence of the Helicobacter p. infection - is the 5th cause of cancer-death all over the world. Over the last three decades, a large body of knowledge has expanded our understanding of the epidemiology, etiology, natural history, and diagnostic criteria of gastritis.</div><div>The RE.GA.IN (Real-world Gastris Initiative) project is a scientific initiative, which aims to gather the interdisciplinary knowledge on gastritis and gastritis-related gastric malignancies and counts on the active involvement of 35 leading international experts of all Continents.</div><div><br /></div><div>The Faculty acts by establishing 5 “dedicated” working groups:</div><div>1. Gastritis and Gastric Cancer: Epidemiology in Different Continents</div><div>2. Etiology and Pathogenesis</div><div>3. Diagnosis: Clinical, Seriological, Molecular on Tissue</div><div>4. Diagnosis: Endoscopy and Histology</div><div>5. Natural History and Prevention Strategies</div><div><br /></div><div>The meetings will take place between May and November 2022. In this period of time, the experts will have multiple meetings in virtual mode for the critical evaluation of the available scientific evidence and for the necessary insights. The RE.GA.IN project will be concluded in Venice in November with an in-presence meeting summarizing the conclusions as achieved through the previous virtual scientific meetings.</div><div><br /></div><div>Prof. Massimo Rugge</div>
presentationDescription_en: <div>Helicobacter pylori infection, and its related gastric diseases affect more than one third of the world population; gastric cancer - a wellestablished consequence of the Helicobacter p. infection - is the 5th cause of cancer-death all over the world. Over the last three decades, a large body of knowledge has expanded our understanding of the epidemiology, etiology, natural history, and diagnostic criteria of gastritis.</div><div>The RE.GA.IN (Real-world Gastris Initiative) project is a scientific initiative, which aims to gather the interdisciplinary knowledge on gastritis and gastritis-related gastric malignancies and counts on the active involvement of 35 leading international experts of all Continents.</div><div><br /></div><div>The Faculty acts by establishing 5 “dedicated” working groups:</div><div>1. Gastritis and Gastric Cancer: Epidemiology in Different Continents</div><div>2. Etiology and Pathogenesis</div><div>3. Diagnosis: Clinical, Seriological, Molecular on Tissue</div><div>4. Diagnosis: Endoscopy and Histology</div><div>5. Natural History and Prevention Strategies</div><div><br /></div><div>The meetings will take place between May and November 2022. In this period of time, the experts will have multiple meetings in virtual mode for the critical evaluation of the available scientific evidence and for the necessary insights. The RE.GA.IN project will be concluded in Venice in November with an in-presence meeting summarizing the conclusions as achieved through the previous virtual scientific meetings.</div><div><br /></div><div>Prof. Massimo Rugge</div>

title_it: Asian Pacific Society of Cardiology Emerging Leaders Scholarship 2022
title_en: Asian Pacific Society of Cardiology Emerging Leaders Scholarship 2022
presentationDescription_it:
The Asian Pacific Society of Cardiology aims to facilitate communication, collaboration and professional development in the advancement of science and medical practice of cardiovascular diseases within the Asia-Pacific region.
Since the dawn of the 21st century, the Asia-Pacific region has been progressively thrust to the forefront of cardiology developments. Home to half the world population, alongside a rapidly ageing demographic, it is vital that the APSC hones the skills necessary for the next generation of leaders to spearhead progress within the field of Cardiology.
The APSC Emerging Leaders programme focuses on the qualities of an effective leader and the importance of building a team. In its fourth edition in 2022, we will also be focusing on hypertension, engaging key leaders as well as the emerging youngers.
You can expect discussion and engagement in the area of community project for the screening and treatment of hypertension, especially in underprivileged and underserved communities. We welcome you to join us in this educational endeavour, made possible with the support of Fondazione Internationale Menarini.

Jack Tan, Chair
Bijoy Khandheria, Co-Chair
Kenny Sin, Programme Director

title_it: New horizons in the therapy of gynecologic cancer
title_en: New horizons in the therapy of gynecologic cancer
presentationDescription_it:
In the last two decades the treatment of ovarian and endometrial carcinomas has achieved tremendous progress thanks also to the implementation of multidisciplinary boards and to the progress of knowledge of molecular biology. These seminars will discuss the state of the art in the treatment of ovarian and endometrial carcinomas and the new horizons of therapy. Particular attention will be paid to the asperts connected with virtual multidisciplinarity and the management of patients, aspects of these current issues in the field of Covid-19 panepidemic. This multidisciplinary approach plays a pivotal role in the management of women affected by ovarin or endometrial cancer since referral to high-volume oncological center is to date mandatory to assure best practice. Furthermore the impact of new knowledge on the molecular biology of these neoplasms will be discussed in depth.


Scientific Directors: Prof. Giovanni Scambia, Prof. Vito Chiantera, Prof. Vittorio Gebbia, Prof. Jalid Sehouli

title_it: XVI UPDATE IN OBSTETRIC ANESTHESIA
title_en: XVI UPDATE IN OBSTETRIC ANESTHESIA
presentationDescription_it:
L’anestesia ostetrica è un insieme di scienza e arte che, se opportunamente combinate, portano a un perfetto outcome di due o più pazienti strettamente intrecciati, la madre e il suo bambino. Negli ultimi anni i cambiamenti nella patologia materno-fetale sono stati uno stimolo per rapidi sviluppi dell’anestesia ostetrica tanto da rendere l’anestesista uno dei protagonisti dell’equipe del parto.
Anche questo XVI UPDATE vuole essere un' occasione per confrontarsi sullo stato dell’arte della pratica anestesiologica ostetrica, in continua evoluzione.
Il dibattito e le relazioni ci stimoleranno a riflettere sulle dinamiche interdisciplinari e sul loro potenziale per garantire standard qualitativi elevati
presentationDescription_en:
Obstetric anesthesia is a set of science and art which, when properly combined, lead to a perfect outcome of two or more closely intertwined patients, the mother and her child. In recent years, changes in maternal-fetal pathology have been a stimulus for rapid developments in obstetric anesthesia, so much so that the anesthesiologist has gained a leading role in the delivery team.
This XVI UPDATE is also intended to be an opportunity to discuss the state of the art of obstetric anesthetic practice, which is constantly evolving.
The debate and the reports will stimulate us to reflect on interdisciplinary dynamics and their potential to guarantee the highest quality standards.

title_it: Advances in pediatric heart failure congenital heart disease and cardiomyopathies
title_en: Advances in pediatric heart failure congenital heart disease and cardiomyopathies
presentationDescription_it: <p><strong><span style="color: #000080;">Dear Colleagues, </span></strong></p><p> <span style="color: #000080;">In recent decades, we have witnessed extraordinary progress both in the field of congenital heart diseases and of cardiomyopathies. These advances are largely driven by early cardiac surgery and interventional procedures, currently performed in very young patients, as well as exciting improvements in diagnostic tools, from advanced imaging to genetics. Tailored, disease-modifying therapies are on the horizon.<br />Nevertheless, heart failure in children and adolescents remains largely uncharted territory in cardiovascular medicine. Research initiatives in pediatric cohorts are limited, and management is often based on a one-size-fits-all adaptation of adult guidelines. Conversely, an age-specific and evidence-based approach is sorely needed. A more comprehensive approach to the problem will require multidisciplinary, concerted efforts, uniting the two most prominent areas in pediatric heart failure: congenital heart disease and genetic cardiomyopathies.<br /> This symposium has been designed to gather international experts from these two different but complementary perspectives and promote constant interaction with the audience. We hope that the synergy of such rich and diverse areas of expertise will help advance the field and improve the outlook of our youngest patients.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000080;"> Welcome to Florence!</span> </p><p style="text-align: right;"> <strong><span style="color: #000080;">The Course Directors</span></strong></p>
presentationDescription_en: <p><strong><span style="color: #000080;">Dear Colleagues,</span></strong></p><p><span style="color: #000080;">In recent decades, we have witnessed extraordinary progress both in the field of congenital heart diseases and of cardiomyopathies. These advances are largely driven by early cardiac surgery and interventional procedures, currently performed in very young patients, as well as exciting improvements in diagnostic tools, from advanced imaging to genetics. Tailored, disease-modifying therapies are on the horizon.<br />Nevertheless, heart failure in children and adolescents remains largely uncharted territory in cardiovascular medicine. Research initiatives in pediatric cohorts are limited, and management is often based on a one-size-fits-all adaptation of adult guidelines. Conversely, an age-specific and evidence-based approach is sorely needed. A more comprehensive approach to the problem will require multidisciplinary, concerted efforts, uniting the two most prominent areas in pediatric heart failure: congenital heart disease and genetic cardiomyopathies.<br />This symposium has been designed to gather international experts from these two different but complementary perspectives and promote constant interaction with the audience. We hope that the synergy of such rich and diverse areas of expertise will help advance the field and improve the outlook of our youngest patients.</span></p><p><span style="color: #000080;">Welcome to Florence!</span></p><p style="text-align: right;"><strong><span style="color: #000080;">The Course Directors</span></strong></p>

title_it: Anti-ageism Alliance A Global Geriatric Task Force for older adults’ care
title_en: Anti-ageism Alliance A Global Geriatric Task Force for older adults’ care
presentationDescription_it:
Rationale

Ageism, as defined by Robert Butler in 1969, is an attitude that discriminates, separates, stigmatizes, or otherwise disadvantages older adults on the basis of chronologic age. Ageism n healthcare is particularly common worldwide and well described as a social phenomenon affecting judgment about and treatment of older adults, potentially leading to both under - and over-diagnosis and -treatment. Thus, representing a major determinant of low quality of care in older adults. Moreover, Ageism may result in higher health care costs, social isolation, and low quality of life. Ageism mainly derives from a limited knowledge of aging process, geriatric medicine and the gerontological approach to older patients’ care. The aim of this conference will be to discuss and disseminate the principles of geriatric medicine with the final purpose to promote the implementation of the gerontological approach against Ageism. The conference will be aimed also to produce a final document: the “Florence Chart against Ageism”
During the meeting, the most influential scientists in geriatric and gerontological medicine will present their research, in the presence of Presidents of the main World geriatric societies. Other professionals involved in geriatric care against ageism will also participate (World Health Organization, United Nation, Ethicist, Patient’s associations)


Prof. Andrea Ungar
