title_it: PASADO, PRESENTE Y FUTURO EN LA MEDICINA DEL DOLOR
title_en: PAST, PRESENT AND FUTURE IN PAIN MEDICINE
presentationDescription_it: <p><br /></p><div style="text-align: center;"><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/Date_Venue(1).png" alt="" style="max-width: 80%;" /></div><p style="text-align: left;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: left;"><span style="color: #333399;">Fondazione Internazionale Menarini (FIM) has a long tradition in the organization of educational events on many medical specialties, including Pain Medicine, all around the world and on several different aspects of the scientific topics. Starting from this year, it has decided to organize a series of congresses named “Past, present and future in Pain Medicine”. Education on Pain Medicine is still lacking in large part of the world, and especially in some geographical areas. Those are the places where FIM is going to dedicate part of its future efforts.<br /> The first event of 2023 on Pain Medicine is organized in Cancun (Mexico), and will be realized with the scientific and educational support of the Paolo Procacci Foundation and of the Latino-American Federation of Pain Societies (FEDELAT). Its President, Prof. Marco Antonio Narvaez Tamayo, has always granted the best support, suggesting the more renowned Pain Physicians of the different Countries of Latino-America. Also in this occasion, he has granted the best. This edition is also supported by Prof. Rocio Guillen and the entire Local Organizing Committee.<br /> The scientific program will start with an intriguing session trying to show how the approach to Pain Patients has changed in the last few years. “Bridging old and new” will put in evidence how the exclusively pharmacologic therapy has been implemented by interventional approach, and how this approach has changed with the support of ultrasounds. The invasive techniques in pain management have grown very much, especially in the last years. For that reason, there is a full session on this aspect of patients’ treatment. The speakers will illustrate the importance of a good radio-anatomical knowledge, which is a basic pre-requisite for the interventional pain management, but also the technical advancements that allow the possibility to treat some specific pain syndromes with neuromodulation or with the use of radiofrequency.<br /> The future of Pain Medicine will be designed with presentations on the new horizons and the new therapeutic targets in the management of pain patients. Moreover, new interesting data will be reported on the influence that some “invasive management” has on systemic body reactions, like the immune response. A session on basic and prospectively clinical research on the sigma opioid receptors will close the first day.<br /> The second day will be dedicated to the clinical aspects of acute pain. The illustration of the most important acute pain guidelines, presented by a great expert, will open the session. This lecture will be followed by an intriguing and futuristic aspect: prehabilitation in perioperative medicine. A good general physical condition is definitely helping to afford the surgical stress in the best way. Of course, also an optimal strategy in the management of postoperative pain, and the use of a multimodal analgesia are of paramount importance to obtain the best results in surgical patients. These aspects will be clearly illustrated by two gurus of these clinical aspects of perioperative medicine. We cannot forget that all the analgesics, as any other drugs, have side effects. A full session is dedicated to some of them, trying in this occasion to illustrate the most important ones. Large part of the pain patients arriving to the attention of the Pain Physicians are multi-medicated, and it would be important to understand the potential dangers of this clinical condition. Then, respiratory depression (a life-threatening side effect) and opioid induced constipation (a side effect strongly influencing the quality of life) will be illustrated by two world renowned scientists that have spent a lot of their scientific energies to studying the topics. The educational event will be closed by a “round table” including all the Faculty, discussing and summarizing with the audience the different important aspects that have been illustrated during the two days.<br /> First of all, we thank Prof. Narvaez and the full FEDELAT Executive Board that have granted their scientific support to the initiative. Then, we thank the Local Organizing Committee, and especially Prof. Guillen, for their support in the organization. We also thank all the international Colleagues that have accepted to ensuring their honorary presence, and sharing what they themselves have gained through many years of study and clinical experience Lastly, we thank all of you for your interest in Pain Medicine and in the initiatives of the FIM. </span></p><p style="text-align: right;"> <strong><span style="color: #333399;">Giustino Varrassi</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: left;"><br /></p> <p style="text-align: center;"> <em>Thursday, 13 April 2023</em><br /> FACULTY MEETING <br /> <br /> <em>Friday, 14 April 2023</em><br /> SESSION I –BRIDGING OLD AND NEW<br /> SESSION II – INVASIVE MANAGEMENT OF PAIN<br /> SESSION III – FUTURE OF PAIN MEDICINE I<br /> SESSION IV – FUTURE OF PAIN MEDICINE II <br /> <br /> <em>Saturday, 15 April 2023</em><br /> SESSION V – ACUTE PAIN<br /> SESSION IV – SIDE EFFECTS IN PAIN MANAGEMENT <br /> <br /> <em>Saturday, 16 April 2023</em><br /> FACULTY MEETING </p>

title_it: Coronary artery disease and myocardial ischemic syndromes
title_en: Coronary artery disease and myocardial ischemic syndromes
presentationDescription_it: <p><span style="color: #333399;">Although coronary atherosclerosis (coronary artery disease) is a main cause of cardiac complications, including myocardial infarction, unstable and stable angina and sudden cardiac death, the link between the two is not univocal. Very often, coronary atherosclerosis does not translate into cardiac complications. Conversely – what we now would like to call, in a new comprehensive term – “myocardial ischemic syndromes” may recognize causes unrelated to the easily visible epicardial obstructive lesions. These may be explained by an interplay of vasoreactivity, inflammation, dissections, metabolic changes and – occasionally – extra-coronary or iatrogenic causes. Coronary causes may occur both in the large epicardial vessels and in the coronary microcirculation. Changes in myocardial metabolism may also cause or worsen myocardial ischemic syndromes. Most important, causes of myocardial ischemic syndromes often likely act in concert, also explaining the inadequacy of purely mechanical epicardial coronary interventions in “non-acute” myocardial ischemic syndromes. Recognizing the multiplicity of causes for myocardial ischemic syndromes paves the way to individualized, patient-tailored therapeutic approaches, clearly different in different settings.<br /> This expert meeting will offer an update on risk factors, mechanisms, diagnostics and management of myocardial ischemic syndromes summoning a group of world-class experts with ample space devoted to discussions and interaction. An important aspect of the meeting will be devoted to proposing a new nomenclature of “myocardial ischemic syndromes”, overarching current terminologies, notably still different between European and American cardiological societies. The meeting is dedicated to a restricted number of cardiology, cardiac surgery and internal medicine specialists. </span></p> <p style="color: #333399; float: right; text-align: center;"><strong>Raffaele De Caterina </strong><br /> Chair and Postgraduate School of Cardiology <br /> University of Pisa <br /><br /> <strong>Director</strong><br /> University Cardiology Division <br /> Pisa University Hospital <br /><br /> Pisa, Italy </p>
presentationDescription_en: <p><span style="color: #333399;">Although coronary atherosclerosis (coronary artery disease) is a main cause of cardiac complications, including myocardial infarction, unstable and stable angina and sudden cardiac death, the link between the two is not univocal. Very often, coronary atherosclerosis does not translate into cardiac complications. Conversely – what we now would like to call, in a new comprehensive term – “myocardial ischemic syndromes” may recognize causes unrelated to the easily visible epicardial obstructive lesions. These may be explained by an interplay of vasoreactivity, inflammation, dissections, metabolic changes and – occasionally – extra-coronary or iatrogenic causes. Coronary causes may occur both in the large epicardial vessels and in the coronary microcirculation. Changes in myocardial metabolism may also cause or worsen myocardial ischemic syndromes. Most important, causes of myocardial ischemic syndromes often likely act in concert, also explaining the inadequacy of purely mechanical epicardial coronary interventions in “non-acute” myocardial ischemic syndromes. Recognizing the multiplicity of causes for myocardial ischemic syndromes paves the way to individualized, patient-tailored therapeutic approaches, clearly different in different settings.<br />This expert meeting will offer an update on risk factors, mechanisms, diagnostics and management of myocardial ischemic syndromes summoning a group of world-class experts with ample space devoted to discussions and interaction. An important aspect of the meeting will be devoted to proposing a new nomenclature of “myocardial ischemic syndromes”, overarching current terminologies, notably still different between European and American cardiological societies. The meeting is dedicated to a restricted number of cardiology, cardiac surgery and internal medicine specialists.</span></p><p style="text-decoration-color: initial; color: #333399; float: right; text-align: center;"><strong>Raffaele De Caterina</strong><br />Chair and Postgraduate School of Cardiology<br />University of Pisa<br /><br /><strong>Director</strong><br />University Cardiology Division<br />Pisa University Hospital<br /><br />Pisa, Italy</p>

title_it: Past, present and future in Pain Medicine - Second Edition
title_en: Past, present and future in Pain Medicine - Second Edition
presentationDescription_it: <p>The 2023 decision of the Fondazione Internazionale Menarini (FIM), to organize a series of educational events dedicated to Pain Medicine has been appreciated very much. Hence, we are at the second edition just in a few weeks. “Past, present and future in Pain Medicine” in Cancun was a thrilling experience, especially because a structured education on Pain Medicine is still lacking in large part of the world.</p><p>This time we are in the Mediterranean area, cradle of deep classical cultures, and where our modern medicine was born. Historically, we could find the roots of pain medicine in most of our cultural heritages. Both Asklipios (Ασκλήπιος) and Hippocrates were concerned about pain of their “patients”, and addressed their cares to pain relief. The roots are even deeper in the Roman medicine deriving and taught by the Etruscans medicine, believed to be the best at that time because based on phytotherapy, but already including surgery. It is just useless to discuss of the advanced medicine of ancient Egypt, where the first knowledges belong to the first monarchical era (2700 BC). Herodotus was used to define the Egyptians “people of the very healthy”, thanks to the important health system they possessed, and to the existence of a doctor for every infirmity (first indication of specialization in the medical field, in the history of the mankind).</p><p>In the more recent times, the Mediterranean cradle has produced extraordinary physicians, like Tawhida&nbsp;Ben Cheikh. She was born in Tunis, in 1908, and has represented a light, an illuminating beacon, an example, for all the women of her age and the future generations. She was particularly interested to the health conditions in the women, including, but not limited to the family planning, and pain in women.</p><p>Now, Tunis is hosting the second edition of “Past, present and future in Pain Medicine”, with the support of several important Colleagues, especially women, interested in Pain Medicine and devoted to reduce the sufferance of their patients. They accepted with enthusiasm the invitation of the FIM to organize an important educational event, which may represent a new experience and a driving force for the young generations. Pain Medicine deserves the maximum of our attention, because, as our Great Guru, John Bonica (born in the Mediterranean), was used to say: patients should never suffer.</p><p>As a responsible for the organization of the scientific program, I would deeply thank all the Colleagues and Friends, who were such for large part of my life dedicated to Pain Medicine. They have accepted with enthusiasm to participate in this event and share their knowledge with all of us. All of them are strongly convinced of the importance to exchange information and learn from others the difficult art of reducing the sufferance of the humanity.</p><p>As we know from recent, dramatic news, this is not always interpreted as a simple and “transparent” mission. When facing suffering people, it could be easy to be attracted by easy earnings. Ethics and comprehension are crucial aspects for a Pain Physician. Maybe in one of the future editions of this educational event, the program will also focuses on these aspects, and not only on the science and the evidence-based results of studies on drugs or on interventional techniques, like it is in this occasion. Who will live will see (qui vivra verra).</p><p>Meanwhile, we all hope that you will enjoy the efforts of the FIM to diffuse the good, ethical knowledges on Pain Medicine, and to stimulate new finalized dreams in all of us, but especially in the new generations. The Paolo Procacci Foundation, requested to help with the scientific program, has tried to do its best. We all hope that you will appreciate and enjoy it.</p> <p style="text-align: center;">SCIENTIFIC PROGRAM COORDINATOR<br /> Giustino Varrassi </p>

title_it: HOT TOPICS IN CARDIOVASCULAR MEDICINE 2023 First edition
title_en: HOT TOPICS IN CARDIOVASCULAR MEDICINE 2023 First edition
venue: Congress Center of the Hotel Paradisus Cancun
presentationDescription_it: <h2 style="text-align: center;color: #005a76;font-weight: bold;">Friday 21 APRIL 2023</h2> <p style="text-align: center;color: #ae0f0a;font-weight: bold;"> SESSION I - CV RISK FACTORS<br /> SESSION II - HYPERTENSION <br /> SESSION III - HEART FAILURE<br /> SESSION IV - RECENT GUIDELINES IN CVD </p> <br /> <br /> <h2 style="text-align: center;color: #005a76;font-weight: bold;">Saturday 22 APRIL 2023</h2> <p style="text-align: center;color: #ae0f0a;font-weight: bold;"> SESSION V - HOT TOPICS IN CVD I<br /> SESSION II - CHRONIC CORONARY SYNDROMES <br /> SESSION III - HOT TOPICS IN CVD II </p> <br /> <br /> <p style="text-align: center; color: #ae0f0a;"><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">CO-PRESIDENTS OF THE MEETING</span></strong></p> <p style="text-align: center;color: #005a76;font-weight: bold;"><br /></p><p style="text-align: center;color: #005a76;font-weight: bold;"> C.Jerjes Sanchez Diaz<br /> C.Indolfi <br /> J.P. Lopez jaramillo<br /> P.Perroni Filardi<br /> G.Rosano </p><p><br /></p><p><br /></p><p> <span style="color: #000080;">Cardiovascular diseases are the leading cause of disability and mortality for global population and, despite new therapeutic options, their burden is projected to continue to increase in the next decade. Despite improved knowledge, availability of new therapies and devices and useful clinical guidelines issued by International societies, the vast majority of patients and individuals at risk are not adequately treated. There are many reasons for this including different social, financial, and health care conditions in different countries. <br /> It is clear that multiple risk factors have a major impact on the general population and that their multimodal modification will decrease incidence of coronary heart disease and there is eviden&#x2;ce that comprehensive risk factor management results in improved clinical outcomes, increased survival and improved quality of life. Furthermore, full implementation of guideline-directed medical therapy reduces cardiovascular events and mortality but often therapeutic inertia is the cause for the under-treatment of patients with cardiovascular diseases. During two-days mee&#x2;ting state of the art and future perspectives of cardiovascular medicine, including novel cardio&#x2;vascular risk factors hypertension, coronary artery disease and heart failure will be discussed by a renowned international faculty. <br /> We look forward to welcoming an international audience in order to provide the practicing phy&#x2;sician with the most up-to-date information in the latest scientific guidelines and at the same time give a comprehensive update of novel insights relevant both to the prevention and treat&#x2;ment of cardiovascular diseases</span></p> <p style="text-align: right;"> <strong><span style="color: #000080;">Prof. Carlos Jerjes Sanchez Diaz<br /> Prof. Ciro Indolfi<br /> Prof. Jose Patricio Lopez Jaramillo<br /> Prof. Pasquale Perroni Filardi<br /> Prof. Giuseppe Rosano </span></strong></p>
presentationDescription_en: <h2 style="text-align: center;color: #005a76;font-weight: bold;">Friday 21 APRIL 2023</h2> <p style="text-align: center;color: #ae0f0a;font-weight: bold;"> SESSION I - CV RISK FACTORS<br /> SESSION II - HYPERTENSION <br /> SESSION III - HEART FAILURE<br /> SESSION IV - RECENT GUIDELINES IN CVD </p> <br /> <br /> <h2 style="text-align: center;color: #005a76;font-weight: bold;">Saturday 22 APRIL 2023</h2> <p style="text-align: center;color: #ae0f0a;font-weight: bold;"> SESSION V - HOT TOPICS IN CVD I<br /> SESSION II - CHRONIC CORONARY SYNDROMES <br /> SESSION III - HOT TOPICS IN CVD II </p> <br /> <br /> <p style="text-align: center; color: #ae0f0a; font-weight: bold;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">CO-PRESIDENTS OF THE MEETING</span></p> <p style="text-align: center;color: #005a76;font-weight: bold;"> C.Jerjes Sanchez Diaz<br /> C.Indolfi <br /> J.P. Lopez jaramillo<br /> P.Perroni Filardi<br /> G.Rosano </p> <p> <br /></p><p><span style="color: #000080;">Cardiovascular diseases are the leading cause of disability and mortality for global population and, despite new therapeutic options, their burden is projected to continue to increase in the next decade. Despite improved knowledge, availability of new therapies and devices and useful clinical guidelines issued by International societies, the vast majority of patients and individuals at risk are not adequately treated. There are many reasons for this including different social, financial, and health care conditions in different countries. <br /> It is clear that multiple risk factors have a major impact on the general population and that their multimodal modification will decrease incidence of coronary heart disease and there is eviden&#x2;ce that comprehensive risk factor management results in improved clinical outcomes, increased survival and improved quality of life. Furthermore, full implementation of guideline-directed medical therapy reduces cardiovascular events and mortality but often therapeutic inertia is the cause for the under-treatment of patients with cardiovascular diseases. During two-days mee&#x2;ting state of the art and future perspectives of cardiovascular medicine, including novel cardio&#x2;vascular risk factors hypertension, coronary artery disease and heart failure will be discussed by a renowned international faculty. <br /> We look forward to welcoming an international audience in order to provide the practicing phy&#x2;sician with the most up-to-date information in the latest scientific guidelines and at the same time give a comprehensive update of novel insights relevant both to the prevention and treat&#x2;ment of cardiovascular diseases</span></p> <p style="text-align: right;"> <strong><span style="color: #000080;">Prof. Carlos Jerjes Sanchez Diaz<br /> Prof. Ciro Indolfi<br /> Prof. Jose Patricio Lopez Jaramillo<br /> Prof. Pasquale Perroni Filardi<br /> Prof. Giuseppe Rosano </span></strong></p>

title_it: TRANSLATIONAL RESEARCH IN PULMONARY FIBROSIS:FROM BEDSIDE TO BENCH AND BACK
title_en: TRANSLATIONAL RESEARCH IN PULMONARY FIBROSIS:FROM BEDSIDE TO BENCH AND BACK
venue: Savoia Excelsior Palace Trieste Hotel, Riva del Mandracchio, 4, 34124 Trieste, Italy
presentationDescription_it: <p>Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common type of idiopathic interstitial pneumonia that occurs with similar frequency of several cancers (stomach, brain, and testicular), and a prognosis not so different from lung cancer. Together with this disease there are several other secondary forms of progressive pulmonary fibrosis sharing similar pathogenesis and treatment with IPF. In the recent decades a tremendous effort was made by researchers all over the world to investigate the molecular and cellular mechanisms underpinning the pathogenesis of IPF and other pulmonary fibrosing disease. The availability of two specific anti-fibrotic drugs, such as pirfenidone and nintedanib, represented almost an advancement for the management of a previously orphan and neglected disease. Obviously, there is still a great expectaction for novel more effective therapeutics raising from new disease-paradigms to prevent and even more, to revert excessive tissue scarring in the lungs. This meeting organized by the Fondazione Menarini is aimed to show which are the most promising translational investigations on pulmonary fibrosis to-date giving a look to new insight into cellular and molecular players driving pulmonary fibrosis. All we hope to identify soon specific biomarkers to facilitate diagnosis and follow-up and, at the best, to develop novel effective treatments to improve the still bad prognosis of this devastating disease.<br /> The historical city of Trieste will host international recognized speakers and experts in this very interesting and challenging area of research to bring new hope for the patients and physicians who care for them. </p><p style="text-align: right;"> <strong><span style="color: #333399;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Prof. Marco Confalonieri </span></span><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><br /><span style="color: #333399;"><strong style="font-family: arial, sans-serif; text-align: start; text-decoration-color: initial;"><span style="font-family: Arial;">Prof. Sergio Harari</span></strong><br /></span></span></strong></p><p style="text-align: right;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><strong><span style="color: #333399;">Co-Presidents of the Meeting</span></strong></span></p>
presentationDescription_en: <p>Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common type of idiopathic interstitial pneumonia that occurs with similar frequency of several cancers (stomach, brain, and testicular), and a prognosis not so different from lung cancer. Together with this disease there are several other secondary forms of progressive pulmonary fibrosis sharing similar pathogenesis and treatment with IPF. In the recent decades a tremendous effort was made by researchers all over the world to investigate the molecular and cellular mechanisms underpinning the pathogenesis of IPF and other pulmonary fibrosing disease. The availability of two specific anti-fibrotic drugs, such as pirfenidone and nintedanib, represented almost an advancement for the management of a previously orphan and neglected disease. Obviously, there is still a great expectaction for novel more effective therapeutics raising from new disease-paradigms to prevent and even more, to revert excessive tissue scarring in the lungs. This meeting organized by the Fondazione Menarini is aimed to show which are the most promising translational investigations on pulmonary fibrosis to-date giving a look to new insight into cellular and molecular players driving pulmonary fibrosis. All we hope to identify soon specific biomarkers to facilitate diagnosis and follow-up and, at the best, to develop novel effective treatments to improve the still bad prognosis of this devastating disease.<br /> The historical city of Trieste will host international recognized speakers and experts in this very interesting and challenging area of research to bring new hope for the patients and physicians who care for them. </p><p style="text-align: right;"> <strong><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><span style="color: #333399;">Prof. Marco Confalonieri </span><br /></span><span style="color: #333399;"><strong style="font-family: arial, sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: start; text-decoration-color: initial;"><span style="font-family: Arial;">Prof. Sergio Harari</span></strong><br /></span></strong></p><p style="text-align: right;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><strong><span style="color: #333399;">Co-Presidents of the Meeting</span></strong></span></p>

title_it: Fridays for digital health
title_en: Fridays for digital health
presentationDescription_it:
Fridays for Digital Health is a project born under the endorsement of the World Hypertension League, co-organized by Fondazione Internazionale Menarini with technical support and organization by AIM Group International.

The purpose of this project is to discuss about the impact that digital health – which includes categories such as mobile health (mHealth), health information technology (IT), artificial intelligence (AI), wearable devices, telehealth, telemedicine and personalized medicine – could have on medical field.

A profiling questionnaire will be available from Friday, April 7th, until Wednesday, April 12th. After taking the questionnaire, users can enjoy a personalized scientific path enriched with a thematic webinar, infographic and a special invitation for a live event!

Click on the link to take the questionnaire and get ready to start your journey across digital health!


https://www.aimphygital.com/events/728ae482-0c5b-41b7-b6e1-3bf96fc25bf8

title_it: First International meeting on Brain-Kidney interaction
title_en: First International meeting on Brain-Kidney interaction
venue: Aula Magna - Congress Center Via Partenope, 36 - Naples (Italy)
presentationDescription_it: <p><span style="color: #000080;">Brain dysfunction is highly prevalent in the population. However, patients suffering from kidney disease have an even greater risk for brain dysfunction, compared to the remaining population. Unfortunately, the pathogenesis of brain-kidney dysfunction remains elusive. Neuropsychological and brain imaging data are now starting to be gathered, thereby characterizing this pathological entity. <br />&nbsp;Data from animal and cellular models suggest several mechanisms and possible avenues for future interventions: mono-aminergic systems, glymphatics, neural stem cells are among the neural structures vulnerable to uremic toxins and, in turn, responsible for the cognitive dysfunctions in chronic kidney disease and dialysis patients. Because kidney function can be replaced by artificial systems (dialysis) or renal transplantation, there is hope that this specific form of cognitive impairment might be prevented or even cured. Furthermore, the comprehension of brain-kidney interaction could disclose our understanding of other neurological diseases. This first meeting on brain-kidney axis will join renowned international speakers from different fields aiming at unraveling the mechanisms and future therapeutic options for this new clinical entity. The character of this meeting will insist on the interdisciplinary interaction among speakers (neurologists, nephrologists, neuroscientists, epidemiologists, renal physiologists, geriatricians, experts in regenerative medicine, precision medicine, imaging and diagnostics). <br />&nbsp;Finally, the meeting is very keen to enable young renal and neuroscience scientists to submit their excellent researches that will be discussed in two very highlighted poster sessions. <br /></span></p><p style="text-align: right;"><strong><span style="color: #000080;">Giovambattista Capasso</span></strong></p>
presentationDescription_en: <p><span style="color: #000080;">Brain dysfunction is highly prevalent in the population. Because kidney function can be replaced by artificial systems (dialysis) or renal transplantation, there is hope that this specific form of cognitive impairment might be prevented or even cured. Furthermore, the comprehension of brain-kidney interaction could disclose our understanding of other neurological diseases. This first meeting on brain-kidney axis will join renowned international speakers from different fields aiming at unraveling the mechanisms and future therapeutic options for this new clinical entity. The character of this meeting will insist on the interdisciplinary interaction among speakers (neurologists, nephrologists, neuroscientists, epidemiologists, renal physiologists, geriatricians, experts in regenerative medicine, precision medicine, imaging and diagnostics).<br />&nbsp;Finally, the meeting is very keen to enable young renal and neuroscience scientists to submit their excellent researches that will be discussed in two very highlighted poster sessions.<br /></span></p><p style="text-align: right;"><strong><span style="color: #000080;">Giovambattista Capasso</span></strong></p><span id="tempSpan"></span>

As a result, novel</span><br /><span style="color: #222222;">therapeutic modalities have been developed for these</span><br /><span style="color: #222222;">conditions that have significantly improved the quality of</span><br /><span style="color: #222222;">life for patients. This international symposium will focus</span><br /><span style="color: #222222;">on three frequently occurring inflammatory disorders of</span><br /><span style="color: #222222;">the gastrointestinal tract, including inflammatory bowel</span><br /><span style="color: #222222;">disease (Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis), celiac</span><br /><span style="color: #222222;">disease, and food allergies, which affect millions of</span><br /><span style="color: #222222;">individuals worldwide. title_it: PRECISION MEDICINE IN TUMOR PREVENTION: GENETICS OF HEREDITARY COLORECTAL, BREAST AND GYNECOLOGICAL CANCERS
title_en: PRECISION MEDICINE IN TUMOR PREVENTION: GENETICS OF HEREDITARY COLORECTAL, BREAST AND GYNECOLOGICAL CANCERS
presentationDescription_it: The International Symposium “Precision Medicine in tumor prevention:genetics of hereditary colorectal, breast and gynecological cancers”is dedicated to advancing the understanding of cancer genetics and itsimpact on the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of various types of cancer.<br />The symposium is designed to gather experts from around the world toshare their knowledge, research findings, and insights, contributing to theglobal effort in combating cancer.<br />During the first day, the focus will be on specific types of cancer, namelyendometrial, colorectal, breast, and ovarian tumors. Renowned expertsin the field of cancer genetics will present their latest research, cuttingedgediscoveries, and breakthroughs. They will shed light on the geneticfactors underlying the development of these cancers, explore innovativediagnostic techniques, and discuss therapeutic approaches that leveragethe knowledge of genetics for more effective treatments.<br />The second day promises an interactive and insightful session where amultidisciplinary approach will be employed to address challenging casesin the real world. This multidisciplinary discussion will involve varioushealthcare professionals, such as oncologists, geneticists, surgeons,radiologists, and other experts in the field. Together, they will analyzecomplex cases, considering various aspects of the patients’ conditions,medical histories, and genetic profiles. This collaborative effort aims tofind optimal solutions and personalized treatment plans, ensuring thatpatients receive the best care possible.<br />Furthermore, the symposium will offer a unique opportunity for attendeesto network, exchange ideas, and foster international collaborations.Researchers, clinicians, and healthcare professionals from diversebackgrounds will have a platform to engage in fruitful discussions, sharetheir experiences, and brainstorm new avenues for research and clinicalpractice.
presentationDescription_en: The International Symposium “Precision Medicine in tumor prevention:genetics of hereditary colorectal, breast and gynecological cancers”is dedicated to advancing the understanding of cancer genetics and itsimpact on the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of various types of cancer.<br />The symposium is designed to gather experts from around the world toshare their knowledge, research findings, and insights, contributing to theglobal effort in combating cancer.<br />During the first day, the focus will be on specific types of cancer, namelyendometrial, colorectal, breast, and ovarian tumors. Renowned expertsin the field of cancer genetics will present their latest research, cuttingedgediscoveries, and breakthroughs. They will shed light on the geneticfactors underlying the development of these cancers, explore innovativediagnostic techniques, and discuss therapeutic approaches that leveragethe knowledge of genetics for more effective treatments.<br />The second day promises an interactive and insightful session where amultidisciplinary approach will be employed to address challenging casesin the real world. This multidisciplinary discussion will involve varioushealthcare professionals, such as oncologists, geneticists, surgeons,radiologists, and other experts in the field. Together, they will analyzecomplex cases, considering various aspects of the patients’ conditions,medical histories, and genetic profiles. This collaborative effort aims tofind optimal solutions and personalized treatment plans, ensuring thatpatients receive the best care possible.<br />Furthermore, the symposium will offer a unique opportunity for attendeesto network, exchange ideas, and foster international collaborations.Researchers, clinicians, and healthcare professionals from diversebackgrounds will have a platform to engage in fruitful discussions, sharetheir experiences, and brainstorm new avenues for research and clinicalpractice.

title_it: The Three Gold Rules for the Future Sexual Medicine: Science, Culture, and Lifestyle
title_en: The Three Gold Rules for the Future Sexual Medicine: Science, Culture, and Lifestyle
venue: Kempinski Hotel Beijing Yansha Center Liangmaqiao Road 50, 100125 Beijing, China
presentationDescription_it: <p><span style="color: #000080;">East and West are two expressions that refer to what was once (in the West!) considered the center of the world: Rome. However, the boundaries between the two worlds have always been highly permeable, even when the distances required men to bridge enormous distances. This was the case for the Silk Road, which is not only a thousand-year-old highway of commercial traffic but an artery of culture, knowledge, and science. <br />Certainly, a symbol of the (re)discovery of the dialogue between the East (represented by the fabulous Cathay) and the West (represented by one of the most beautiful cities in the world: Venice) is epitomized by the incredible journey of Marco Polo, soon imitated by another great and courageous Italian scientist, Matteo Ricci. The encounter of the two Italians with oriental culture was immediately characterized by deep mutual respect, which still exists and continuously blooms again. <br />The medicine of sexuality is probably the youngest branch of internal medicine. Since its inception as a true science, more or less 25-30 years ago, it has been nourished by dialogue, openness, and by the knowledge of different scientific and cultural expressions that collaborate in the understanding of the biologically most important function of all: the sexual one and the dysfunctions that affect it. <br />This explains the reason for this meeting organized by the Menarini Foundation: a meeting of dialogue between scientists from Italy, where the medicine of sexuality has produced some of the most prolific researchers, accompanied by famous opinion leaders from Europe, America, and other parts of the “Western” world with great scientists from China, where the medicine of sexuality is snowballing, also accompanied by well-known opinion leaders from Korea and Vietnam and other parts of the “Eastern” world. <br />Dialogue and mutual learning are pivotal in every field of science, but above all, in sexual medicine, which increasingly bases its work not only on the hydraulic and pharmacological aspects but on the holistic, indeed systemic, understanding of the couple and their health. Therefore, it appears evident that the millennial tradition of traditional medicines can ideally dialogue with Western diagnostics and therapy of sexual dysfunctions, brilliantly overcoming the difficulties of mutual understanding that there may be present. I am sure that these goals - also thanks to the generous unconditional support of the Menarini Foundation which has always supported the research of excellence and the dissemination of scientific knowledge - will be achieved in this meeting which celebrates new horizons of bright collaboration between East and West in the young, exciting field of sexual medicine!</span> <br /></p><p style="text-align: right;"><br /><span style="color: #000080;"><strong>&nbsp;Prof. Emmanuele A. Jannini <br /></strong>&nbsp;President of the Meeting</span></p><p style="text-align: right;"><span style="color: #000080;"><img src="https://www.fondazione-menarini.it/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/firma-event.png" alt="" style="width: 169.238px; height: 55.4009px;" /><br /></span></p>

title_it: Convegno Internazionale di Suicidologia e Salute Pubblica XXI EDIZIONE

presentationDescription_it: Benvenuti alla XXI edizione del Simposio Internazionale sulla Suicidologia e la Salute Pubblica, che riunisce la comunità scientifica per una discussione approfondita sul rischio di suicidio, salute mentale, psicoterapia e farmacoterapia in campo psichiatrico.La conferenza ospiterà relatori rinomati e opinion leader internazionali.
presentationDescription_en: <div>Welcome to the XVII edition of the International Symposium on Suicidology</div><div>and Public Health, gathering the scientific community for an in-depth discussion on suicide risk, mental health, psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy in psychiatric field.The conference will host renowned speakers and international opinion leaders.</div>

title_it: Fridays for Digital Health
title_en: Fridays for Digital Health
presentationDescription_it: <p style="color: #0e101a; font-family: Tahoma; font-size: 12pt; text-align: left; margin: 0pt;"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Fridays for Digital Health</span><span>&nbsp;is a project born under the endorsement of the&nbsp;</span><span style="font-weight: bold;">World Hypertension League</span><span> and co-organized by&nbsp;</span><span style="font-weight: bold;">Fondazione Menarini</span><span>.</span></p><p style="text-align: left; margin: 0pt;"><span style="color: #0e101a; font-family: Tahoma; font-size: 12pt;">&nbsp;</span></p><p style="color: #0e101a; font-family: Tahoma; font-size: 12pt; text-align: left; margin: 0pt;"><span>The purpose of this project is to discuss the impact that&nbsp;</span><span style="font-weight: bold;">digital health</span><span>&nbsp;– which includes categories such as mobile health (mHealth), health information technology (IT), artificial intelligence (AI), wearable devices, telehealth, telemedicine, and personalized medicine – could have on the medical field.</span></p><p style="text-align: left; margin: 0pt;"><span style="color: #0e101a; font-family: Tahoma; font-size: 12pt;">&nbsp;</span></p><p style="color: #0e101a; font-family: Tahoma; font-size: 12pt; text-align: left; margin: 0pt;"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Register to the platform</span><span>&nbsp;to start your educational journey across digital health in cardiovascular. title_it: ACUTE CORONARY SYNDROMES From high-risk plaque to high-risk patient
title_en: ACUTE CORONARY SYNDROMES From high-risk plaque to high-risk patient
venue: Sala Quadrivium - Largo Eros Lanfranco, 8 - 16121 Genova (IT)
presentationDescription_it: <p><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/genova_img%20tab%20presentazione.jpg" alt="" /></p><p><br /></p> <p style="text-align: center;"> <strong><span style="color: #993300;">ACUTE CORONARY SYNDROMES From high-risk plaque to high-risk patient<br /><br /></span></strong></p> <p> During the past few decades, we have learned a great deal about the pathogenesis and mechanisms of acute coronary syndromes at the molecular, cellular, pathological and clinical levels. The concept of the so-called “vulnerable plaque” has guided research and thinking on this topic. Yet, as evidence has accumulated, the risk profile of our patients has shifted, and novel therapies have been reshaping atherosclerotic disease, with a transition from focusing on individual “vulnerable plaque” to understanding atherosclerotic disease as multifactorial and systemic disease. The main objective of this International Meeting will be to provide the latest update on this topic, from exploring the pathophysiological basis of the disease to its assessment with novel advanced imaging technologies and treatment. </p> <p>Prof. Italo Porto <br />Prof. Ik-Kyung Jang </p>
presentationDescription_en: <p><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/genova_img%20tab%20presentazione.jpg" alt="" /></p><p><br /></p> <p style="text-align: center;"> <strong><span style="color: #993300;">ACUTE CORONARY SYNDROMES From high-risk plaque to high-risk patient<br /><br /></span></strong></p> <p> During the past few decades, we have learned a great deal about the pathogenesis and mechanisms of acute coronary syndromes at the molecular, cellular, pathological and clinical levels. The concept of the so-called “vulnerable plaque” has guided research and thinking on this topic. Yet, as evidence has accumulated, the risk profile of our patients has shifted, and novel therapies have been reshaping atherosclerotic disease, with a transition from focusing on individual “vulnerable plaque” to understanding atherosclerotic disease as multifactorial and systemic disease. The main objective of this International Meeting will be to provide the latest update on this topic, from exploring the pathophysiological basis of the disease to its assessment with novel advanced imaging technologies and treatment. </p> <p>Prof. Italo Porto <br />Prof. Ik-Kyung Jang </p>

title_it: HEART IN VENICE: FROM ATHEROSCLEROSIS TO THE MANAGEMENT OF CORONARY ARTERY DISEASES
title_en: HEART IN VENICE: FROM ATHEROSCLEROSIS TO THE MANAGEMENT OF CORONARY ARTERY DISEASES
venue: THE HOME OF THE HUMAN SAFETY NET, PROCURATIE VECCHIE, 3RD FLOOR
presentationDescription_it: Atherosclerotic pathology is changing over time affecting younger people with a modest burden of risk factors. This aspect leads to a consideration on whether the guidelines and the consequent preventive actions are currently effective and adequate. Considering the fact of non-invasive and invasive diagnostic tools have made an extraordinary strides forward it’s time to match each other in an interdisciplinary approach,focusing on the patient with the real probability of coronary artery disease. In this regards aim to this meeting is that of reconsidering the role of guidelines, matching the different tools for diagnosing coronary artery disease, starting from pre-clinical phase to acute phase, through a clinical chronic state, and matching the latest interventional and medical therapies.
presentationDescription_en: Atherosclerotic pathology is changing over time affecting younger people with a modest burden of risk factors. This aspect leads to a consideration on whether the guidelines and the consequent preventive actions are currently effective and adequate. Considering the fact of non-invasive and invasive diagnostic tools have made an extraordinary strides forward it’s time to match each other in an interdisciplinary approach,focusing on the patient with the real probability of coronary artery disease. In this regards aim to this meeting is that of reconsidering the role of guidelines, matching the different tools for diagnosing coronary artery disease, starting from pre-clinical phase to acute phase, through a clinical chronic state, and matching the latest interventional and medical therapies.

title_it: III International Congress on Cardiovascular Diseases
title_en: III International Congress on Cardiovascular Diseases
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center; margin: 0pt 0pt 8pt;color: #993300;"><strong>III International Congress on<br />Cardiovascular Diseases<br />28th-29th November, 2023 - Taormina (IT)</strong></p> <p> In these last years we have witnessed an explosive growth of Cardiology involving both diagnosis and therapy fields. This has resulted in a marked improvement of patients’ management. Accordingly, a deep review of the diagnostic and therapeutic algorithms for all cardiovascular diseases has been introduced providing new models much more effective in clinical practice. The continuous update of the guidelines by the major international scientific societies (e.g., European Society of Cardiology) is the evidence of this wide dynamism of the knowledge in cardiovascular diseases. For all these reasons, the organization of an International Congress of Cardiology, where will attend international and national speakers who have highly distinguished in the research and clinic, assumes an important meaning. The main objective of the Congress will be to provide an appropriate scientific updating on major cardiovascular diseases such as heart failure, ischemic heart disease, valvular disease, cardiomyopathies, arrhythmias, cardio-oncology. One session will be dedicated to the role of imaging in the field of the important cardiovascular diseases. The program also includes some lectures on emerging issues The topics to be addressed and the quality of the international and national speakers is a guarantee of the high scientific profile and the good result of the congress.</p><div style="text-align: right;">Scipione Carerj</div><div style="text-align: right;">Giuseppe De Luca</div><div style="text-align: right;">Gianluca Di Bella</div><div style="text-align: right;">Antonio Micari</div>

This has resulted in a marked improvement of patients’ management. Accordingly, a deep review of the diagnostic and therapeutic algorithms for all cardiovascular diseases has been introduced providing new models much more effective in clinical practice. The continuous update of the guidelines by the major international scientific societies (e.g., European Society of Cardiology) is the evidence of this wide dynamism of the knowledge in cardiovascular diseases. title_it: RESPIRAMI: Recent Advances on Air Pollution and Health
title_en: RESPIRAMI: Recent Advances on Air Pollution and Health
venue: Centro Congressi Fondazione Cariplo, via Romagnosi 8
presentationDescription_it: <div>Reducing the incidence and prevalence of modifiable risk factors of noncommunicable diseases is a critical endeavor to tackle the global burden of these ailments that claim several millions lives per year globally, and thus to foster effective initiatives of primary and secondary prevention. Air pollution is one of the most important modifiable risk factors, owing to ubiquitous environmental and household exposure in low-income and high-income countries. With this background, in collaboration with the Environmental Research Group (ERG) of the Imperial College in London, UK, we organize for the fifth time the independent International Seminar RespiraMi, and summon in the Italian city of Milan (IT) an impressive faculty of experts to present the most recent data stemming from research completed in the last few years and to bring up to date present knowledge of the achieved progress.<br /><br /></div><div>In the first session, “New evidence supporting air pollution risk assessment”, speakers from European countries and the World Health organization critically analyze recent systematic reviews on the relation of morbidity and mortality to air pollution. Of particular interest and relevance is the report that, at the end of this opening session, evaluates the economic consequences of the impacts of air pollution on health.</div><div>The next four sessions of the first day of the Seminar update the current scientific evidence on the relation to air pollution exposure of four frequent noncommunicable diseases: cardiovascular and respiratory diseases, tumors as well as neurological and mental disease. The last session of the day is an innovative and until now poorly attempted effort to stimulate a cross-talk between medical specialists and general</div><div>practitioners with epidemiologists to understand the relevance for clinical practice of the accumulated evidence on the adverse effects of air pollution, and the role of clinicians in using this evidence with their patients. Equally important and cogent are the scientific sessions of the conference’s second day.<br /><br /></div><div>The poster presentation session deals with the update of research conducted on air pollution in Italy, a country characterized by a high degree of exposure, particularly but not exclusively in the northern region of the river Po valley. The next session evaluates the issues and recent progress in the assessment of the degree of exposure to air pollution, by using not only the traditional models of epidemiology but also</div><div>other equally effective and perhaps less costly approaches. The last session reports the policy and actions planned for the European Union and the UK to reduce the health risks of air pollution. The Seminar ends with a discussion and related reporting on which further evidence is warranted in order to support actions designed to reduce the health risks of air pollution in Europe and elsewhere.<br /><br /></div><div>The audience of the seminar will include scientists involved in the research on health effects of air pollution, public health specialists, experts on air quality assessment and management as well as representatives of organizations involved in actions designed to reduce health impacts of air pollution. The multidisciplinary discussion will serve both for better communication of the scientific knowledge to the wide public and identification of further questions to be addressed by research in order to improve prevention of the adverse impacts of air pollution on health.</div><div style="text-align: right;"><br /><br /><br />Francesco Forastiere</div><div style="text-align: right;">Sergio A. Harari</div><div style="text-align: right;">Michal Krzyzanowski </div><div style="text-align: right;">Pier Mannuccio Mannucci</div><div><br /></div>
presentationDescription_en: <div>Reducing the incidence and prevalence of modifiable risk factors of noncommunicable diseases is a critical endeavor to tackle the global burden of these ailments that claim several millions lives per year globally, and thus to foster effective initiatives of primary and secondary prevention. Air pollution is one of the most important modifiable risk factors, owing to ubiquitous environmental and household exposure in low-income and high-income countries. With this background, in collaboration with the Environmental Research Group (ERG) of the Imperial College in London, UK, we organize for the fifth time the independent International Seminar RespiraMi, and summon in the Italian city of Milan (IT) an impressive faculty of experts to present the most recent data stemming from research completed in the last few years and to bring up to date present knowledge of the achieved progress.<br /><br /></div><div>In the first session, “New evidence supporting air pollution risk assessment”, speakers from European countries and the World Health organization critically analyze recent systematic reviews on the relation of morbidity and mortality to air pollution. Of particular interest and relevance is the report that, at the end of this opening session, evaluates the economic consequences of the impacts of air pollution on health.</div><div>The next four sessions of the first day of the Seminar update the current scientific evidence on the relation to air pollution exposure of four frequent noncommunicable diseases: cardiovascular and respiratory diseases, tumors as well as neurological and mental disease. The last session of the day is an innovative and until now poorly attempted effort to stimulate a cross-talk between medical specialists and general</div><div>practitioners with epidemiologists to understand the relevance for clinical practice of the accumulated evidence on the adverse effects of air pollution, and the role of clinicians in using this evidence with their patients. Equally important and cogent are the scientific sessions of the conference’s second day.<br /><br /></div><div>The poster presentation session deals with the update of research conducted on air pollution in Italy, a country characterized by a high degree of exposure, particularly but not exclusively in the northern region of the river Po valley. The next session evaluates the issues and recent progress in the assessment of the degree of exposure to air pollution, by using not only the traditional models of epidemiology but also</div><div>other equally effective and perhaps less costly approaches. The last session reports the policy and actions planned for the European Union and the UK to reduce the health risks of air pollution. The Seminar ends with a discussion and related reporting on which further evidence is warranted in order to support actions designed to reduce the health risks of air pollution in Europe and elsewhere.<br /><br /></div><div>The audience of the seminar will include scientists involved in the research on health effects of air pollution, public health specialists, experts on air quality assessment and management as well as representatives of organizations involved in actions designed to reduce health impacts of air pollution. The multidisciplinary discussion will serve both for better communication of the scientific knowledge to the wide public and identification of further questions to be addressed by research in order to improve prevention of the adverse impacts of air pollution on health.</div><div style="text-align: right;"><br /><br /><br />Francesco Forastiere</div><div style="text-align: right;">Sergio A. Harari</div><div style="text-align: right;">Michal Krzyzanowski</div><div style="text-align: right;">Pier Mannuccio Mannucci</div><div><br /></div>

title_it: INFECTIOUS DISEASES IN THE MEDITERRANEAN BASIN IN A ONE HEALTH PERSPECTIVE
title_en: INFECTIOUS DISEASES IN THE MEDITERRANEAN BASIN IN A ONE HEALTH PERSPECTIVE
presentationDescription_it: <div style="text-align: left;">Twenty-three countries and territories from Europe, North Africa, and Middle Eastern Asia have coastlines along the Mediterranean Sea, which is almost entirely bordered by land. Throughout history, the Mediterranean Sea has served as a vital thoroughfare for merchants and travelers, facilitating commerce and cultural interchange among the diverse populations residing in the area. Over the past few years, the Mediterranean Sea has emerged as a prominent migration route utilized by individuals originating from developing nations who are in pursuit of improved prospects in Europe. From the coasts of Africa, hundreds of thousands of individuals traverse the Mediterranean, frequently in small vessels. While the majority made it to European coastlines, a considerable number perished in their endeavor to reach Europe. The aim of the Congress is to bring together the world’s leading experts on the main pathologies historically present in the Mediterranean area and on all those that represent a serious threat due to migratory flows, climate change, wars, and population dynamics also with the aim oflay the foundations for future research and scientific collaborations. With a comprehensive outlook and from a One Health perspective, we shall discuss antimicrobial resistance from veterinary medicine and agriculture in addition to human medicine. Emerging viral threats, difficult-to-treat infections, foodborne zoonoses, arthropod transmitted diseases, and diseases associated with migration and travel will be the main topics of the conference. <br /><br /> <p> <span style="float: left;">Prof. Antonio Cascio</span> <span style="float: right;">Prof. David Leslie Paterson</span> </p></div>

title_it: Functional and Oncological Uroandrology. The Point of View of World Experts
title_en: Functional and Oncological Uroandrology. The Point of View of World Experts
venue: Merchants Club - Gedimino pr. 35, 01108 Vilnius, Lithuania
presentationDescription_it: <!-- <p style="text-align:center;"><span style="color: #000080;"><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/Vilnius_img%20tab%20presentazione.jpg" alt=""/></span></p> --> <p><span style="color: #000080;">In recent years, urology and andrology have made great progress in terms of medical and surgical therapies. Medical therapies have gone in the direction of finding drugs against so-called orphan pathologies or with ineffective therapies such as chronic pelvic pain, induratio penis plastica and premature ejaculation. There has also been a development of new oncological drugs such as in prostate cancer. As regards surgery, there has been a great development of new techniques thanks also to biomedical technology. For two days, great world experts will discuss the reality of urology in Lituania for an exchange of scientific information where there will be plenty of space for discussion. <br /><br /></span></p><p style="text-align: right;"> <strong><span style="color: #000080;">Albertas Cekauskas <br />Nicola Mondaini</span></strong></p>
presentationDescription_en: <!-- <p style="text-align:center;"><span style="color: #000080;"><img src="/Portals/19/vgfm/HtmlEditorFondazione/Vilnius_img%20tab%20presentazione.jpg" alt=""/></span></p> --> <p><span style="color: #000080;">In recent years, urology and andrology have made great progress in terms of medical and surgical therapies. Medical therapies have gone in the direction of finding drugs against so-called orphan pathologies or with ineffective therapies such as chronic pelvic pain, induratio penis plastica and premature ejaculation. There has also been a development of new oncological drugs such as in prostate cancer. As regards surgery, there has been a great development of new techniques thanks also to biomedical technology. For two days, great world experts will discuss the reality of urology in Lituania for an exchange of scientific information where there will be plenty of space for discussion.<br /><br /></span></p><p style="text-align: right;"><strong><span style="color: #000080;">Albertas Cekauskas<br />Nicola Mondaini</span></strong></p>

title_it: POINT-OF-CARE TESTING: STATE-OF-THE ART AND PERSPECTIVES
title_en: POINT-OF-CARE TESTING: STATE-OF-THE ART AND PERSPECTIVES
venue: The Home of The Human Safety Net, Procuratie Vecchie, 3rd Floor Piazza San Marco, 128
presentationDescription_it: <p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 8pt; text-align: center;"><strong><span style="font-family: Calibri; font-size: 11pt;">POINT-OF-CARE TESTING: State of the art and perspectives</span></strong></p><p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 8pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: Calibri; font-size: 11pt;">Point-of-care testing (POCT) is the fastest-growing segment of laboratory medicine and the COVID-19 pandemic has raised an increasing concern on the adoption of POCT not only in traditional settings, namely critical care and disaster situations, but also in primary care, pharmacies, and for home testing,</span></p><p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 8pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: Calibri; font-size: 11pt;">There is no doubt that POCT represents a disruptive innovation in laboratory medicine, but the discussion about how to set analytical performance specifications, quality control and quality assurance as well as the training of operators needs further debate and initiatives.</span></p><p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 8pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: Calibri; font-size: 11pt;">The aim of this two-days meeting is to discuss the state of the art and future perspectives of POCT in different scenarios and clinical settings to provide recommendations and practical guidelines for a more effective and safe adoption of POCT.</span></p><p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 8pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: Calibri; font-size: 11pt;">The most influent experts of POCT have been invited to deliver lecturers and discuss the traditional and emerging technologies for molecular and genetic diagnostics, the role of Artificial Intelligence as an integrative tool and, in general, its role in value-based laboratory medicine.</span></p>
presentationDescription_en: <p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 8pt; text-align: center;"><strong><span style="font-family: Calibri; font-size: 11pt;">POINT-OF-CARE TESTING: State of the art and perspectives</span></strong></p><p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 8pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: Calibri; font-size: 11pt;">Point-of-care testing (POCT) is the fastest-growing segment of laboratory medicine and the COVID-19 pandemic has raised an increasing concern on the adoption of POCT not only in traditional settings, namely critical care and disaster situations, but also in primary care, pharmacies, and for home testing,</span></p><p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 8pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: Calibri; font-size: 11pt;">There is no doubt that POCT represents a disruptive innovation in laboratory medicine, but the discussion about how to set analytical performance specifications, quality control and quality assurance as well as the training of operators needs further debate and initiatives.</span></p><p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 8pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: Calibri; font-size: 11pt;">The aim of this two-days meeting is to discuss the state of the art and future perspectives of POCT in different scenarios and clinical settings to provide recommendations and practical guidelines for a more effective and safe adoption of POCT.</span></p><p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 8pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: Calibri; font-size: 11pt;">The most influent experts of POCT have been invited to deliver lecturers and discuss the traditional and emerging technologies for molecular and genetic diagnostics, the role of Artificial Intelligence as an integrative tool and, in general, its role in value-based laboratory medicine.</span></p>

title_it: COPD and Multimorbidity a conundrum in need of a rational approach
title_en: COPD and Multimorbidity a conundrum in need of a rational approach
presentationDescription_it: <p style="text-align: center; margin: 0pt 0pt 8pt;"><strong><span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 10pt;"><span style="color: #000080;">CLOSED WORKSHOP COPD and Multimorbidity a conundrum in need of a rational approach </span></span></strong></p><p style="text-align: center; margin: 0pt 0pt 8pt;"><strong><span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 10pt;"><span style="color: #000080;">Scientific Coordinator Bartolome Celli</span></span></strong></p><div style="text-align: center;"><div><strong>RATIONALE</strong></div><div><br /></div><div>Based on the long tradition of single organ classification of diseases, the identification of the cause of death or the burden of these diseases in the world is presented in silos, assuming that one single diagnosis is the responsible cause of the outcome. </div><div>This epidemiological information was very useful when infectious diseases were the primary cause of illness across the globe, when one agent, one cause, one disease was the rule. </div><div>However, the world population has aged, has been exposed to the environment for longer periods of time and as a result, non-communicable diseases are the most important causes of poor health and death globally. </div><div>Actually, multimorbidity is now considered the next “pandemic” to affect the inhabitants of the planet in which we live, and that the medical community should be prepared to face this challenge.</div><div>The multimorbid state is particularly relevant to patients with COPD caused by cigarette smoking, who on average suffer from 5 other identified morbidities that independently affect their health and increase their risk of death. </div><div>The morbidities seen in patients with COPD, can be evaluated by measuring their frequency as has been done in several studies. </div><div><br /></div><div>However, these associations assume that the patients with a diagnosis of COPD constitute a homogenous group, a fact that is far from real. </div><div>Indeed, unbiased hypothesis free analysis of several cohorts of COPD patients including clinical and laboratory characteristics have demonstrated the grouping of clusters with similar expressions of disease within each group and with significant differences amongst the clusters, including differences in the type of morbidities present in each cluster.</div><div>In 2006, the concept of Syndemics was first used by Singer and coworkers to define the aggregation of two or more diseases or other health conditions in a population in which there is some level of deleterious biological </div><div>or behavior interface that exacerbatesthe negative health effects of any or all of the diseases involved. </div><div>Primarily used in the field of epidemiology it can be useful in the context of mutimorbidity whereby syndemics refers to the occurrence of disease clusters which have biological interactions that exacerbate the overall prognosis and burden of disease.</div><div><br /></div><div>With the support of the Menarini Foundation, we have built this closed forum, to review the state of the art of the most important morbidities associated with COPD and explore how to best approach this reality. </div><div>We look forward to an important exchange of constructive ideas, so we can look ahead with optimism. </div><div>A change in paradigm is needed, if we are to help our COPD patients live a longer and healthier life.</div><div><em>Bartolome Celli</em></div></div>

a fact that is far from real.</div><div style="text-align: center;">Indeed, unbiased hypothesis free analysis of several cohorts of COPD patients including clinical and laboratory characteristics have demonstrated the grouping of clusters with similar expressions of disease within each group and with significant differences amongst the clusters, including differences in the type of morbidities present in each cluster.</div><div style="text-align: center;">In 2006, the concept of Syndemics was first used by Singer and coworkers to define the aggregation of two or more diseases or other health conditions in a population in which there is some level of deleterious biological</div><div style="text-align: center;">or behavior interface that exacerbatesthe negative health effects of any or all of the diseases involved.</div><div style="text-align: center;">Primarily used in the field of epidemiology it can be useful in the context of mutimorbidity whereby syndemics refers to the occurrence of disease clusters which have biological interactions that exacerbate the overall prognosis and burden of disease.</div><div style="text-align: center;"><br /></div><div style="text-align: center;">With the support of the Menarini Foundation, we have built this closed forum, to review the state of the art of the most important morbidities associated with COPD and explore how to best approach this reality.</div><div style="text-align: center;">We look forward to an important exchange of constructive ideas, so we can look ahead with optimism.</div><div style="text-align: center;">A change in paradigm is needed, if we are to help our COPD patients live a longer and healthier life.</div><div style="text-align: center;"><em>Bartolome Celli</em></div>

title_it: Essential Concepts in Cardiopulmonary Medicine: Hypertension, Heart Failure, Ischemic Heart Disease and Respiratory Illness
title_en: Essential Concepts in Cardiopulmonary Medicine: Hypertension, Heart Failure, Ischemic Heart Disease and Respiratory Illness
venue: CTIIC 2 (CapeTown International Convention Centre), Corner of Heerenggracht and Rua Bartholomeu Dias, Foreshore, Cape Town, 8001, Sud Africa
presentationDescription_it: <div style="text-align: center;"><div><strong>INTRO SPEECH<br /><br /></strong></div><div>Hypertension, heart failure, ischemic heart disease and respiratory illnesses pose huge health</div><div>challenges in Africa. These chronic conditions are major contributors to the rising burden</div><div>of non-communicable diseases on the continent. The epidemiological transition, coupled</div><div>with urbanization, pollution, aging populations and changes in lifestyle behaviors have precipitated</div><div>a sharp increase in the prevalence of these diseases across Africa over recent decades.</div><div>African women appear to be particularly vulnerable to the epidemiological transition.</div><div>Hypertension rates across Africa are among the highest in the world, with recent systematic</div><div>reviews estimating a 30-35% prevalence among adult populations in many countries. This</div><div>equates to over 130 million hypertensive cases continent-wide. Worryingly, levels of awareness,</div><div>treatment and control also remain very low. Heart failure prevalence has risen to 3-7%</div><div>in many settings. While ischemic heart disease has traditionally been less common in Africa</div><div>compared to higher income regions, age-standardized death rates attributable to ischemic</div><div>heart disease increased by over 50% in the region from 1990 to 2019 based on data from the</div><div>Global Burden of Disease study, reflecting changing patterns likely influenced by the rise in</div><div>hypertension, obesity and other risk factors.</div><div>Respiratory conditions also contribute substantially to morbidity and healthcare spending</div><div>across Africa. There were over 250 million new cases of pneumonia in adults and children in</div><div>2019, along with over 170,000 deaths. Asthma prevalence ranges from 5-20% across African</div><div>nations. COPD prevalence sits between 13-16% among adults in many countries as well, due</div><div>in large part to indoor and outdoor air pollution, tobacco use, and occupational exposures.</div><div>Progress has been made globally in reducing communicable respiratory diseases like tuberculosis</div><div>and HIV-related pneumonia due to expanded testing and treatment efforts. However,</div><div>more focus is still required on tackling non-communicable respiratory illness that commonly</div><div>lead to right heart failure and premature death.</div><div>As Africa contends with these epidemiological shifts, strengthening health systems to ensure</div><div>universal screening, early diagnosis, access to affordable medications and ongoing care will</div><div>be paramount. There are also major gaps and geographical disparities in terms of availability</div><div>of cardiac rehabilitation programs or critical care services that need addressing. Clear opportunities</div><div>exist to enhance community-based prevention efforts, self-management training,</div><div>frontline provider capacity and treatment optimization as well.</div><div>The meeting, supported by the Fondazione Menarini will discuss the wealth of global evidence</div><div>around interventions that can effectively reduce risk, limit hospitalisations, improve</div><div>quality of life and prevent premature mortality from heart disease, stroke, kidney disease</div><div>and lung disease and will provide a chance to catalyse key world opinion leaders, including</div><div>those from across the region, in assessing specific needs and bringing contextually-appropriate</div><div>solutions to scale that can curb the rising burden of these chronic illnesses in Africa.</div><div><br /></div><div><strong><br />Co-Presidents of the meeting</strong></div>Giuseppe Rosano<br />Karen Sliwa-Hahnle<br />Brian Rayner<br />Periachille Santus</div>

title_it: 2^ MASTERCLASS SIF-ECPG “PHARMACOLOGISTS 2.0”
title_en: 2^ MASTERCLASS SIF-ECPG “PHARMACOLOGISTS 2.0”
presentationDescription_it: <p>The SIF Early Career Pharmacologists group was established in May 2023 with the purpose of promoting scientific initiatives for young SIF members under 38. These initiatives are aimed at supporting professional growth and collaboration within the group itself. From this perspective, knowledge and experiences in terms of leadership, understood as the development of hard and soft skills, represent an instrument to develop vision, new behaviours and new ways of working. This masterclass aims to enrich pharmacologists with advanced skills regarding grant writing, public speaking, innovative teaching and editorial dynamics.</p><p><br /></p><p style="text-align: right;">SIF-ECPG Committee<br /></p>
presentationDescription_en: <p>The SIF Early Career Pharmacologists group was established in May 2023 with the purpose of promoting scientific initiatives for young SIF members under 38.
